questions.text: What is the most likely block being performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interscalene brachial plexus block

 

  • The interscalene block targets the roots/trunks of the brachial plexus. 
  • On ultrasound, they appear as round hypoechoic structures situated between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, typically at the level of C6 (cricoid cartilage).
  • The layout is often referred to as a “traffic signal sign”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Supraclavicular brachial plexus block: The plexus appears as a cluster lateral to the subclavian artery above the first rib and pleura.

 

Option C. Infraclavicular brachial plexus block: Cords are seen around the axillary artery, deeper, under the clavicle.

 

Option D.  Axillary brachial plexus block: Nerves surround the axillary artery and vein, visualized in the axilla.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The interscalene brachial plexus block targets the roots/trunks of the plexus between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, visible as round hypoechoic structures at the level of C6 on ultrasound.

choices.text: Large-loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ)

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman undergoes a cervical biopsy after an abnormal Pap smear. The histopathology reveals cells with irregular nuclei consistent with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 3 (CIN3). What is the most appropriate next step in management to prevent progression to invasive cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Large-loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) 

 

  • The biopsy report confirms CIN3, which is a high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. 
  • CIN3 is considered a precancerous lesion with a significant risk of progression to invasive carcinoma if left untreated. 
  • To effectively treat CIN3 and prevent progression, the standard and most commonly used method is large-loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ). 
  • This technique involves the removal of abnormal cervical tissue using a diathermy loop and is highly effective, well-tolerated, and fertility-preserving.
  • The document specifically states that: "CIN needs to be treated to prevent progression over several years to cervical carcinoma. The commonest treatment is large-loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) – removal of abnormal cervical tissue with a diathermy loop."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryotherapy of the cervix: Although used for low-grade lesions (e.g., CIN1), cryotherapy is not effective for CIN3 as it does not allow for histological confirmation of margin clearance or precise removal of transformation zone tissue.

 

Option C. Repeat Pap smear in 6 months: CIN3 is a high-grade lesion and requires immediate intervention. Observation or delayed follow-up is not appropriate due to the high risk of malignant progression.

 

Option D. Total abdominal hysterectomy: While this is a treatment option in women with recurrent CIN3 or if malignancy is confirmed, it is not the first-line treatment for initial CIN3 in a young woman, especially one desiring future fertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN3) should be promptly treated with large-loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) to prevent progression to cervical carcinoma.

choices.text: Disk diffusion with increased incubation time

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with bacterial endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis requires precise dosing of ampicillin. The lab reports a large zone of inhibition around an ampicillin disk, suggesting susceptibility, but the clinician needs the exact MIC to tailor therapy. Which of the following methods will provide the MIC value for ampicillin against this organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epsilometer (E-test) strip on agar

 

The E-test combines diffusion and dilution principles: a plastic strip with a gradient of antibiotic yields an elliptical zone of inhibition whose intersection with the strip’s scale indicates the MIC in µg/mL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kirby–Bauer disk diffusion: Provides only categorical results (S, I, R) based on zone diameters, not a numeric MIC.

 

Option C. Disk diffusion with increased incubation time: Does not convert qualitative zone sizes into quantitative MIC values.

 

Option D. Gram stain and morphology: Offers rapid identification, but no susceptibility data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E-test strip is a viable, agar-based method to obtain a quantitative MIC directly from zone-of-inhibition endpoints.

questions.text: A hypopigmented patch is noted on the trunk since birth. It appears chalky to dull white under Wood’s lamp, and Diascopy is negative (no blanching). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nevus depigmentosus

 

  • Congenital onset (since birth): Points toward developmental causes of hypopigmentation such as nevus depigmentosus or nevus anaemicus.
  • Wood’s lamp shows chalky/dull white enhancement: Suggests some degree of melanin reduction, not complete loss.
  • Diascopy is negative (no blanching): Supports nevus depigmentosus.
  • Congenital lesion due to defective melanosome transfer (not complete melanocyte absence).
  • Chalky/dull white appearance under Wood’s lamp (partial pigment loss).
  • Diascopy is negative.
  • Stable in size and distribution over time.
  • Classic presentation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitiligo:

 

  • Acquired autoimmune depigmentation.
  • Shows brilliant bright white enhancement under Wood’s lamp due to total absence of melanin.
  • Not congenital.
  • Ruled out.

 

Option C. Nevus anaemicus:

 

  • Also congenital, but due to vascular hypersensitivity causing localized vasoconstriction.
  • Does not enhance under Wood’s lamp because melanin is normal.
  • On diascopy, the lesion becomes indistinguishable from surrounding skin.
  • Ruled out based on Wood’s lamp.

 

 

Option D. Indeterminate leprosy:

 

  • Acquired, not congenital.
  • Often associated with loss of sensation, which is not mentioned here.
  • May show subtle enhancement on Wood’s lamp depending on pigment status.
  • Eliminated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nevus depigmentosus is a congenital hypopigmented macule caused by defective melanosome transfer, showing partial enhancement under Wood’s lamp. 
  • It remains stable over time, and diascopy is generally not helpful. 
  • It should be distinguished from vitiligo (acquired, complete depigmentation) and nevus anaemicus (vascular origin, no enhancement under Wood's lamp).

choices.text: Detection of infection in a mycotic aortic aneurysm
Assessment of lymph node involvement by malignancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not an appropriate indication for positron emission tomography (PET)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Detection of infection in a mycotic aortic aneurysm

 

  • While 18-FDG‑PET can identify metabolically active processes, it is not the first‑line modality for diagnosing mycotic (infected) aneurysms. 
  • CT angiography combined with blood cultures and inflammatory markers is more reliable. 
  • PET lacks sufficient anatomic resolution, and increased uptake may be nonspecific in the aorta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Characterization of a solitary pulmonary nodule: PET accurately differentiates benign vs. malignant nodules based on FDG uptake, with high sensitivity and specificity.

 

Option C. Staging of lung cancer: Whole‑body PET/CT is standard for detecting both regional nodal and distant metastases, guiding treatment decisions.

 

Option D. Assessment of lymph node involvement by malignancy: PET identifies hypermetabolic lymph nodes even when they are not enlarged on CT, improving nodal staging across many cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Use PET primarily for oncologic indications—characterizing nodules, staging cancers, and evaluating lymph nodes—while relying on CT angiography and clinical/lab data to diagnose and manage mycotic aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents for evaluation of recurrent pregnancy loss. She has had three consecutive first-trimester miscarriages. Laboratory evaluation reveals a positive anticardiolipin antibody on two separate occasions, 8 weeks apart. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antiphospholipid syndrome

 

  • This patient meets both clinical and hematological criteria for Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS) as defined in the provided reference:
    • Clinical feature: Three or more consecutive miscarriages (a major obstetric criterion for APS)
    • Hematological feature: Lupus anticoagulant positivity detected on two occasions at least 6 weeks apart
  • APS is an autoimmune, prothrombotic condition that can lead to recurrent miscarriage, particularly in the first trimester. 
  • It is a key cause of recurrent pregnancy loss and must be differentiated from chromosomal, anatomic, or hormonal causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luteal phase defect: This involves insufficient progesterone production in the luteal phase, which may contribute to infertility or early miscarriage but is not diagnosed by antibody testing, and it does not fulfill APS criteria.

 

Option B. Balanced translocation in one parent: While parental chromosomal translocations can lead to recurrent pregnancy loss, this would be identified by karyotyping, not by antibody tests, and is not associated with thrombosis or autoimmune markers.

 

Option D. Progesterone receptor mutation: This is a rare genetic cause of pregnancy failure, often implicated in implantation issues, and is not connected to recurrent thrombosis or immunologic abnormalities like lupus anticoagulant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To diagnose antiphospholipid syndrome, there must be at least one clinical criterion (e.g., ≥3 consecutive miscarriages, fetal loss, severe pre-eclampsia, or thrombosis) and one hematologic criterion (positive lupus anticoagulant or anticardiolipin antibody on 2 occasions ≥6 weeks apart).

choices.text: Repeat pharmacologic stress test with perfusion imaging

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a 3-week history of intermittent exertional substernal chest pain undergoes an ECG exercise stress test. Report: Exercise capacity of 4 METs (stopped due to angina). His ECG during peak exercise is shown. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coronary angiography

 

  • Exertional chest pain with high-risk stress test (angina @ 4 METs, diffuse ST depressions, aVR elevation) suggests severe CAD (left main or multivessel).
  • Poor exercise tolerance and ECG changes indicate significant ischemia.
  • Angiography defines anatomy for revascularization (PCI/CABG).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac MRI: For viability, not high-risk CAD.

 

Option C. Coronary CT angiography (CTA): For low-intermediate risk, not high-risk.

 

Option D. Repeat pharmacologic stress test with perfusion imaging: Redundant with clear high-risk findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High-risk stress test requires urgent angiography.
  • ST depressions and aVR elevation suggest severe CAD.
  • Angiography guides revascularization.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical locations is most likely lined by this type of cartilage given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Articular surfaces of joints

 

  • The tissue described—smooth, glassy, avascular cartilage with chondrocytes in lacunae embedded in a homogeneous matrix—is hyaline cartilage, which is the predominant cartilage type found on the articular surfaces of joints.
  •  It provides low-friction articulation and resists compressive forces due to its high water content and type II collagen fibers.
  • In the histological slide, the lacunae with single or grouped chondrocytes and a translucent extracellular matrix are classical for hyaline cartilage, confirming the tissue identity. 
  • Importantly, hyaline cartilage in articular surfaces lacks perichondrium, further differentiating it from other sites where it might be found.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intervertebral disc: Incorrect. This region contains fibrocartilage, not hyaline cartilage. Fibrocartilage has dense type I collagen bundles and fewer chondrocytes, typically arranged in rows between the collagen fibers.

 

Option B. Epiglottis: Incorrect. The epiglottis is composed of elastic cartilage, which contains elastin fibers, making it flexible and resilient. It also differs histologically by having a darker staining due to elastin content and presence of perichondrium.

 

Option D. External ear: Incorrect. Like the epiglottis, the external ear (auricle) is made of elastic cartilage, not hyaline cartilage. Elastic cartilage provides structural support with flexibility, and the presence of elastic fibers is a distinguishing feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Articular surfaces of synovial joints are lined by hyaline cartilage, characterized histologically by chondrocytes in lacunae and an avascular matrix composed primarily of type II collagen.

choices.text: Used in the treatment of hypernatremia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding conivaptan?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vasopressin antagonist

 

  • Conivaptan is a non-selective vasopressin (ADH) receptor antagonist, targeting both V1A and V2 receptors. 
  • It promotes free water excretion without electrolyte loss, making it useful in the treatment of euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia, such as in SIADH or heart failure. It is administered intravenously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. V2 selective action: Incorrect. Tolvaptan, not conivaptan, is selective for V2 receptors.

 

Option C. Given orally: Incorrect. Conivaptan is available only as an IV preparation.

 

Option D. Used in the treatment of hypernatremia: Incorrect. It raises serum sodium and is used to correct hyponatremia, not hypernatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conivaptan is a non-selective V1A and V2 vasopressin receptor antagonist used intravenously to treat euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman from rural Southeast Asia presents with a 3-month history of chronic cough with rusty-colored sputum, intermittent pleuritic chest pain, and low-grade fever. She often consumes undercooked freshwater crabs. The image below shows the adult form of a trematode found in sputum. Which of the following is the most likely parasite responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paragonimus westermani

 

  • Paragonimus westermani is known as the lung fluke (as it is the only trematode that affects the lungs).
  • Transmission: Ingestion of undercooked freshwater crabs or crayfish.
  • Clinical features:
    • Chronic cough
    • Rusty (hemoptysis-like) sputum
    • Pleuritic chest pain
    • May mimic tuberculosis
  • Diagnosis: Finding eggs or adult worms in sputum; the adult worm is thick, ovoid, and often pigmented as seen in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Opisthorchis viverrini:

 

  • A liver fluke found in Southeast Asia, but causes biliary tract disease, not pulmonary symptoms.
  • Associated with cholangiocarcinoma, not cough or hemoptysis.
  • 2nd intermittent host is fresh water fish

 

Option C. Fasciola hepatica:

 

  • Also a liver fluke.
  • Causes hepatic symptoms (RUQ pain, hepatomegaly), not lung disease.
  • Ingested from contaminated water plants (like watercress - 2nd intermittent host), not crabs.

 

Option D. Clonorchis sinensis:

 

  • Also affects the biliary tract.
  • Found in East Asia, transmitted via raw freshwater fish (2nd intermittent host).
  • Causes cholangitis, not respiratory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paragonimus westermani is the cause of chronic cough with hemoptysis-like sputum in patients from endemic areas who consume raw or undercooked crabs (2nd intermittent host), and differentiate it from other trematodes based on organ system involvement.

 

Note – For all trematodes 1st intermittent host is Snail

choices.text: Evidence of tumor invasion through the capsule and into blood vessels
Complete absence of colloid in thyroid follicles
Sudden and rapid increase in tumor size
Detection of metastatic spread to regional lymph nodes

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging neck mass over the past year. Fine-needle aspiration suggests a follicular-patterned thyroid neoplasm, but a definitive diagnosis is deferred until surgical excision. Histopathologic examination after lobectomy confirms malignant transformation. Which of the following best defines malignancy in this type of thyroid cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evidence of tumor invasion through the capsule and into blood vessels

 

  • In follicular carcinoma of the thyroid, the hallmark criterion for malignancy is capsular and/or vascular invasion on histologic examination.
  • Follicular carcinoma cannot be definitively distinguished from follicular adenoma on cytology alone because both can have a follicular growth pattern.
  • The diagnosis requires histopathologic confirmation showing the tumor breaching the capsule and/or invading blood vessels.
  • This invasive behavior enables hematogenous spread, commonly to lungs, bones, and liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete absence of colloid in thyroid follicles: Follicles without colloid can be seen in hyperplastic nodules or other thyroid pathologies but do not define malignancy in follicular carcinoma.

 

Option C. Sudden and rapid increase in tumor size: While rapid growth may suggest aggressive behavior or anaplastic transformation, it is not the histologic criterion for malignancy in follicular carcinoma.

 

Option D. Detection of metastatic spread to regional lymph nodes: Lymphatic spread is more typical of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Follicular carcinoma primarily spreads via hematogenous routes rather than to lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is diagnosed by histologic evidence of capsular and/or vascular invasion. 
  • Fine-needle aspiration cannot distinguish adenoma from carcinoma; surgical excision and pathology are necessary for diagnosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and its branches are incorrect?

 

  1. The pericallosal artery, a branch of the ACA, supplies the lateral surface of the frontal lobe.
  2. The ACA supplies the paracentral lobule, which is involved in coordination of voluntary eye movement.
  3. The ACA supplies the paracentral lobule, which governs micturition and defecation control.
  4. The ACA territory includes the medial surface of the motor cortex responsible for lower limb movement.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2

 

Statement 1. The pericallosal artery, a branch of the ACA, supplies the lateral surface of the frontal lobe: Incorrect. The pericallosal artery, a branch of the ACA, supplies the medial (not lateral) surfaces of the frontal and parietal lobes, especially the genu of the corpus callosum.

 

Statement 2. The ACA supplies the paracentral lobule, which is involved in coordination of voluntary eye movement: Incorrect. The paracentral lobule, supplied by the ACA, governs micturition and defecation, not voluntary eye movement (which is controlled by the frontal eye field supplied by the middle cerebral artery).

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 3. The ACA supplies the paracentral lobule, which governs micturition and defecation control: Correct. The ACA does indeed supply the paracentral lobule, critical for pelvic floor function.

 

Statement 4. The ACA territory includes the medial surface of the motor cortex responsible for lower limb movement: Correct. The ACA supplies the medial portion of the precentral gyrus, which corresponds to lower limb motor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the medial frontal and parietal lobes, including the paracentral lobule and genu of the corpus callosum, which are crucial for lower limb movement and visceral motor control such as micturition and defecation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old G1P1, 5 days postpartum, presents with severe substernal burning chest pain and diaphoresis for 45 minutes, HR 120 bpm, BP 90/74 mmHg, and ECG is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coronary dissection

 

  • In young postpartum women presenting with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) symptoms and ST-elevation, the most likely etiology is Spontaneous Coronary Artery Dissection (SCAD).
  • SCAD is a non-atherosclerotic cause of MI and is strongly associated with pregnancy and the postpartum period, especially within the first few weeks after delivery.
  • It typically affects young women without traditional cardiac risk factors, and the anterior leads may be involved if the left anterior descending artery (LAD) is affected.
  • Hypotension and tachycardia further support a hemodynamically significant event such as coronary dissection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypermagnesemia: Typically causes hyporeflexia, bradycardia, and hypotension—not ST elevation or chest pain.

 

Option C. Aortic dissection: Presents with tearing chest/back pain, often radiating, with pulse deficits; not typically associated with ST elevation in anterior leads.

 

Option D. STEMI: Possible, but in a young, postpartum woman without risk factors, SCAD is more likely than classic plaque rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spontaneous Coronary Artery Dissection (SCAD) is the most likely cause of ACS in young postpartum women.
  • SCAD commonly presents with ST elevation, chest pain, and occurs within weeks postpartum.
  • Always consider SCAD over atherosclerotic STEMI in young women with no risk factors but suggestive ECG and symptoms.

questions.text: A 28‑year‑old man from rural area presents with painless hematuria and irritative voiding symptoms. Abdominal X-ray is shown below. This radiographic pattern is most characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schistosomiasis

 

  • Peripheral calcification of the bladder will be seen which is called as fetal skull sign, which is suggestive of Schistosomiasis.
  • Chronic Schistosoma haematobium infection leads to granulomatous inflammation around deposited eggs in the bladder mucosa. 
  • Over time, these granulomas calcify in a thin, uniform rim, producing the classic “eggshell” or “pipe-stem” calcification of the bladder wall visible on plain X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Genitourinary tuberculosis: Causes irregular, amorphous calcifications in the renal pelvis or ureter (“putty kidney”), not smooth rim calcification of the bladder.

 

Option C. Neurogenic bladder: Leads to trabeculation or diverticula on imaging, but does not produce bladder wall calcification.

 

Option D. Pelvic abscess: May calcify centrally if chronic, but would appear as a localized mass rather than a uniform bladder wall rim.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiographic hallmark of bladder wall calcification in Schistosoma haematobium infection and distinguish it from other causes of genitourinary calcification.

choices.text: Administer IV bolus of Hartmann solution
Administer IV glucose and recheck blood glucose after 20 minutes

questions.text: A newborn, born to a diabetic mother, presents after 24 hours of life with a blood glucose level of <35 mg/dL. The baby is symptomatic. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer IV glucose and recheck blood glucose after 20 minutes

 

  • In a symptomatic neonate with hypoglycemia (<45 mg/dL), and especially one born to a diabetic mother, the standard of care is immediate correction of glucose via IV glucose administration.
  • The threshold for treatment is <40 mg/dL in first 24 hours, and <45 mg/dL after 24 hours.
  • Since this baby is >24 hours old, symptomatic, and blood glucose is <35 mg/dL, urgent IV glucose is indicated.
  • Typically, 10% dextrose (D10W) is given as an IV bolus (2 mL/kg), followed by continuous infusion.
  • Rechecking glucose after 20–30 minutes ensures effective correction and guides further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer IV bolus of Hartmann solution:

 

  • Hartmann (Ringer’s lactate) does not contain glucose.
  • It is not indicated for treating hypoglycemia and may dilute serum glucose further, worsening the condition.
  • Not appropriate for neonates in hypoglycemic crisis.

 

Option B. Recheck blood glucose after 20 minutes:

 

  • Delaying treatment in a symptomatic neonate is dangerous.
  • Observation without intervention can lead to seizures, coma, or brain damage.
  • Rechecking is essential after intervention, not as an isolated step.

 

Option D. Start oral feeds and observe: 

 

  • This may be suitable in asymptomatic neonates with borderline glucose levels (>25–30 mg/dL in first 4 hours).
  • However, in symptomatic babies with severe hypoglycemia, IV route is preferred due to rapid effect.
  • Oral feeds are slower and less reliable in acute settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a symptomatic neonate with blood glucose <45 mg/dL, immediate IV glucose administration is the first-line treatment, followed by glucose monitoring to prevent neurological complications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman presents for evaluation of infertility. Her menstrual cycles are regular, and she reports no history of pelvic infections or surgeries. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals two intramural fibroids—one measuring 7x5 cm at the right cornual region and another 5x3 cm at the left cornual end of the uterus. Her husband’s semen analysis is within normal parameters. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic myomectomy 

 

  • This patient is a young woman with infertility and significant intramural fibroids located at the cornual ends, which may interfere with implantation or embryo transport.
  • Intramural fibroids, particularly those >4 cm or those impinging on the endometrial cavity, can distort the uterine architecture and impact fertility.
  • Laparoscopic myomectomy is the preferred treatment in women desiring fertility, as it removes the fibroids while preserving the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: Incorrect. While effective for symptom control in fibroid-related menorrhagia, this is not preferred in women seeking fertility due to potential effects on ovarian reserve and endometrial perfusion.

 

Option C. Hysteroscopic evaluation: Incorrect. Hysteroscopy is useful for submucosal fibroids or endometrial polyps. This patient has intramural fibroids at the cornual ends, which are better visualized and treated via laparoscopy.

 

Option D. GnRH analogues: Incorrect. GnRH analogues can temporarily shrink fibroids but are not a definitive treatment. They are often used preoperatively to reduce fibroid size, not as standalone treatment in a woman actively seeking fertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic myomectomy is the treatment of choice for symptomatic or fertility-impairing intramural fibroids in women desiring future pregnancy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient with moderate to severe Crohn’s disease is being evaluated for biologic therapy. Which of the following agents is not typically used in the management of Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Denosumab

 

  • For moderate to severe Crohn’s disease, biologic therapies include:
    • Anti-TNF agents: infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab.
    • Anti-integrins: natalizumab, vedolizumab.
    • Anti-IL-12/23: ustekinumab.
  • Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody against RANKL, used in osteoporosis, bone metastases, and giant cell tumor of bone, but it has no role in inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Denosumab is not used in Crohn’s disease. It targets RANKL to inhibit osteoclast activity and bone resorption; indicated in osteoporosis and malignancy-associated bone loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infliximab: Used in Crohn’s disease. Chimeric monoclonal antibody against TNF-α. Especially helpful in fistulizing disease.

 

Option B. Adalimumab: Used in Crohn’s disease. Fully human monoclonal antibody against TNF-α.

 

Option C. Certolizumab: Used in Crohn’s disease. Pegylated anti-TNF antibody fragment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Denosumab is not used in Crohn’s disease, it is used for treatment of osteoporosis. 
  • The drugs used for Crohn’s disease are TNF-α inhibitors like infliximab, adalimumab and certolizumab.

choices.text: It is inhibited by bile salts
It requires added cysteine and iron

questions.text: During an outbreak investigation at a hotel, environmental water samples are sent for microbiology. Technicians inoculate both standard blood agar and BCYE agar. After 3 days, only the BCYE plate shows growth of small, gray-white colonies. This selective growth pattern confirms which of the following about Legionella pneumophila?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It requires added cysteine and iron

 

  • The fact that Legionella grows on BCYE (which contains L-cysteine and iron) but not on blood agar indicates a nutritional requirement for those supplements. 
  • BCYE’s activated charcoal also neutralizes toxic metabolites. 
  • The lack of growth on blood agar is not due to temperature preference, bile sensitivity, or acid-fast properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is inhibited by bile salts: Legionella’s absence on blood agar has nothing to do with bile; blood agar contains no bile salts.

 

Option C. It grows only at 42 °C: Legionella grows optimally at 35–37 °C; it is not a thermophile.

 

Option D. It is acid-fast: Legionella is a gram-negative rod, not acid-fast like Mycobacterium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selective isolation of Legionella hinges on its specific nutritional needs—it does not grow on routine media lacking L-cysteine and iron.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with non-erosive seropositive RA, unable to tolerate methotrexate or hydroxychloroquine due to gastrointestinal intolerance. She also has a history of Stevens-Johnson syndrome after sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim, and she wants an efficacious biological DMARD. Which agent is least likely to achieve good disease control?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anakinra

 

  • Anakinra (IL-1 receptor antagonist) is less effective for RA than TNF inhibitors (infliximab), IL-6 inhibitors (tocilizumab), or costimulation modulators (abatacept).
  • IL-1 plays a minor role in RA compared to TNF-α or IL-6, limiting anakinra’s efficacy.
  • Pregnancy planning favors abatacept for safety; infliximab and tocilizumab are effective but require caution.
  • Anti-IL-1 molecules like anakinra are important in treatment of autoinflammatory syndromes like familial Mediterranean fever, and some acquired autoinflammatory syndromes like gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infliximab: Potent TNF-α inhibitor for RA.

 

Option C. Tocilizumab: Effective IL-6 inhibitor for RA.

 

Option D. Abatacept: Inhibits T-cell activation, effective for RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anakinra is less effective for RA than other biologics.
  • Consider pregnancy safety in DMARD selection.
  • TNF-α/IL-6 inhibitors target key RA pathways.

choices.text: High lipid solubility for passive reabsorption
Free filtration at glomerulus and lack of tubular reabsorption

questions.text: Which of the following pharmacokinetic properties is essential for a drug to function effectively as an osmotic diuretic?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Free filtration at glomerulus and lack of tubular reabsorption

 

  • For a drug to act as an osmotic diuretic (e.g., mannitol), it must:
    1. Be freely filtered at the glomerulus → so that it enters the tubular fluid easily.
    2. Not undergo tubular reabsorption → so that it stays in the tubular lumen, retaining water by osmotic effect.
    3. Be pharmacologically inert (not binding to receptors significantly).
  • This property ensures that the agent increases tubular fluid osmolality, preventing water reabsorption and producing diuresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High lipid solubility for passive reabsorption: Incorrect. Osmotic diuretics must not be reabsorbed; lipid-soluble drugs get reabsorbed easily and won’t act as osmotic diuretics.

 

Option B. Ability to inhibit sodium-chloride symporters: Incorrect. That’s the mechanism of thiazide diuretics, not osmotic diuretics.

 

Option C. Complete tubular secretion without filtration: Incorrect. Tubular secretion is not their primary pathway. For osmotic effect, filtration at the glomerulus is essential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To act effectively as an osmotic diuretic, a drug must be freely filtered at the glomerulus, remain inert, and not undergo reabsorption in the renal tubules, thereby drawing water into the urine via osmotic gradients.

questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Venous ulcer

 

Venous ulcers are classically seen above the medial malleolus, with irregular borders, granulation tissue, and often accompanied by pigmentation due to hemosiderin deposition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial ulcer: Painful, punched-out, found over pressure points like toes, lateral malleolus.

 

Option C. Diabetic ulcer: Typically on pressure  points like metatarsal heads, often painless.

 

Option D. Neuropathic ulcer: Painless, deep, on weight-bearing surfaces in patients with neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous ulcers occur over the medial malleolus with irregular edges and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency.

questions.text: As part of a standard neonatal screen, an infant is diagnosed with a loss of function genetic defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. Defects in this enzyme can result in a condition known as phenylketonuria (PKU), which results from the toxic effects of phenylalanine derived phenylketones. Fortunately, this condition can be managed by regulating the amount of phenylalanine provided in the diet. Which of the following nonessential amino acids will need to be supplied in the diet of this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tyrosine

 

  • In phenylketonuria (PKU) due to phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, phenylalanine cannot be converted to tyrosine.
  • This makes tyrosine an essential amino acid for the patient, even though it is normally nonessential (because the body usually synthesizes it from phenylalanine).
  • Without supplementation, tyrosine deficiency can impair protein synthesis, melanin production, and catecholamine synthesis.

 

Biochemical pathway:

 

Phenylalanine — (phenylalanine hydroxylase + BH4) → Tyrosine → Melanin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine: Remains nonessential; synthesized from pyruvate via transamination.

 

Option B. Aspartate: Remains nonessential; synthesized from oxaloacetate.

 

Option C. Serine: Remains nonessential; synthesized from 3-phosphoglycerate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In phenylketonuria due to phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid because it can no longer be synthesized from phenylalanine and must be obtained through the diet.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with exertional dyspnea and a history of cyanotic spells. On examination, there is clubbing and a harsh systolic murmur heard at the left upper sternal border. Chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

 

  • This is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease beyond infancy.
  • The classic presentation includes cyanosis, exertional dyspnea, clubbing, and "tet spells" (hypercyanotic episodes). 
  • The murmur is due to right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. A “boot-shaped heart” on chest X-ray (caused by right ventricular hypertrophy) is pathognomonic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection: Usually presents earlier in life with severe cyanosis and may show a "snowman" sign in the supracardiac type on X-ray.

 

Option C. Transposition of the great arteries:  Presents in neonates with cyanosis and an “egg-on-string” appearance on X-ray.

 

Option D. Coarctation of aorta: Presents with differential cyanosis and radio-femoral delay, not boot-shaped heart or cyanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot is identified by cyanosis, systolic murmur, and characteristic boot-shaped heart on imaging.
  • It is the most common cyanotic heart disease in children beyond infancy.

choices.text: Administer aspirin and monitor in the hospital
Start anticoagulation therapy for stroke prevention
Perform an MRI of the brain to rule out a hemorrhagic stroke

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and difficulty walking starting about 2 hours ago, with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. Examination shows right-sided hemiparesis, facial droop, dysarthria, and NIHSS score of 12. Non-contrast CT of the head is shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiate tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) immediately

 

  • Sudden weakness, dysarthria, and NIHSS 12 indicate acute ischemic stroke.
  • No hemorrhage on CT and 2-hour onset are within tPA’s 3-4.5-hour window.
  • tPA dissolves clots, improving outcomes; risk factors (hypertension, smoking) support ischemic etiology.
  • NIHSS 12 indicates moderate stroke, benefiting from thrombolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Administer aspirin and monitor in the hospital: For secondary prevention, not acute.

 

Option C. Start anticoagulation therapy for stroke prevention: For long-term, not acute management.

 

Option D. Perform an MRI of the brain to rule out a hemorrhagic stroke: CT sufficient; MRI delays tPA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • tPA is for ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours if no hemorrhage.
  • Time is critical for stroke outcomes.
  • NIHSS guides treatment decisions.

questions.text: Two children with genetic issues in fructose metabolism were seen by the same doctor. The parents of the first child were advised to restrict dietary fructose due to health risks. However, the second child’s parents were informed that their child was unlikely to experience any symptoms, despite the presence of fructose in the urine. Based on this information, which enzyme is likely deficient in the second child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fructokinase

 

  • Essential fructosuria is caused by fructokinase deficiency.
  • Fructose from the diet is not phosphorylated in the liver → it is freely filtered into the urine.
  • Key features:
    • Benign, asymptomatic condition
    • Fructosuria is the only finding
    • No hypoglycemia, no liver damage
  • Hence, parents are told no dietary restriction is needed.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fructose-1-phosphate aldolase (aldolase B):

 

  • Deficiency → Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI).
  • Fructose-1-P accumulates → inhibits glycogenolysis → severe hypoglycemia, vomiting, liver damage after fructose ingestion.
  • Requires strict avoidance of fructose, sucrose, sorbitol.
  • This fits the first child in the question, not the second.

 

Option B. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase A):

 

  • Involved in glycolysis, not fructose metabolism per se.
  • Deficiency causes hemolysis & myopathy, not isolated fructosuria.

 

Option D. Hexokinase:

 

  • Phosphorylates glucose (and to a small extent fructose) in peripheral tissues.
  • Deficiency → affects glycolysis broadly, not just fructose metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fructokinase deficiency causes essential fructosuria, a benign condition where fructose appears in the urine but causes no systemic illness. Unlike hereditary fructose intolerance, it requires no dietary restriction.

questions.text: Which of the following actin–myosin crossbridge pair correctly represents the point (B–C) shown on length–tension relationship in the sarcomere curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B)

 

 

  • The length–tension relationship in skeletal muscle describes how the amount of force (tension) a muscle fiber can generate depends on the sarcomere length at the onset of contraction.
  • B–C segment on the curve corresponds to optimal sarcomere length (~2.0–2.2 µm), where maximal active tension is produced.
  • At this length, there is maximal overlap between actin (thin) and myosin (thick) filaments without interference from opposite actin filaments, allowing the maximum number of crossbridges to form.
  • The diagram in option B shows exactly this optimal overlap:
  • All myosin heads have access to binding sites on actin.
  • There is no excessive filament overlap that would reduce binding sites.
  • There is no overstretch preventing crossbridge formation.
  • Therefore, option B correctly represents the crossbridge geometry at the optimal length producing maximum active force.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Represents sarcomere length shorter than optimal (left of point B), with actin filaments overlapping each other and potentially interfering with myosin binding. This reduces tension because some crossbridges cannot form effectively and actin–actin interference occurs.

 

Option C. Shows sarcomere length longer than optimal (right of point C), with reduced actin–myosin overlap. Fewer crossbridges form, lowering active tension despite no filament interference.

 

Option D. Represents extreme stretch — little to no actin–myosin overlap. Almost no crossbridges form, so active force approaches zero.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • At optimal sarcomere length (~2.0–2.2 µm), the maximum number of actin–myosin crossbridges can form, producing peak active tension. 
  • Shorter lengths lead to actin–actin interference and reduced crossbridge binding, while longer lengths decrease overlap and thus reduce the number of possible crossbridges. 
  • The B–C range on the length–tension curve reflects this physiological optimum for force generation in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman suddenly develops dyspnea, hypotension, and generalized rash after receiving an intramuscular injection of ceftriaxone. She is wheezing and her blood pressure is 74/42 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most immediate and life-saving intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intramuscular adrenaline

 

  • This is a case of anaphylactic shock caused by beta lactams like penicillins and cephalosporins 
  • In anaphylactic shock, intramuscular adrenaline (epinephrine) is the only life-saving intervention. 
  • It acts by reversing airway obstruction, vasodilation, and hypotension through alpha- and beta-adrenergic effects. 
  • The recommended adult dose is 0.5 mg IM (0.5 mL of 1:1000 solution), repeated every 5–10 minutes if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous diphenhydramine: H1 blockers help with cutaneous symptoms but do not address life-threatening airway or circulatory collapse.

 

Option C. Intravenous hydrocortisone: Helpful for prolonged or biphasic reactions, but its effect is delayed (onset >4 hours).

 

Option D. High-flow oxygen and IV fluids: Supportive, but not sufficient alone; adrenaline is mandatory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intramuscular adrenaline is the first-line and only life-saving treatment in anaphylactic shock and should be administered immediately.

choices.text: Providing transitional shelter and social services
Distributing food, clothing, and employment assistance
Organizing community rehabilitation and livelihood programs

questions.text: A multidisciplinary relief team is organizing post‑disaster interventions. They categorize activities according to the disaster cycle. During the tertiary phase, which of the following is least appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conducting mass immunization campaigns

 

  • Phases of health and medical relief in the disaster cycle:
    • Primary (0–6 h): First aid, search and rescue, field care
    • Secondary (6–24 h): Transportation, sanitation, immunization, disease surveillance
    • Tertiary (1–60 days): Food, clothing, shelter assistance; social services; employment; rehabilitation
  • Mass immunization campaigns are a secondary phase activity. 
  • By the tertiary phase, focus shifts to restoring normalcy through shelter, nutrition, social support, and livelihood rebuilding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Providing transitional shelter and social services: Central to tertiary relief—helps displaced families regain stability.

 

Option C. Distributing food, clothing, and employment assistance: Essential tertiary tasks that address longer‑term survival and well‑being.

 

Option D. Organizing community rehabilitation and livelihood programs: Core tertiary objective: rebuilding infrastructure, skills, and economic opportunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disaster cycle phases have distinct priorities:
    • Secondary phase includes immunization,
    • Tertiary phase focuses on rehabilitation, shelter, nutrition, and social services.

questions.text: A national tuberculosis (TB) control program manager needs to monitor long‑term trends in TB transmission that are not immediately altered by recent case control strategies. Which of the following indicators best reflects such a trend?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual risk of infection

 

  • Prevalence of TB infection is 40%
  • The annual risk of infection (ARI) estimates the proportion of the population newly infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis each year.
  • In ARI incidence of infection is 1-2%. This can be found by TCI (Tuberculin conversion index – Mantoux test negative to positive conversion).
  • Because it captures new infections before disease detection or treatment, ARI directly reflects transmission intensity and is unaffected by changes in case‑finding or treatment effectiveness. 
  • ARI is derived from periodic tuberculin surveys in children, offering a real‑time measure of force of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prevalence of TB infection: Reflects cumulative, historic infections over many years and changes only slowly; it does not indicate current transmission dynamics.

 

Option C. Percentage of primary drug resistance: Measures the proportion of new cases with resistant strains; influenced by past treatment practices and secondary transmission, not a direct measure of overall transmission trend.

 

Option D. Percentage of multidrug resistance: Depends on both transmission of resistant strains and treatment failures; it is sensitive to drug‑management programs and does not isolate the trend in all TB transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annual risk of infection provides the most direct, current measure of TB transmission intensity, independent of case detection and treatment program performance.

choices.text: Deposition of immunoglobulin light chains due to plasma cell dyscrasia
Deposition of β2-microglobulin from chronic hemodialysis
Deposition of serum amyloid A protein from chronic inflammation
Deposition of misfolded transthyretin due to mutation in the TTR gene

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was found unresponsive at home and could not be resuscitated. His family reports a 2-year history of progressive exertional dyspnea, lower limb swelling, and occasional dizziness. His father died suddenly at the age of 40 from a similar cardiac condition. Autopsy and histopathology of the heart is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s fatal cardiac disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Deposition of misfolded transthyretin due to mutation in the TTR gene 

 

  • The gross image shows a markedly thickened left ventricular free wall with a pale, waxy appearance, characteristic of amyloid infiltration. 
  • In this case, the presentation, young age, and positive family history indicate Hereditary Transthyretin-related (ATTR) Amyloidosis.
  • Pathophysiology: Mutation in the TTR gene → abnormal transthyretin protein misfolds → amyloid fibrils deposit in the myocardium → restrictive cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, and eventual sudden cardiac death, as seen in this patient.
  • Histology: Amyloid appears as slightly pale, eosinophilic, amorphous, homogenous material filling up the interstitium on hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. The cardiac myocytes appear atrophic due to the compressive effect of the amyloid deposits. Congo red staining reveals apple-green birefringence under polarized light.
  • These deposits cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, and conduction abnormalities, predisposing to sudden cardiac death, as in this patient. The strong family history supports the hereditary form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deposition of immunoglobulin light chains due to plasma cell dyscrasia: Usually secondary to multiple myeloma; patient’s age, family history, and lack of plasma cell disorder make this unlikely.

 

Option B. Deposition of β2-microglobulin from chronic hemodialysis: Seen in dialysis-related amyloidosis, affecting joints/tendons; no history of renal failure or dialysis here.

 

Option C. Deposition of serum amyloid A protein from chronic inflammation: Associated with chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., RA, TB); typically affects kidneys, liver, and spleen, not isolated familial cardiac amyloidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hereditary ATTR amyloidosis is caused by TTR gene mutation, leading to transthyretin misfolding and amyloid deposition in the myocardium. 
  • It manifests as restrictive cardiomyopathy, conduction abnormalities, and high risk of sudden cardiac death.

choices.text: 1st it rises then remains elevated

questions.text: Blood glucose was raised 2–3 times and then maintained for a consistent period. Which of the following is correct regarding the insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1st it rises then remains elevated

 

  • When plasma glucose is abruptly increased and then held at a constant elevated level, insulin secretion shows a biphasic pattern:
    • First phase: A rapid, sharp rise in insulin secretion within the first few minutes, reflecting release of pre‑formed insulin from β‑cell storage granules.
    • Second phase: After this spike, secretion plateaus at a sustained but lower level, representing ongoing synthesis and release of new insulin in response to persistent hyperglycaemia.
  • This biphasic response is a hallmark of normal pancreatic β‑cell physiology and is essential for effective glucose homeostasis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rise and fall rapidly: Describes only the first phase of insulin release but ignores the sustained second phase. It does not fit the prolonged elevation scenario described.

 

Option B. Gradually rise and fall: Suggests a slow onset and decline, which is not the physiological response to an acute step‑up in glucose. This would also miss the sharp initial surge.

 

Option C. Remain elevated: Implies a constant high plateau without the initial spike, which is inaccurate because normal β‑cells respond with an immediate first‑phase release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A sudden and sustained rise in blood glucose elicits a biphasic insulin secretion pattern: an early rapid spike from release of stored insulin, followed by a sustained lower plateau from ongoing synthesis. 
  • This pattern is lost in early type 2 diabetes, where the first phase is diminished or absent — contributing to postprandial hyperglycaemia.

questions.text: Refer to the image below. Which of the following intraocular devices is shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Capsular tension ring

 

  • A capsular tension ring (CTR) is a thin, flexible polymethylmethacrylate ring with eyelet ends, designed to be inserted into the equator of the lens capsule during cataract surgery when zonular support is compromised. 
  • It redistributes forces evenly around the capsular bag, ensuring a stable, round implant platform for the intraocular lens (IOL).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iris-claw IOL: Rigid, claw-shaped haptics that clip to the mid-peripheral iris, not a continuous circular ring.

 

Option B. Scleral-fixated IOL: A posterior chamber IOL with sutures through the sclera; no ring structure.

 

Option D. Intracorneal stromal ring: Often made of PMMA segments implanted within the corneal stroma to flatten keratoconic corneas; they are thicker and arc-shaped, not equatorial capsular rings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of zonular dialysis (e.g., pseudoexfoliation, trauma, Marfan syndrome), early insertion of a capsular tension ring after capsulorhexis helps maintain a symmetric, stable capsular bag for optimal IOL positioning and long-term centration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for cervical dysplasia. Imaging and biopsy reveal involvement limited to the cervix and upper part of the vagina. Which of the following lymph nodes are most likely to be involved in this metastatic spread?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External iliac

 

  • The upper part of the vagina and cervix primarily drain into the external iliac and internal iliac lymph nodes. 
  • These nodes are part of the pelvic lymphatic drainage system, which receives lymph from deep pelvic organs including the cervix and upper vagina. 
  • This is clinically significant in the staging and spread of gynecologic cancers such as cervical carcinoma.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Para-aortic: These nodes receive lymph from the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and upper uterus. They are not the primary drainage site for the cervix or upper vagina.

 

Option C. Superficial inguinal: These drain the vulva, perineum, and lower third of the vagina, not the upper portion or the cervix.

 

Option D. Deep inguinal: These drain lymph from the superficial inguinal nodes and parts of the lower limb, not primarily the cervix or upper vagina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix and upper vagina primarily drain into the external and internal iliac lymph nodes, which is important for understanding the spread of cervical and upper vaginal malignancies.

choices.text: Clomifene citrate 100 mg on days 14–18; check FSH on day 21
Letrozole 50 mg on days 2–6; check LH on day 14
Clomifene citrate 50 mg on days 2–6; check progesterone on day 21
Clomifene citrate 50 mg on days 10–14; check estradiol on day 21

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a 1-year history of infertility is found to have anovulatory cycles. She is started on treatment to induce ovulation. Which of the following is the most appropriate regimen and follow-up for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clomifene citrate 50 mg on days 2–6; check progesterone on day 21

 

  • Clomifene citrate is a first-line agent used to induce ovulation in women with anovulatory infertility. 
  • The standard regimen involves administering 50 mg of clomifene citrate daily from day 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle.
  • Day 21 progesterone level is checked to confirm ovulation; a mid-luteal progesterone level >3 ng/mL typically indicates that ovulation has occurred.
  • This protocol is based on the assumption of a 28-day cycle, with ovulation occurring around day 14.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomifene citrate 100 mg on days 14–18; check FSH on day 21: Incorrect. The dosage is excessive for a first-line regimen, and clomifene is not given this late in the cycle. FSH is not the appropriate marker to confirm ovulation.

 

Option B. Letrozole 50 mg on days 2–6; check LH on day 14: Incorrect. Although letrozole is an alternative ovulation induction agent, the dose is incorrect and LH is not the preferred hormone to confirm ovulation.

 

Option D. Clomifene citrate 50 mg on days 10–14; check estradiol on day 21: Incorrect. This timing does not coincide with the follicular phase needed for clomifene to be effective. Estradiol levels are not used to confirm ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For PCOS, preferred drug is Letrozole 2.5 mg (max upto 7.5 mg) from day 2 to day 6. 

 

OR 

 

Clomifene citrate 50 mg/day (max upto 150 mg) from day 2 to day 6 and 

later USG required for follicular monitoring.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes abdominal and pelvic imaging to evaluate lower abdominal discomfort. Initial pelvic ultrasound reveals a large ovarian cyst. A subsequent CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis incidentally shows the renal structure as shown in the image below. Which of the following anatomical structures most commonly prevents the full ascent of this renal anomaly during embryologic development?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior mesenteric artery

 

  • Horseshoe kidney is a congenital anomaly in which the lower poles of the kidneys are fused. 
  • During embryologic ascent, this fused structure typically gets trapped under the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA), preventing it from reaching the normal retroperitoneal position. 
  • These kidneys remain abnormally low in the abdomen and are often discovered incidentally, as in this case during imaging for an ovarian cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal artery: The renal arteries originate at varying levels during kidney ascent, adjusting accordingly. They do not hinder renal migration.

 

Option B. Ureter: The ureter is a passive structure that follows the kidney’s position. It is not a limiting factor in renal ascent.

 

Option C. Inferior vena cava: Although anatomically adjacent, the IVC does not interfere with renal migration during development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior mesenteric artery is the most frequent anatomical barrier to the ascent of a horseshoe kidney, which is often identified incidentally on imaging done for unrelated abdominal or pelvic pathology.

choices.text: Impaired function of δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase due to vitamin B6 deficiency
Deficiency of ferrochelatase leading to impaired incorporation of iron into protoporphyrin
Inhibition of aminolevulinic acid dehydratase by lead
Decreased transferrin synthesis leading to impaired iron delivery to erythroid precursors

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with progressive fatigue and pallor. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin: 8.4 g/dl, MCV: 72 fl, increased ferritin, increased serum iron, increased % saturation and reduced TIBC. Bone marrow biopsy is shown below. Which of the following best explains the underlying defect in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impaired function of δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase due to vitamin B6 deficiency

 

  • Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by defective protoporphyrin synthesis, which prevents the incorporation of iron into heme. 
  • As a result, iron becomes trapped within the mitochondria of erythroid precursors, forming ringed sideroblasts.
  • The rate-limiting step in protoporphyrin synthesis is catalyzed by ALA synthase (ALAS), which requires vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate) as a cofactor. 
  • In chronic alcoholics or patients receiving isoniazid (for TB), vitamin B6 deficiency is common, leading to impaired ALAS activity and sideroblastic anemia. 
  • Alcohol itself can also inhibit ALA synthase through acetaldehyde. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deficiency of ferrochelatase leading to impaired incorporation of iron into protoporphyrin: Seen in lead poisoning, but the patient’s history of alcohol abuse and vitamin B6 deficiency makes ALAS dysfunction more likely here.

 

Option C. Inhibition of aminolevulinic acid dehydratase by lead: Also seen in lead poisoning, but again, history of alcoholism strongly points to vitamin B6 deficiency as the cause.

 

Option D. Decreased transferrin synthesis leading to impaired iron delivery to erythroid precursors: This describes anemia of chronic disease, not sideroblastic anemia. In sideroblastic anemia, iron is present but cannot be utilized due to defective protoporphyrin synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sideroblastic anemia results from defective protoporphyrin synthesis, most commonly due to vitamin B6 deficiency impairing ALA synthase activity. It is associated with alcoholism, isoniazid therapy, and ringed sideroblasts on bone marrow biopsy.

choices.text: It occurs more commonly in children than in adults
Every infective mosquito bite leads to clinical disease
The ratio of apparent (symptomatic) to inapparent infections is approximately 1:1,000
An epidemic can be signaled by as few as 2–3 cases within a village

questions.text: A rural health officer is reviewing Japanese encephalitis (JE) epidemiology to prepare for an upcoming awareness campaign. Which of the following statements about JE is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Every infective mosquito bite leads to clinical disease

 

  • Most JE virus infections are subclinical. Fewer than 1 in 1,000 infected individuals develop encephalitis; the vast majority have inapparent or mild illness. 
  • Thus, an infective bite does not always result in disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It occurs more commonly in children than in adult: True. Children account for most clinical JE cases because adults in endemic areas often develop partial immunity. 1-15 years of age

 

Option C. The ratio of apparent (symptomatic) to inapparent infections is approximately 1:1,000: True. The symptomatic-to-asymptomatic infection ratio is about 1:1,000.

 

Option D. An epidemic can be signaled by as few as 2–3 cases within a village: True. In hyperendemic regions, 2–3 cases in a village over a brief period may constitute an epidemic threshold.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Not every JE‑infected mosquito bite causes clinical disease; only about 0.1% of infections become overt encephalitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with cirrhosis and recent gastrointestinal bleeding presents with confusion, asterixis and poor concentration. Labs: AST 60 U/L, ALT 50 U/L, and INR 1.5. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lactulose

 

  • Confusion and asterixis in cirrhosis indicate hepatic encephalopathy from ammonia accumulation.
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding is a common precipitant, increasing ammonia production.
  • Lactulose acidifies the colon, promoting ammonia excretion, improving mental status.
  • Treat precipitants (e.g., bleeding) alongside lactulose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV antibiotics: Adjunct (e.g., rifaximin), not initial therapy.

 

Option C. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt: For ascites or variceal bleeding, not encephalopathy. Contraindicated in encephalopathy.

 

Option D. Propranolol: For variceal prophylaxis, not encephalopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hepatic encephalopathy presents with confusion and asterixis.
  • Lactulose is first-line to reduce ammonia.
  • Address precipitants like bleeding.

choices.text: Overexpression of the c-MYC oncogene leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation
Loss of function of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene leading to dysregulated G1/S transition
Activation of BCL2 gene resulting in inhibition of apoptosis
Mutation of the APC gene leading to impaired regulation of β-catenin

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from East Africa presents with a rapidly enlarging, painless mass on the jaw. He has also experienced fever and night sweats. Biopsy of the lesion is shown below. Cytogenetic studies reveal a translocation responsible for these findings. Which of the following best explains the underlying molecular mechanism of this malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Overexpression of the c-MYC oncogene leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation

 

  • The t(8;14) translocation is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma, where the c-MYC oncogene (chromosome 8) is translocated next to the immunoglobulin heavy chain locus (chromosome 14).
  • This results in c-MYC overexpression, driving rapid cellular proliferation.
  • The classic histologic “starry sky” appearance arises from tumor cells with dark blue cytoplasm interspersed with macrophages that ingest apoptotic debris.
  • Endemic cases are often associated with EBV infection, with the jaw being the most common site of involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of function of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene leading to dysregulated G1/S transition: Seen in retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, not Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Option C. Activation of BCL2 gene resulting in inhibition of apoptosis: Found in follicular lymphoma t(14;18)), leading to impaired apoptosis, not Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Option D. Mutation of the APC gene leading to impaired regulation of β-catenin: Associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and colorectal carcinoma, not with Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma strongly associated with EBV (endemic type) and characterized by t(8;14) translocation, which causes c-MYC overexpression and uncontrolled cell proliferation. 
  • Classic pathology shows a “starry sky” appearance with tingible body macrophages.

questions.text: A patient presents with a plaque on the face showing central atrophy as seen in the image. Chest X-ray reveals apical calcification. What is the next best step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PCR

 

  • The skin lesion shown is a large annular plaque with central atrophy, suggestive of lupus vulgaris (cutaneous TB).
  • Apical calcification on chest X-ray strongly suggests past pulmonary tuberculosis, reinforcing a tuberculous etiology.
  • The combination of chronic facial plaque with central atrophy, and pulmonary TB signs (apical calcification) – strongly favours lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • PCR is highly sensitive and specific for detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA from skin biopsy or tissue samples.
  • It is preferred in cutaneous TB when classical histopathology and culture are not diagnostic or too slow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mantoux test:

 

  • May be positive in TB but is not confirmatory and has low specificity, especially in endemic areas where many people have latent TB.
  • Cannot differentiate between cutaneous and pulmonary TB or between TB and other granulomatous diseases.

 

Option B. Probe test: Used in chronic sinus tracts or ulcers, such as in tuberculous ulcers, not for plaque-type lesions like lupus vulgaris.

 

Option C. Split skin smear:

 

  • Used to identify Mycobacterium leprae in leprosy.
  • Not helpful in tuberculosis, especially cutaneous TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected cases of cutaneous tuberculosis like lupus vulgaris, especially with supporting systemic findings such as apical calcification, PCR is the best diagnostic test to confirm the presence of M. tuberculosis DNA in skin lesions.

choices.text: Give bolus of 10 ml/kg Hartmann solution

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child was brought to the ER after a burn and was found to have 20% BSA burns. He was resuscitated as per Parkland’s equation. After 6 hours, he was found to have cool extremities and hypotension, and urine output of 0.3ml/kg/hour. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give bolus of 10 ml/kg Hartmann solution

 

  • This child is in burn with shock (tachycardia, hypotension, oliguria).
  • The initial management is crystalloid resuscitation with a bolus of 10–20 ml/kg, preferably 10 ml/kg in this situation, followed by monitoring and titration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give colloid bolus: Not first-line in initial resuscitation.

 

Option C. Wait for 2 hours and reassess:Waiting further is not ideal

 

Option D. Give bolus at 30 ml/kg : Too aggressive; risks fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In burn shock, prompt fluid resuscitation with isotonic crystalloids at 10 ml/kg is the initial management step to restore perfusion and urine output.

choices.text: JAK2 V617F mutation activating the tyrosine kinase pathway
t(9;22) translocation producing BCR-ABL fusion gene
t(15;17) translocation producing PML-RARA fusion gene
t(8;14) translocation leading to c-MYC overexpression

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue and abdominal fullness. Examination reveals marked splenomegaly. CBC shows leukocytosis with basophilia and peripheral smear demonstrates numerous immature myeloid cells. Bone marrow biopsy is hypercellular. Which of the following genetic alterations is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) t(9;22) translocation producing BCR-ABL fusion gene

 

  • The Philadelphia chromosome results from a t(9;22) translocation, creating the BCR-ABL fusion gene.
  • This fusion encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, leading to uncontrolled myeloid proliferation.
  • The classic triad includes: Splenomegaly + Marked leukocytosis with left-shifted myeloid cells + Basophilia.
  • This is the hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
  • Targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (eg, imatinib) is highly effective.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. JAK2 V617F mutation activating the tyrosine kinase pathway: Seen in polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, primary myelofibrosis, not CML.

 

Option C. t(15;17) translocation producing PML-RARA fusion gene: Seen in APML, responsive to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA).

 

Option D. t(8;14) translocation leading to c-MYC overexpression: Found in Burkitt lymphoma, not CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic myeloid leukemia is defined by the Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22), which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene encoding a constitutively active tyrosine kinase.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent sinusitis and repeated lung infections. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the CFTR gene. Which test is considered the gold standard to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweat chloride test

 

  • The sweat chloride test is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Cystic Fibrosis (CF). 
  • CF is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to defective chloride transport across epithelial membranes. 
  • This defect results in abnormally thick mucus in the lungs, sinuses, and other organs.
  • In the sweat chloride test:
    • Pilocarpine iontophoresis stimulates sweat production.
    • Sweat is collected and analyzed.
    • A chloride concentration >60 mmol/L (in children) confirms the diagnosis.
    • Even if a genetic mutation is detected, functional confirmation via sweat chloride testing is essential, especially in borderline or novel mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lung biopsy: Lung biopsy is not required for diagnosis and is invasive. Histopathology is not diagnostic in CF; rather, it may show secondary changes like bronchiectasis.

 

Option C. Chest X-ray: Chest X-ray may show signs of chronic lung disease (e.g., hyperinflation, bronchiectasis), but it is non-specific and not diagnostic. It's useful for monitoring complications, not confirmation.

 

Option D. Nasal swab culture: While nasal cultures can grow organisms like Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which are common in CF patients, this test is not diagnostic or confirmatory of CF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with recurrent respiratory infections and CFTR gene mutation, the sweat chloride test remains the gold standard to confirm cystic fibrosis by functionally demonstrating defective chloride transport.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with a history of persistent foul-smelling ear discharge and progressive hearing loss in his right ear for several months. Otoscopic examination is as given below. There are no signs of acute infection, but the discharge has not resolved despite medical management. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Modified radical mastoidectomy (MRM)

 

  • The patient has active mucosal chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with persistent discharge and granulation tissue, suggesting ongoing disease in the middle ear and mastoid air cells. 
  • MRM is indicated in cases of unsafe CSOM (especially with persistent infection, granulation tissue, or cholesteatoma) to remove all diseased tissue while preserving as much normal anatomy as possible and maintaining a dry, safe ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: Incorrect. A myringoplasty is performed for dry perforations without active infection or middle ear disease. This patient has ongoing infection and granulation tissue, making myringoplasty alone inadequate.

 

Option C. Atticotomy: Incorrect. Atticotomy is used in attic cholesteatoma or limited epitympanic disease, not in widespread mucosal disease with large perforation and granulation tissue.

 

Option D. Exploratory tympanotomy: Incorrect. This is performed to explore the middle ear for causes of conductive hearing loss (e.g., ossicular chain fixation), not for chronic infective pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modified radical mastoidectomy is the surgery of choice in unsafe CSOM with active infection, granulation tissue, or cholesteatoma to eradicate disease, create a safe ear, and prevent complications like facial nerve palsy or intracranial spread.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is most appropriate as an alternative antihypertensive in patients who develop angioedema due to captopril?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Losartan

 

  • Captopril-induced angioedema is caused by bradykinin accumulation, a class effect of ACE inhibitors. 
  • Losartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), works downstream by blocking angiotensin II receptors without affecting bradykinin metabolism.
  • Thus, it does not carry the same risk of angioedema and is often considered a safe substitute for patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enalapril: Another ACE inhibitor; also increases bradykinin and can trigger angioedema.

 

Option B. Lisinopril: Same class; contraindicated in patients with previous ACEI-induced angioedema.

 

Option D. Ramipril: Also an ACE inhibitor with the same risk profile for angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), such as losartan, are appropriate alternatives for patients with ACE inhibitor–induced angioedema.

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing technique.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Simple interrupted

 

Single loop sutures without vertical or horizontal looping pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vertical mattress: Sutures penetrate deeply and are designed to evert skin edges and reduce dead space. The image shows both deep and superficial bites on opposite sides of the wound, classic for vertical mattress.

 

 

Option B. Horizontal mattress: These are placed parallel to the wound and remain more superficial.

 

 

Option C. Subcuticular: Continuous stitches placed in the dermis, not the pattern shown.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Single loop sutures without vertical or horizontal looping pattern.

choices.text: Administer additional dose of IV furosemide

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is presents with dyspnea at rest, bilateral rales, and elevated jugular venous pressure. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/min. He is a known case of congestive heart failure and is currently on furosemide, lisinopril, and carvedilol. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discontinue carvedilol temporarily

 

  • This patient with CHF on guideline-directed therapy has now developed acute decompensated heart failure with hypotension and pulmonary congestion. 
  • In such cases, beta-blockers (like carvedilol) should be held or reduced because their negative inotropic effect can worsen acute decompensation.
  • Once the patient is stabilized, beta-blocker therapy can be carefully restarted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of lisinopril: Incorrect. ACE inhibitors are beneficial in chronic CHF, but in acute decompensation with low BP (90/60 mm Hg), increasing vasodilator dose would worsen hypotension and perfusion.

 

Option C. Add IV dobutamine infusion: Not the first step here. Inotropes like dobutamine are used in cardiogenic shock with severe hypotension and hypoperfusion, not as routine management of acute pulmonary congestion in a patient who is stable enough. Here, stopping the beta-blocker is the priority.

 

Option D. Administer additional dose of IV furosemide: This may help relieve congestion but does not address the precipitating problem of ongoing beta-blockade in acute decompensation with low BP. Giving more diuretics without correcting the beta-blocker effect could worsen hypotension and renal perfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-blockers should be stopped in acute decompensated heart failure and resumed only after stabilization.

questions.text: A patient presents with a swollen, semi-flexed index finger. The finger is exquisitely tender along its palmar aspect, and passive extension causes severe pain. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor tenosynovitis

 

  • The patient's symptoms are a perfect match for Kanavel's four cardinal signs, which are the definitive clinical criteria for this emergency hand infection:
  1. Uniform swelling of the affected finger.
  2. A semi-flexed posture of the digit.
  3. Exquisite tenderness along the course of the flexor tendon sheath.
  4. Severe pain with passive extension of the finger.
  • This condition requires urgent surgical drainage and broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent permanent disability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cellulitis: 

 

  • This is a diffuse bacterial infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. 
  • While it causes redness, swelling, and warmth, the infection is not confined to the tendon sheath. 
  • It lacks the specific signs of a semi-flexed posture and pain with passive extension, which are unique to tenosynovitis.

 

Option C. Septic arthritis: 

 

  • This is an infection of the joint space itself. 
  • The pain and swelling would be localized to the joint, not along the entire length of the tendon sheath. 
  • The pain would be most prominent with movement of the joint, but the specific finding of pain with passive extension of the entire digit is less characteristic.

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: 

 

  • This is a serious infection of the bone. 
  • It typically has a more insidious onset and presents with deep, localized pain. 
  • While it can cause swelling and tenderness, it does not typically produce the specific semi-flexed posture or tenderness along the tendon sheath that are characteristic of flexor tenosynovitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the classic clinical presentation of flexor tenosynovitis and differentiate it from other common hand infections. This is achieved by identifying Kanavel's four cardinal signs, which are pathognomonic for this condition.

questions.text: Match the following clinical tests with what they assess in airway examination:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • 1-A. Thyromental distance evaluates mandibular space.
  • 2-B. Mallampati classification evaluates tongue-to-pharyngeal space.
  • 3-C. Upper lip bite test checks mandibular mobility.
