  • 4-D. Sternomental distance evaluates neck extension and head movement.

 

Educational Objective:


Proper airway examination includes tests assessing tongue size, jaw mobility, and neck extension to predict intubation difficulty.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with secondary infertility. She has a history of two first-trimester miscarriages. Hysteroscopic evaluation is performed and revealed below. Based on the image shown, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

  • The hysteroscopic image demonstrates intrauterine adhesions (also known as Asherman syndrome), which is a common cause of secondary infertility, especially following uterine instrumentation such as curettage after miscarriage.
  • These adhesions may appear as fibrous bands within the endometrial cavity.
  • In this case, the appropriate next step is hysteroscopic adhesiolysis, which involves direct visualization and dissection of the adhesions to restore the normal uterine cavity and improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubal recanalization: Incorrect. Tubal recanalization is indicated in cases of tubal infertility, not when the problem lies within the uterine cavity, as seen here. There is no evidence of tubal obstruction in this case.

 

Option C. In-vitro fertilization (IVF): Incorrect. IVF is typically reserved for cases of tubal factor infertility, severe male factor infertility, or refractory intrauterine causes. Intrauterine adhesions are a correctable structural cause of infertility and should be managed surgically before considering IVF.

 

Option D. Hysteroscopic septal resection: Incorrect. This procedure is performed in patients with congenital uterine anomalies like a septate uterus, not acquired conditions like adhesions. The hysteroscopic image does not show a septum but rather fibrotic adhesions between uterine walls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome) are a common cause of secondary infertility, especially following uterine surgery or curettage.
  • Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is started on a new medication that inhibits an enzyme involved in purine metabolism. A Lineweaver-Burk plot is generated to determine the mechanism of inhibition. The plot shows that the inhibitor increases the slope of the line but does not alter the y-intercept. Which type of enzyme inhibition is most likely occurring?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive inhibition

 

Reasoning based on the plot:

 

  • In a Lineweaver–Burk plot,
    • Y-intercept = 1/Vmax
    • X-intercept = –1/Km
    • Slope = Km/Vmax
  • In competitive inhibition:
    • The inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site → you can overcome the inhibition by increasing substrate concentration.
    • Vmax remains unchanged → Y-intercept (1/Vmax) stays the same.
    • Km increases → the absolute value of X-intercept decreases (moves toward zero), slope increases.
  • The image shows:
    • Blue line = no inhibitor.
    • Red line (A) = with inhibitor → same Y-intercept but steeper slope.
    • This is exactly the pattern for competitive inhibition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive inhibition: Both Vmax and Km decrease → parallel lines (different y-intercept). Not seen here.

 

Option C. Mixed inhibition: Vmax decreases (y-intercept changes), Km can ↑ or ↓ depending on inhibitor's affinity → not matching the same y-intercept here.

 

Option D. Non-competitive inhibition: Vmax decreases (↑ y-intercept) with same Km → also not matching the given plot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site, increasing Km but leaving Vmax unchanged. 
  • On a Lineweaver–Burk plot, this produces a steeper slope with the same y-intercept.

choices.text: Resection of cyst along with adjacent bowel

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for an 8 cm chylo-lymphatic mesenteric cyst?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enucleation

 

  • Chylolymphatic mesenteric cysts are benign and arise from lymphatic channels in the mesentery.
  • If they are large or symptomatic (as in this 8 cm case), enucleation (removal without bowel resection) is the treatment of choice unless the cyst shares a common wall with bowel (i.e., enterogenous).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspiration: Incorrect. Aspiration of mesenteric cysts often results in recurrence. It is not definitive treatment and is not recommended for large or symptomatic cysts.

 

Option C. Resection of cyst along with adjacent bowel: Incorrect. This is reserved for enterogenous cysts, which are adherent to bowel and cannot be separated. Not the preferred option for chylolymphatic cysts.

 

Option D. Conservative: Incorrect. Conservative management is not appropriate for a large (8 cm) mesenteric cyst, due to risk of infection, rupture, volvulus, or obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enucleation is the preferred treatment for large chylolymphatic mesenteric cysts unless the cyst is enterogenous and requires bowel resection.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory tests is typically performed at the initial prenatal visit to screen for underlying health conditions and to provide a baseline for comparison throughout pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Urinalysis

 

  • At the initial prenatal visit, urinalysis is routinely performed to:
    • Detect baseline renal function
    • Identify asymptomatic bacteriuria, which, if untreated, can lead to complications like pyelonephritis
    • Screen for proteinuria or glucosuria, which may help assess early signs of hypertensive disorders or diabetes
  • Urinalysis serves as an essential baseline test that can be used for comparison throughout the pregnancy to monitor maternal health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose tolerance test: The oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is not performed at the initial prenatal visit unless the patient is at high risk for diabetes (e.g., obesity, previous GDM, family history). Typically, it is done between 24–28 weeks of gestation.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B surface antigen: Although Hepatitis B screening is performed at the first prenatal visit, urinalysis is more appropriate as a baseline comparison tool throughout pregnancy. Hepatitis B screening is important for infection control and neonatal prophylaxis but not for longitudinal maternal monitoring.

 

Option D. Pap smear: A Pap smear is done only if the woman is due for cervical cancer screening based on age and previous results. It is not specifically required or repeated at every pregnancy, nor is it a baseline for health comparisons throughout pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinalysis is a routine test at the first prenatal visit used to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria, assess renal function, and establish a baseline for maternal health monitoring during pregnancy.

choices.text: Withhold rabies vaccine and observe the dog for 10 days
Administer a cell culture rabies vaccine series
Euthanize the dog and send its brain for biopsy

questions.text: A 10‑year‑old child presents with an unprovoked dog bite to the forearm. The dog is a stray and its status is unknown. What is the most appropriate immediate action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer a cell‑culture rabies vaccine series

 

  • An unprovoked bite from a dog of unknown health status is considered a Category III exposure (transdermal bites or scratches). 
  • Such exposures carry a high risk of rabies transmission, and post‑exposure prophylaxis (PEP) should be initiated immediately with a WHO‑approved cell‑culture rabies vaccine (e.g., human diploid cell vaccine) along with rabies immunoglobulin infiltrated around the wound. 
  • Delaying vaccine or relying on animal observation risks fatal rabies infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Withhold rabies vaccine and observe the dog for 10 days: Only dogs known to be vaccinated and available for reliable observation may be monitored; stray dogs cannot be assessed safely, so PEP must not be delayed.

 

Option C. No further action is necessary: Failing to initiate PEP after a high‑risk bite is contraindicated and uniformly fatal if rabies develops.

 

Option D. Euthanize the dog and send its brain for biopsy: Brain testing confirms diagnosis but does not substitute for immediate PEP, which should start before test results and cannot wait for euthanasia or laboratory confirmation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO rabies exposure categories and PEP recommendations:

 

 

  • If previous PEP completed within the last 3 months, only two vaccine doses (Days 0 and 3) are given.

     

Key regimens (abbreviations):

 

  • IPC (Institut Pasteur du Cambodge): 2‑site ID on Days 0, 3, 7 (1 week total)
  • Essen (4‑dose IM): IM on Days 0, 7, 14, 28
  • Zagreb (2‑1‑1 IM/ID): 2 sites on Day 0 + 1 site on Days 7, 21 (3 weeks total)

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with stricturing Crohn’s disease involving the ileum has undergone multiple ileal resections for bowel obstruction. Which of the following complications is she not at increased risk of?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency

 

  • Ileal disease and resection are associated with multiple nutritional and metabolic complications due to malabsorption of bile salts and fat-soluble vitamins.
  • Common complications include:
    • Gallstones: Due to impaired bile salt reabsorption → increased cholesterol saturation of bile.
    • Kidney stones: Oxalate stones form due to increased intestinal oxalate absorption (fat binds calcium, leaving oxalate free).
    • Osteoporosis: Due to vitamin D and calcium malabsorption, chronic inflammation, and steroid use.
  • However, iron is primarily absorbed in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, not the ileum.
  • Therefore, iron deficiency is not typically a consequence of ileal resection unless there's active bleeding or proximal small bowel involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kidney stones: Increased risk due to hyperoxaluria from fat malabsorption after ileal resection.

 

Option C. Gallstones: Bile salt malabsorption leads to cholesterol supersaturation → gallstone formation.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis: Risk from malabsorption of vitamin D and calcium, chronic inflammation, and corticosteroid use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ileal resection in Crohn’s disease increases risk of gallstones, oxalate kidney stones, and osteoporosis.
  • Iron absorption occurs proximally; thus, iron deficiency is not directly related to ileal disease or resection.
  • Fat malabsorption underlies many of these complications due to bile salt loss in ileal disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old right-handed male presents with progressive wrist pain, especially during thumb extension. The discomfort worsens with certain movements such as reaching or gripping. On examination, there is tenderness and crepitus near the dorsal aspect of the distal radius. The physician suspects tenosynovitis. Which of the following tendons is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus 

 

  • The third extensor compartment of the wrist contains the extensor pollicis longus (EPL) tendon. 
  • This tendon wraps around the Lister's tubercle of the distal radius, making it particularly vulnerable to mechanical stress and tenosynovitis, especially in individuals with repetitive wrist and thumb use. 

 

 

  • Pain, swelling, and crepitus at this site are hallmark features. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL): This tendon lies within the second extensor compartment, not the third. It functions primarily in wrist extension and abduction.

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB): EPB passes through the first extensor compartment, along with abductor pollicis longus (APL). It helps in thumb extension but is not located in the third compartment.

 

Option D. Extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB): Like ECRL, ECRB travels through the second extensor compartment and aids wrist extension. It is not associated with the third compartment pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The third extensor compartment of the wrist contains the extensor pollicis longus (EPL) tendon, which wraps around Lister’s tubercle and is a common site for tenosynovitis in repetitive strain injuries.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with progressive nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis over the past several months. On nasal endoscopy, a reddish, lobulated mass is seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

  • This benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. 
  • It arises from the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity near the sphenopalatine foramen.
  • Key Clues:
    • Teenage male
    • Progressive nasal obstruction + recurrent, profuse epistaxis
    • Imaging: vascular mass in nasopharynx extending into pterygopalatine fossa with bony remodeling (Holman-Miller sign)
    • Endoscopic appearance: reddish, lobulated mass
    • Biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of severe hemorrhage. Diagnosis is made on the basis of clinical features and imaging (CT/MRI). Surgical excision is the treatment of choice, often preceded by preoperative embolization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antrochoanal polyp: Incorrect. Originates from the maxillary sinus, passes through the sinus ostium into the choana. Typically nonvascular and presents without recurrent severe epistaxis.

 

Option C. Ethmoidal polyp: Incorrect. Usually bilateral, pale, edematous masses seen in allergic rhinitis; do not cause massive bleeding.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Incorrect. Chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, producing friable, polypoid masses studded with white dots; not specific to adolescent males and without the typical pterygopalatine fossa extension. Strawberry like tumor will be seen 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign, highly vascular tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males. 
  • It presents with nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis, and is diagnosed clinically with imaging; biopsy is avoided due to bleeding risk.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with tinnitus, a sensation of fullness in his right ear, and progressive hearing loss over several years. Seven years after symptom onset, he develops vertigo, headache, and progressive imbalance. Audiometry reveals moderate sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear. Histopathologic examination of a biopsy specimen shows Antoni A and Antoni B cell patterns. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vestibular schwannoma

 

  • Vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma) is a benign tumor of Schwann cells, most commonly involving the vestibular portion of the CN VIII. 
  • Patients typically present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance. 
  • As the tumor enlarges, it can compress nearby cranial nerves and the brainstem, causing headache and ataxia.
  • Histology showing Antoni A (densely cellular) and Antoni B (loose) areas is pathognomonic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ménière disease: Incorrect. Characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and ear fullness due to endolymphatic hydrops. Hearing loss is typically fluctuating rather than progressively worsening over years, and histopathology does not show Antoni patterns.

 

Option C. Otosclerosis: Incorrect. Affects the stapes footplate, causing conductive hearing loss due to abnormal bone remodeling. It does not cause sensorineural loss or vertigo, and histology is unrelated.

 

Option D. Paget disease: Incorrect. Involves abnormal bone turnover, which can affect the skull base, leading to conductive or mixed hearing loss. It is not associated with Antoni cell histology or isolated vestibular nerve tumors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vestibular schwannoma presents with unilateral progressive sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance.

 

  • Histology shows Antoni A and B cell patterns, confirming the diagnosis.

choices.text: Encouraging individuals in all regions to exercise more
Assuming that every person in active regions is at low risk
Designing a randomized trial of exercise interventions

questions.text: An ecological analysis finds that regions with higher average physical activity have lower heart‑disease rates. Which flawed inference exemplifies the ecological fallacy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Assuming that every person in active regions is at low risk

 

  • The ecological fallacy arises when one infers individual risk or behavior from group‑level data. 
  • Although counties with higher average activity show lower heart‐disease rates, not every individual in those counties benefits equally—some may be sedentary or have other risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encouraging individuals in all regions to exercise more: True inference. Promoting exercise is reasonable based on the group association, though individual trials are needed.

 

Option C. Designing a randomized trial of exercise interventions: It is appropriate next step. A randomized trial tests whether increasing an individual’s activity reduces their heart‐disease risk.

 

Option D. Adjusting for regional dietary patterns: It is Sound analytic method. Adjusting for confounders like diet at the group level strengthens causal inference without committing the ecological fallacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Do not assume that relationships observed between populations (e.g., counties) necessarily apply to every individual within those populations; individual‐level studies are needed to confirm causality.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. He complains of severe neck pain and has limited neck movement. X-ray imaging of the cervical spine is performed and reveals the following findings. Based on the provided information, what is the most probable diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hangman’s Fracture

 

  • A Hangman's fracture is a fracture of the pars interarticularis of the axis (C2 vertebra). 
  • It is caused by a hyperextension-distraction injury, which is a common mechanism in a motor vehicle accident, especially when the patient's head snaps forward and then backward. 
  • The fracture is a bilateral fracture through the pedicles of C2, with a resulting traumatic spondylolisthesis (forward displacement of C2 on C3). 
  • The name "Hangman's" comes from the historical finding of this fracture in victims of judicial hanging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jefferson’s Fracture: 

 

  • This is a burst fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra). 
  • It is caused by an axial load on the head, such as a diving accident. 
  • The fracture involves the anterior and posterior arches of C1 and is characterized by a displacement of the lateral masses. 
  • While it is a cervical spine fracture, its mechanism and location are different from a Hangman's fracture.

 

Option B. Chance Fracture: 

 

  • This is a fracture of the spine that results from a hyperflexion injury, often seen in motor vehicle accidents where the patient is restrained by a lap belt without a shoulder belt. 
  • It primarily affects the thoracolumbar spine (T11-L2), not the cervical spine.

 

Option D. Odontoid Fracture: 

 

  • This is a fracture of the odontoid process (the dens), which is a tooth-like projection on the C2 vertebra. 
  • It can be caused by various types of trauma, including flexion and extension injuries. 
  • While it's a C2 fracture, the specific finding of a fracture through the pars interarticularis points more specifically to a Hangman's fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

One should be able to recognize a Hangman's fracture as a bilateral pars interarticularis fracture of C2, typically resulting from a hyperextension-distraction injury, which is a common finding in motor vehicle accidents.

questions.text: A 54‑year‑old woman with memory loss and suspected Alzheimer’s disease is referred for functional neuroimaging. Her physician orders a brain SPECT scan. Which radionuclide is routinely used for this scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Technetium

 

  • Technetium‑99m is the most widely used radionuclide in SPECT imaging. 
  • It emits a 140 keV gamma photon ideal for gamma‑camera detection, has a short physical half‑life (~6 hours) that limits radiation exposure, and can be readily bound to a variety of perfusion and receptor ligands for functional brain studies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radium: Emits alpha particles and gamma rays but has a long half‑life and poor imaging characteristics; it is not used for diagnostic SPECT.

 

Option C. Plutonium: A heavy alpha emitter used in nuclear weapons and fallout studies—totally unsuitable for medical imaging.

 

Option D. Barium: A radiopaque heavy metal used for X‑ray visualization of the gastrointestinal tract; it does not emit gamma photons and cannot be used for SPECT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SPECT uses technetium‑99m for its ideal gamma emission (140 keV) and short half‑life.
  • Other radionuclides (radium, plutonium) or contrast agents (barium) lack the appropriate emission profile or chemistry for functional nuclear imaging.

questions.text:
A patient has the following values for Starling forces at a capillary bed:

  • Capillary hydrostatic pressure  = 18 mmHg
  • Capillary oncotic pressure = 27 mmHg
  • Interstitial oncotic pressure = 7 mmHg

If there’s no net filtration across the capillaries, what is the value of the interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) –2 mmHg

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When there is no net filtration, the balance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures determines the interstitial hydrostatic pressure. 
  • In normal physiology, Pi is often slightly negative (~–2 mmHg), helping maintain fluid movement equilibrium between capillaries and interstitial space.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of gastric cancer underwent a total gastrectomy six months ago. He now presents with fatigue, pallor, and numbness in his hands and feet. Laboratory findings reveal macrocytic anemia, homocystinuria and methyl malonyl acid urea. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B12

 

This patient’s presentation points toward Vitamin B12 deficiency:

 

  1. History – Total gastrectomy → loss of intrinsic factor production from parietal cells → impaired B12 absorption in the ileum.
  2. Symptoms – Fatigue, pallor → anemia; Numbness in hands & feet → peripheral neuropathy due to demyelination.
  3. Lab clues:
    • Macrocytic anemia → megaloblastic anemia from impaired DNA synthesis.
    • Homocystinuria → B12 is needed to convert homocysteine → methionine.
    • Methylmalonic aciduria → B12 is required for conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA → succinyl-CoA.
    • Elevated methylmalonic acid is specific for B12 deficiency, not folate deficiency.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Vitamin B9 (Folate): Causes macrocytic anemia but no neurologic symptoms and methylmalonic acid remains normal.

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Deficiency causes scurvy (bleeding gums, poor wound healing), not macrocytosis or neuropathy.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Deficiency causes bone problems (osteomalacia, rickets), not anemia or neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency after gastrectomy results from loss of intrinsic factor production, leading to impaired absorption in the terminal ileum. It presents with macrocytic anemia, neurologic deficits, homocystinuria, and elevated methylmalonic acid levels.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not rooted in behavioral‐science principles for managing human behavior?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) System analysis 

 

  • System analysis originates from systems engineering and operations research. 
  • It focuses on mapping, modeling, and optimizing organizational processes and structures rather than on psychological or behavioral techniques to shape individual attitudes, motivations, or skills.
  • Quantitative methods
    • Cost benefit analysis
    • Cost effective analysis
    • Input output analysis
    • System analysis 
    • Network analysis (PERT and CPM)
    • Model
    • PPBS
    • Cost accounting
    • Work sampling 
    • Decision making

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Personal management: Draws on counseling, motivation theory, and interpersonal skills to guide and develop individual staff performance.

 

Option C. Management by objectives: Based on goal‑setting theory from organizational psychology; uses clear targets, participatory goal selection, and regular feedback to drive behavior change.

 

Option D. Communication strategies: Employ principles of persuasion, social marketing, and health‐behavior theory to influence attitudes and promote desired behaviors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Behavioral‑science techniques—such as personal management, goal‑setting (management by objectives), and strategic communication—focus on influencing people’s motivations and actions, whereas system analysis optimizes workflows and is not a direct behavior‑change method.

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant presents with scrotal swelling that has been present since birth. Now the swelling has become suddenly painful, red, and irreducible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated inguinal hernia

 

  • A long-standing reducible hernia that becomes painful, red, and irreducible suggests strangulation (vascular compromise of herniated contents). 
  • It is a surgical emergency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Incorrect. Rare in neonates and infants; it usually presents with pain but not irreducibility or sudden swelling. Also not associated with congenital hernias.

 

Option B. Testicular torsion: Incorrect. Presents with acute onset of pain, but there’s usually no prior scrotal swelling since birth. Seen in teenage boys

 

Option D. Hydrocele: In a child with prior scrotal swelling now presenting with pain, redness, and irreducibility, suspect strangulated inguinal hernia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful, red and irreducible swelling in an infant indicates strangulated inguinal hernia

questions.text: A middle-aged male experiences sudden onset of left-sided limb weakness and diplopia. Neurological examination reveals right-sided ptosis, a “down and out” eye position, and a dilated pupil. MRI confirms a lesion involving the ventral portion of the midbrain. Which of the following structures is most likely to remain unaffected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medial lemniscus

 

  • This clinical scenario describes a classic presentation of Weber syndrome, a brainstem stroke syndrome caused by infarction in the ventral midbrain.
  • The hallmark findings include:
    • Contralateral hemiparesis: due to involvement of the corticospinal tract in the cerebral peduncle.
    • Ipsilateral third nerve palsy: due to damage to oculomotor nerve fascicles, resulting in ptosis, a “down and out” eye, and a dilated pupil from parasympathetic fiber involvement.
  • Among the structures listed, the medial lemniscus lies dorsal to the cerebral peduncles and is usually spared in such ventral midbrain lesions.
  • Therefore, medial lemniscus is the correct answer.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Substantia nigra: Found in the ventral midbrain and located near the cerebral peduncles, making it susceptible in ventral midbrain infarcts. Thus, it is not typically spared.

 

Option C. Red nucleus: Positioned within the tegmentum of the midbrain, it may be affected depending on the size and extension of the lesion.

 

Option D. Edinger–Westphal nuclear fibers: These parasympathetic fibers contribute to pupillary constriction and travel with the oculomotor nerve. Because the fascicular part of the oculomotor nerve is involved in ventral lesions, these fibers are also likely to be compromised.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ventral midbrain infarction (Weber syndrome), medial lemniscus is usually spared while corticospinal tracts and oculomotor fascicles are affected, leading to contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral cranial nerve III palsy.

questions.text: The grid shown below is primarily used to evaluate which region of vision?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central 20° of vision

 

  • The Amsler grid subtends approximately 20 degrees of visual angle around fixation, allowing assessment of the macula and parafoveal retina. 
  • The test is called as Amsler’s test 
  • It is a home monitoring test 
    • The patient must wear spectacles 
    • It is done with one eye at a time 
    • Patient has to look at the central dot 
  • When a patient fixates the central dot, any distortion, waviness, or scotoma of the grid lines—known as metamorphopsia or central scotoma—will be confined to this central 20° field.

 

 

Seen in:

  • ARMD 
  • Posterior uveitis
  • CSR
  • Macular hole 
  • CME 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central 10° of vision: The 10° field is too small for an Amsler grid; that region is better tested by a 10-2 Humphrey visual field program.

 

Option C. Peripheral vision: Peripheral field defects (>20°) require kinetic or automated perimetry with a larger field of view (e.g., Goldmann or Humphrey 30-2/60-4).

 

Option D. Lens opacity: Lens changes are detected by slit-lamp examination and glare testing, not by grid distortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Use the Amsler grid to monitor the central 20° of the visual field for macular diseases—patients report line waviness or missing areas indicating metamorphopsia or scotoma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal distention and dull pain for the past month. She underwent a dilatation and curettage procedure for a molar pregnancy six months ago but has not followed up since. Her urine pregnancy test is strongly positive. Quantitative beta-hCG levels are elevated and remain persistently high on serial testing. A chest X-ray is ordered for further evaluation and is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methotrexate with folinic acid

 

  • This is case of choriocarcinoma 
  • The patient’s history of molar pregnancy followed by persistently elevated beta-hCG levels and the presence of “cannonball” pulmonary metastases on chest X-ray is consistent with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).
  • The choice between single-agent and multi-agent chemotherapy depends on the WHO risk score.
  • Patients with a low-risk metastatic GTN (score ≤ 6) — even if lung metastases are present — can be effectively treated with methotrexate plus folinic acid. 
  • This regimen is preferred due to its high cure rates, fewer side effects compared to multi-drug regimens, and ability to preserve fertility. 
  • In this patient, the history and findings suggest low-risk metastatic disease, making methotrexate with folinic acid the appropriate first-line choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EMACO regimen: Incorrect. This multi-agent chemotherapy (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, vincristine) is reserved for high-risk metastatic GTN (WHO score ≥ 7). It is not necessary in low-risk metastatic disease.

 

Option C. Methotrexate monotherapy: Incorrect. Methotrexate alone can be used for low-risk disease, but when pulmonary metastases are present, folinic acid rescue is generally added to reduce toxicity and optimize efficacy.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Incorrect. Surgery may be used in selected cases (e.g., localized uterine disease in women who do not desire fertility), but it is not first-line for metastatic GTN and would not treat distant metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In gestational trophoblastic neoplasia with low-risk metastatic disease — including pulmonary metastases but with a WHO score ≤ 6 — the treatment of choice is methotrexate with folinic acid.

choices.text: Do suction and again try intubation

questions.text: After an RTA patient has severe maxillofacial trauma with SpO₂ 80% at room air and the patient cannot be intubated or ventilated, what should be your immediate step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cricothyrotomy

 

  • In severe maxillofacial trauma, if both intubation and ventilation fail, securing the airway becomes the priority. 
  • Cricothyrotomy is the preferred emergency airway procedure as it can be performed rapidly and does not require neck extension or extensive surgical exposure. 
  • Tracheostomy is a more definitive airway but not the immediate step in acute emergencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal airway: Will not be possible in maxillofacial trauma

 

Option C. ICD insertion: Irrelevant here; used for pneumothorax or hemothorax.

 

Option D. Do suction and again try intubation: Already tried and failed, hence not useful now.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In trauma with failed intubation and ventilation, emergency cricothyrotomy is the immediate lifesaving airway intervention.

questions.text: Match each renal condition with its characteristic histopathologic finding:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) a–2, b–3, c–4, d–1

 

  • a. Chronic reflux nephropathy → 2 (Segmental sclerosis involving some glomeruli, often with hyaline deposition): Chronic reflux nephropathy results from repeated episodes of vesicoureteral reflux causing cortical scarring and loss of functional nephrons. The surviving nephrons undergo hyperfiltration injury, producing the focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) pattern. Histologically, this is seen as segmental sclerosis in some glomeruli with frequent hyaline deposition.
  • b. Diabetic nephropathy → 3 (Nodular glomerulosclerosis): Long-standing diabetes causes non-enzymatic glycosylation of the GBM and mesangial proteins, leading to increased permeability and mesangial matrix expansion. The hallmark lesion is Kimmelstiel–Wilson nodules (nodular glomerulosclerosis).
  • c. Membranous nephropathy → 4 (Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial immune deposits): Membranous nephropathy is characterized by immune complex deposition on the subepithelial side of the GBM. This produces diffuse GBM thickening seen on light microscopy and spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy.
  • d. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) → 1 (Crescents in Bowman’s space) : RPGN is a severe form of glomerulonephritis that progresses rapidly to renal failure. Histologically, crescents composed of proliferating parietal epithelial cells and infiltrating monocytes/macrophages fill Bowman’s space, compressing the glomerular tuft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic reflux nephropathy most often leads to secondary FSGS; diabetic nephropathy is characterized by Kimmelstiel–Wilson nodules; membranous nephropathy shows subepithelial immune deposits with diffuse GBM thickening; RPGN demonstrates crescents in Bowman’s space.

questions.text: Infiltration of which of the following structures causes this defect in the breast?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cooper’s ligament

 

  • The image shows dimpling of the skin over the breast, which is a classical sign seen in invasive breast carcinoma. This happens due to involvement of Cooper's ligaments.
  • Cooper’s ligaments (also known as suspensory ligaments of the breast) are fibrous connective tissue strands that anchor the breast tissue to the overlying skin.
  • In invasive breast cancer, cancer cells infiltrate and shorten these ligaments.
  • This leads to tethering of the skin over the involved area, causing visible dimpling or puckering of the skin, and sometimes fixation.
  • This clinical sign is important for early suspicion of underlying malignancy even before a palpable lump becomes evident.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lactiferous duct: Involved in milk secretion, and its blockage may cause nipple discharge or retraction, but not dimpling of the skin.

 

Option C. Dermal lymphatics: Obstruction here leads to peaud’orange appearance due to lymphatic edema, not dimpling due to tethering.

 

Option D. Suspensory fascia: A vague term and not anatomically distinct; Cooper's ligaments are the specific suspensory structures involved in this pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dimpling of breast skin in carcinoma is caused by cancer infiltration and shortening of Cooper’s ligaments, which tether the skin, leading to puckering or fixation.

questions.text: In a patient with pulmonary embolism causing complete obstruction of blood flow. Which of the following points on the V/Q curve corresponds with given condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point D

 

  • A complete obstruction of pulmonary arterial blood flow means there is no perfusion to the affected alveolus.
  • This results in a ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio approaching infinity (∞): ventilation is present, but perfusion is absent.
  • On a V/Q diagram plotting alveolar PO₂ vs PCO₂, this situation corresponds to the dead space point — where alveolar gas composition approaches inspired air:
  • PO₂ ≈ 150 mm Hg (humidified inspired air value at sea level)
  • PCO₂ ≈ 0 mm Hg
  • Point D on the curve represents this extreme, and is therefore correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point A:

 

  • Represents low V/Q close to zero, as in a shunt situation (e.g., complete airway obstruction).
  • Perfusion is present, but ventilation is absent, causing alveolar gas to resemble mixed venous blood (low PO₂, high PCO₂).

 

Option B. Point B:

 

  • Reflects normal V/Q ratio (~0.8) with normal alveolar gas values (PO₂ ~100 mm Hg, PCO₂ ~40 mm Hg).
  • Seen in healthy, well-matched lung regions.

 

Option C. Point C:

 

  • Indicates moderately elevated V/Q ratio (e.g., apex of the lung in an upright person), where ventilation exceeds perfusion.
  • Leads to alveolar gas PO₂ higher than normal, and PCO₂ lower than normal, but not to the extremes of dead space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On the alveolar V/Q curve, pulmonary embolism causing complete cessation of blood flow creates a dead space unit (V/Q → ∞).  
  • Here, alveolar gas composition approaches that of inspired air (PO₂ ~150 mm Hg, PCO₂ ~0 mm Hg), corresponding to the dead space point on the diagram (Point D).

choices.text: Association with cavitary lesions due to central necrosis
Predilection for peripheral location in the lung
Increased incidence in non-smokers, especially women

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 50-pack-year smoking history presents with persistent cough and weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals a hilar mass. Biopsy of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following features is most strongly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Association with cavitary lesions due to central necrosis

 

  • The biopsy demonstrates keratin pearls, a hallmark of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung.
  • SCC is strongly associated with smoking and typically arises as a central hilar mass.
  • Due to its central necrosis and obstructive growth pattern, cavitation within the lesion is common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High frequency of EGFR mutations: Seen more in adenocarcinoma of the lung, particularly in nonsmokers.

 

Option C. Predilection for peripheral location in the lung: This describes adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Option D. Increased incidence in non-smokers, especially women: Again, this describes adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is a smoking-related central tumor characterized by keratin pearls and cavitation due to central necrosis.

questions.text:
During β-oxidation of palmitic acid (C₁₆), which of the following are produced?

 

  1. Three molecules of acetyl-CoA
  2. A net yield of 106ATP
  3. A net yield of 108 ATP
  4. Sixteen molecules of acetyl-CoA
  5. Eighty ATP produced from the citric acid cycle per molecule of palmitoyl-CoA
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 5

 

Step 1 – Understanding β-oxidation of palmitic acid (C₁₆)

 

  • Palmitic acid has 16 carbons.
  • β-oxidation cleaves 2 carbons at a time → produces acetyl-CoA.

 

Number of acetyl-CoA formed:

 

Number of carbons = 16 /2 = 8 acetyl-CoA

 

So 16 acetyl-CoA in option 4 is wrong — it should be 8.

 

Step 2 – ATP yield from palmitic acid oxidation

 

1. β-oxidation cycles:


Number of cycles = n/2 – 1 = 8 – 1 = 7 cycles


Each cycle gives:

  • 1 NADH → 2.5 ATP
  • 1 FADH₂ → 1.5 ATP

ATP from 7 cycles = 7 × (2.5+1.5) = 7×4 =28 ATP

 

2. TCA cycle from acetyl-CoA:

 

Each acetyl-CoA gives:

  • 3 NADH → 7.5 ATP
  • 1 FADH₂ → 1.5 ATP
  • 1 GTP → 1 ATP
    Total = 10 ATP per acetyl-CoA

8 acetyl-CoA → 8×10=80 ATP (matches option 5)

 

3. Total ATP before activation cost:

 

28 (from β-oxidation) + 80 (from TCA) = 108 ATP

 

4. Subtract 2 ATP for fatty acid activation:

 

108 – 2 = 106 ATP net yield (matches option 2)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete β-oxidation of palmitic acid yields 8 acetyl-CoA, which produce 80 ATP via the TCA cycle, plus additional ATP from NADH and FADH₂ generated during β-oxidation, for a net total of 106 ATP after subtracting the activation cost.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman complains of persistent thoughts of contamination and compulsive handwashing. She recognizes the thoughts as irrational but cannot stop herself. What is the first-line psychotherapy for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exposure and response prevention

 

  • Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the first-line psychotherapy for Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD).
  • ERP involves gradually exposing the patient to feared stimuli (e.g., dirt, germs) and preventing the usual compulsive response (e.g., handwashing).
  • Over time, this reduces anxiety and the urge to perform compulsions through habituation.
  • The key aspect in this case is that the patient is aware that her thoughts are irrational (ego-dystonic), yet is unable to stop the compulsions — a classic presentation of OCD, and ERP is specifically designed to address this pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psychoanalysis: An insight-oriented therapy focusing on unconscious conflicts; not effective for OCD, especially not as first-line treatment.
 

Option B. Systematic desensitization: A technique used for phobias, involving relaxation training and gradual exposure to a feared stimulus. It is less effective for OCD, which involves obsessions and compulsions rather than simple avoidance behaviors.
 

Option C. Cognitive restructuring: Part of CBT, useful for addressing maladaptive beliefs, but on its own, it is less effective than ERP in managing compulsions. ERP specifically targets the behavioral aspect of OCD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. 
  • It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

questions.text: A patient presents with irregular swelling over the foot, with multiple discharging sinuses and black granules in the discharge. A KOH mount is performed on the discharge. What is the most likely observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Septate hyphae 4–5 μm

 

  • The presentation is classical of mycetoma, specifically eumycetoma caused by fungi (vs. actinomycetoma caused by bacteria). 
  • The presence of black granules strongly suggests a fungal mycetoma (black-grain eumycetoma).

 

  • Key Diagnostic Clues:
    • Discharging sinuses + granules: Seen in mycetoma.
    • Black granules: Associated with eumycetoma (fungal origin), especially dematiaceous fungi.
    • KOH mount: Helps visualize fungal elements.
  • Characteristic of fungal eumycetoma.
  • Especially Madurella mycetomatis and other dematiaceous fungi show septate branching hyphae in KOH.
  • Right thickness (4–5 μm) and septation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yeast:

 

  • Seen in infections like candidiasis or cryptococcosis.
  • Do not form granules or sinuses like in this case.
  • Incorrect.

 

Option C. Dematiaceous fungi:

 

  • This refers to the fungal group (pigmented fungi), not an observation on KOH mount.
  • The KOH finding is the hyphal structure, not the fungal classification.
  • Incorrect as an observation.

 

Option D. Arthrospore:

 

  • Seen in infections like tinea (dermatophytes), Coccidioides, etc.
  • Not typical in mycetoma presentation.
  • Incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with chronic discharging sinuses and black granules, eumycetoma should be suspected. 
  • KOH mount reveals septate hyphae (4–5 μm), distinguishing fungal mycetoma from actinomycetoma, which shows thin filamentous bacteria.

questions.text: A small clinic measures mean waiting time for its first five patients as 12 minutes. When a sixth patient experiences a 60-minute wait, the clinic director wants to quantify how dramatically the average increased. By approximately what percent did the mean waiting time increase after including the sixth patient’s 60-minute delay?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 66.7%

 

  • The original total waiting time for five patients is 

 

5 × 12 = 60 minutes

 

  • Adding the sixth patient’s 60 minutes gives a new total of 

 

60 + 60 = 120 minutes 

 

  • Dividing by six patients yields 

 

120 ÷ 6 = 20 minutes 

 

  • Absolute increase in mean: 20 − 12 = 8 min
  • Percent increase: 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a new data point alters the average, quantify its impact using: 

 

(New Mean - Original Mean)  ÷ Original Mean × 100%

 

to express the relative change—recognizing that extreme values can dramatically skew the mean.

questions.text: Pasteurella multocida infection in humans is most commonly acquired through which route?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Animal bite

 

  • Pasteurella multocida is a gram-negative coccobacillus that is part of the normal oral and respiratory flora of many animals, especially cats and dogs.
  • Human infection typically follows bites or scratches, whereby the organism is inoculated directly into subcutaneous tissues.
  • Clinical manifestations include cellulitis, abscess formation, and potential systemic spread (septic arthritis, osteomyelitis) if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insect bite: While various pathogens (e.g., Bartonella henselae) can be transmitted by arthropod vectors, Pasteurella is not insect-borne.

 

Option C. Respiratory droplets: P. multocida does not spread via the respiratory route; respiratory transmission is associated with organisms like Bordetella pertussis or Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Sexual contact: This mode of transmission is not implicated in Pasteurella infections, which are zoonotic and linked to direct animal exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For any cat or dog bite, promptly irrigate the wound and consider antibiotic coverage (e.g., amoxicillin–clavulanate) to prevent Pasteurella multocida–associated cellulitis and deeper tissue infection.

questions.text: A 32‑year‑old woman discovers a firm, mobile lump in her right breast during self‑examination. She has no nipple changes, discharge, or systemic symptoms. A targeted ultrasound image is shown below. Which diagnosis is most consistent with these sonographic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibroadenoma

 

  • A fibroadenoma typically appears on ultrasound as a solid, oval mass with uniform echotexture, smooth margins, and sometimes lateral (edge) shadowing caused by the benign lesion’s compressible, fibrous nature.
  • These features contrast with the fluid‑filled, anechoic appearance of a cyst and the irregular, spiculated, vascular patterns seen in malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breast abscess: Presents as a complex, often painful fluid collection with posterior enhancement and irregular walls—not a uniform, solid mass with edge shadowing.

 

Option B. Invasive ductal carcinoma: Usually appears taller‑than‑wide, spiculated or angular, and hypoechoic with internal vascular flow, lacking the smooth, benign profile of this lesion.

 

Option D. Simple cyst: Is entirely anechoic (black) with marked posterior acoustic enhancement rather than iso‑ to hypoechoic texture and edge shadow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An oval, well‑defined, iso‑ to hypoechoic breast lesion with edge shadowing in a young woman is highly suggestive of a fibroadenoma and typically managed with routine imaging follow‑up rather than immediate biopsy.

questions.text: Two independent groups of diabetic patients (n=12 each) rate their quality of life on a validated 5‑point ordinal scale. The distributions are skewed, and the data do not meet parametric assumptions. Which statistical test is most appropriate to compare the two groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mann–Whitney U test

 

  • The Mann–Whitney U test (also called the Wilcoxon rank‑sum test) compares two independent samples on an ordinal (or non‑normal continuous) outcome by ranking all observations and assessing whether one group’s ranks tend to be higher than the other’s. 
  • It does not require normality and is ideal for skewed distributions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wilcoxon signed‑rank test: Designed for paired or matched samples (e.g., before/after measurements in the same subjects), not independent groups.

 

Option C. Sign test: Compares binary or paired directional changes within the same subjects, not suitable for two independent samples or full ordinal scales. It is done for comparing before and after in 1 group 

 

Option D. Chi‑square test: Compares categorical frequencies across groups; ignores the ordinal nature and requires larger expected cell counts. It is done for comparing  ≥2 group of people.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Use the Mann–Whitney U test to compare two independent groups on an ordinal or non‑normal continuous outcome—reserve paired tests (Wilcoxon signed‑rank or sign test) for matched data and chi‑square for categorical counts.

choices.text: Pisiform normally appears later than other carpals
Early estrogen exposure accelerates pisiform ossification
Lunate should not yet be ossified at this age

questions.text: A pediatric endocrinologist reviews a wrist X-ray of an 11-year-old girl. All carpal centers except the pisiform are present. Which of the following best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pisiform normally appears later than other carpals

 

  • Carpal bones 
    • 1st 2 carpal bones → 2 months 
    • 3rd – 7th carpal bone → 3 – 6 years 
    • 8th carpal bone (Pisiform) → 10 - 12 years
  • By age 11, all carpal ossification centers except the pisiform should be present. 
  • The pisiform is the last carpal to ossify—typically between 10 and 12 years of age—because it arises within the tendon of the flexor carpi ulnaris rather than directly from the general carpal ossification sequence. 
  • Seeing all other centers (capitate, hamate, triquetral, lunate, scaphoid, trapezium, trapezoid) but no pisiform is therefore normal for an 11-year-old.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skeletal maturation is suggested: A “bone age” delay would involve missing ossification centers that should normally appear by this age (e.g., scaphoid or trapezoid). Here, only the pisiform is absent, which is expected—so maturation is on schedule.

 

Option C. Early estrogen exposure accelerates pisiform ossification: Hormonal influences can affect overall skeletal maturation, but the pisiform’s timing is highly consistent across genders and hormonal states. Early estrogen does not selectively advance only the pisiform.

 

Option D. Lunate should not yet be ossified at this age: The lunate ossifies by 4 years—well before age 11—so its presence is entirely expected and would not argue against normal development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pisiform is the final carpal bone to ossify, appearing between 10 and 12 years; all other carpals are present by early childhood.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining facial trauma in a road traffic accident. He reports nasal pain, swelling, and difficulty breathing through his nose. On examination, there is visible nasal deformity with tenderness over the nasal bridge and crepitus. There is no septal hematoma. A lateral X-ray of the nasal bones is as given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate instrument for reduction of this fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Walsham forceps

 

  • Walsham forceps are specifically designed for closed reduction of nasal bone fractures.
  • They have a smooth surface to prevent mucosal trauma and are used to realign displaced nasal bones under local or general anesthesia. 
  • In lateral nasal bone fractures, these forceps are inserted intranasally to elevate and reposition the bone fragments to restore both airway patency and cosmetic contour.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luc’s forceps: Incorrect. Luc’s forceps are mainly used in endoscopic sinus surgery or Caldwell-Luc procedures to remove diseased mucosa, polyps, or bony fragments from the maxillary sinus. They are not intended for nasal bone fracture reduction.

 

Option C. Killian’s forceps: Incorrect. Killian’s nasal speculum (sometimes called forceps) is used for anterior rhinoscopy and nasal septal surgeries, particularly for exposing the septum. It is not a reduction tool for nasal fractures.

 

Option D. Tilley’s forceps: Incorrect. Tilley’s forceps are angled, toothed or untoothed forceps mainly used for packing removal or placing nasal packs in epistaxis. They are not designed for manipulating or reducing bone fractures.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Walsham forceps are the instrument of choice for closed reduction of nasal bone fractures, allowing atraumatic manipulation and realignment of displaced fragments to restore nasal structure and function.

questions.text: Match the following transplant-related conditions with their correct immunological mechanism:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a–2, b–3, c–1, d–4

 

  • a. GVHD (Runt disease) → 2. Donor immunocompetent T lymphocytes recognize host alloantigens and attack recipient tissues: Donor T cells attack host tissues (skin, liver, GI tract).
  • b. Hyperacute rejection → 3. Preformed recipient antibodies react with donor endothelium → complement activation and thrombosis: Mediated by preformed antibodies (eg, anti-ABO, anti-HLA) → immediate thrombosis and necrosis.
  • c. Acute rejection → 1. Host T lymphocytes recognize alloantigens on donor tissue and activate cytokine-mediated cytotoxicity (CD8⁺ and CD4⁺ T cells): Host T cells recognize donor antigens → cytokine release, inflammation, and cytotoxic killing.
  • d. Chronic rejection → 4. Host T cells and antibodies cause progressive fibrosis and narrowing of graft vessels: Long-term immune injury → smooth muscle proliferation, fibrosis, and vascular narrowing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • GVHD (Runt disease): Donor T cells attack host tissues.
  • Hyperacute rejection: Preformed host antibodies cause complement-mediated necrosis.
  • Acute rejection: Host T cells mediate direct cytotoxicity.
  • Chronic rejection: Progressive fibrosis and vascular narrowing lead to long-term graft loss.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoes a liver transplant from an unrelated donor. Six weeks post–transplant, he develops fever and elevated liver enzymes. Biopsy reveals lymphocytic infiltration and endothelial damage. Which rejection type is most likely and what cell type mediates it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute rejection; T lymphocytes

 

Timing & Histology:

 

  • Occurs weeks to months after transplant (here, 6 weeks).
  • Histology shows dense lymphocytic infiltrates targeting graft endothelium and parenchyma.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Host T lymphocytes (predominantly CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, aided by CD4+ helper T cells) recognize donor allo–MHC molecules on graft cells.
  • This triggers cell-mediated cytotoxicity, release of perforin/granzymes, and cytokine-driven inflammation, resulting in graft injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperacute rejection; B cells:

 

  • Hyperacute: Occurs minutes to hours post-transplant due to preformed antibodies (B-cell products) against donor antigens → complement activation and thrombosis.
  • This patient’s presentation at 6 weeks and lymphocytic infiltrate are inconsistent.

 

Option C. Chronic rejection; macrophages: 

 

  • Chronic: Develops months to years later with vascular intimal fibrosis, smooth-muscle proliferation, and parenchymal fibrosis. 
  • Macrophages and antibodies contribute, but timing and histology differ.

 

Option D. Late acute rejection; neutrophils:

 

  • Neutrophils are key in hyperacute (early) and ischemia–reperfusion injury, not in typical acute cellular rejection. 
  • There is no distinct “late acute” entity mediated by neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute graft rejection occurs weeks to months post-transplant and is mediated by host T lymphocytes recognizing donor MHC on graft cells, leading to lymphocytic infiltration and endothelial injury.
  • A transplant patient presenting 4–12 weeks after surgery with fever, organ dysfunction, and lymphocytic infiltrates on biopsy is experiencing acute T cell–mediated rejection, which requires adjustment of immunosuppression to prevent permanent graft damage.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, 2 weeks postpartum, reports hearing voices commanding her to harm her baby. She is disorganized and has not been sleeping. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Admit and start antipsychotics

 

  • This patient is presenting with postpartum psychosis, a psychiatric emergency that occurs within days to weeks after childbirth. 
  • Hallucinations (especially command auditory hallucinations to harm the baby), disorganized behavior, and insomnia are red flags. 
  • The next best step is immediate psychiatric hospitalization to ensure the safety of both mother and infant, and to initiate antipsychotic medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe SSRI and monitor: SSRIs are used for postpartum depression, not psychosis. Delaying appropriate treatment in psychosis is dangerous.

 

Option C. Start mood stabilizer at home: Mood stabilizers may be used in bipolar postpartum psychosis, but home treatment is unsafe given the risk of infanticide or self-harm. Hospitalization is necessary.

 

Option D. Reassure and schedule follow-up: Reassurance and outpatient management are inappropriate in acute postpartum psychosis, especially with command hallucinations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postpartum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency requiring immediate inpatient care and antipsychotic therapy to protect both mother and child.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is prescribed isoniazid as part of combination therapy for latent tuberculosis. After 4 weeks, he presents with numbness and tingling in both feet. Neurologic exam reveals decreased pinprick and vibration sensation in a stocking-glove distribution. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism predisposing this patient to the adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slow acetylation of isoniazid

 

  • Isoniazid is metabolized by N-acetyltransferase, and patients who are slow acetylators accumulate more of the parent drug. 
  • This increases the risk of peripheral neuropathy due to pyridoxine (vitamin B6) depletion. 
  • Genetic polymorphism in the acetylation pathway explains the variability in toxicity profiles among individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rapid hydroxylation of isoniazid: Hydroxylation is not the primary metabolic route for isoniazid.

 

Option C. Impaired renal clearance of isoniazid: Isoniazid is mainly metabolized hepatically, not cleared renally.

 

Option D. Cytochrome P450 inhibition by isoniazid: Though isoniazid can inhibit CYP enzymes, this is not the mechanism for neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Slow acetylators are at increased risk of isoniazid-induced peripheral neuropathy due to impaired drug clearance and pyridoxine deficiency.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with known ATTR amyloidosis presents for follow-up. She has been suffering from HFpEF, and peripheral neuropathy for the last 6 months. Genetic testing confirms transthyretin gene mutation, and nuclear scans confirm amyloid deposition. Which of the following is not used in the treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nusinersen

 

  • ATTR amyloidosis can be wild-type or hereditary and results from misfolded transthyretin (TTR) protein, depositing in the heart, nerves, or other organs.
  • Treatment approaches target different steps in TTR amyloidogenesis:
  • Nusinersen is used in spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) and has no role in ATTR amyloidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tafamidis: FDA-approved for ATTR cardiomyopathy; stabilizes the TTR tetramer to prevent misfolding.

 

Option C. Diflunisal: NSAID shown to stabilize TTR; used off-label for ATTR polyneuropathy.

 

Option D. Vutisiran: siRNA therapy approved for hereditary ATTR amyloidosis with polyneuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tafamidis, diflunisal, and vutisiran are approved or used off-label for ATTR amyloidosis.
  • Nusinersen is specific to SMA and has no therapeutic role in ATTR.
  • Therapies target either TTR stabilization or reduction of TTR synthesis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss and unsteadiness while walking. MRI of the brain shows a mass at the cerebellopontine angle compressing the vestibulocochlear nerve. The mass is surgically excised and histology confirms a benign tumor. Several years later, follow-up imaging reveals multiple dural-based enhancing lesions consistent with meningiomas. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mutation of the NF2 gene

 

  • This presentation is most consistent with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • NF2 is caused by a mutation in the NF2 gene located on chromosome 22, which encodes the tumor suppressor protein merlin (schwannomin).
  • Merlin regulates contact-dependent inhibition of cell proliferation. Loss of merlin allows uncontrolled proliferation of Schwann cells, meningothelial cells, and ependymal cells.
  • Key features of NF2:
    • Bilateral vestibular schwannomas (or unilateral schwannoma in young patients) involving the cerebellopontine angle and CN VIII → hearing loss, tinnitus, imbalance
    • Multiple meningiomas and ependymomas of the spinal cord
  • The combination of a vestibular schwannoma and later multiple meningiomas is classic for NF2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation of the CDKN2 gene: CDKN2A mutations are linked to familial melanoma and pancreatic cancer, not schwannomas or meningiomas.

 

Option B. Mutation of the WT gene: WT1 and WT2 gene mutations are associated with Wilms tumor, a pediatric renal malignancy, and do not cause CNS tumors.

 

Option D. Mutation of the PTEN gene: PTEN mutations cause Cowden syndrome, which is associated with multiple hamartomas and increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers — not vestibular schwannomas or meningiomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the NF2 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22. 
  • It presents with bilateral vestibular schwannomas, multiple meningiomas, and spinal ependymomas.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with a history of recurrent bacterial infections, including otitis media and pneumonia. On examination, the infant has absent tonsils and lymph nodes, and laboratory investigations show very low levels of all immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, IgM). Flow cytometry reveals absent CD19+ B cells but normal T-cell counts. Which of the following best describes the type of immunity that is defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Humoral immunity

 

  • The clinical picture is consistent with Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia (X-linked agammaglobulinemia).
  • There is a defect in B-cell maturation → absent B cells (CD19+) → no antibody production → defective humoral immunity.
  • This leads to recurrent infections with encapsulated bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cell-mediated immunity: Incorrect because,

 

  • Cell-mediated immunity is mediated by T cells, especially CD4+ and CD8+ T cells.
  • In this case, T-cell count is normal, and the infections are predominantly bacterial, not viral or fungal (which are typical in T-cell defects like DiGeorge syndrome).

 

Option B. Innate immunity: Incorrect because,

 

  • Innate immunity involves neutrophils, macrophages, NK cells, and barriers.
  • Defects here often present with severe, early-onset infections (e.g., in CGD, LAD).
  • This child specifically has absent B cells and low immunoglobulins, which points to adaptive immunity (humoral), not innate.

 

Option C. Complement-mediated immunity: Incorrect because,

 

  • Complement deficiencies (like C3, C5-C9) lead to issues like recurrent Neisseria infections, or increased susceptibility to pyogenic infections.
  • But complement defects usually show normal immunoglobulin levels and normal B-cell counts.
  • Here, the absence of B cells and all Ig classes is key.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Humoral immunity is the part of adaptive immunity mediated by B cells and antibodies (IgG, IgA, IgM, etc.).
  • It protects against extracellular bacteria, viruses, and toxins by neutralization and opsonization.
  • Deficiency leads to recurrent bacterial infections, especially with encapsulated organisms, due to impaired antibody production.

questions.text: Identify the drug which works by the mechanism shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nilotinib

 

  • Nilotinib is a second-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) that specifically targets the BCR-ABL fusion protein, which is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). 
  • It binds to the ATP-binding site, blocking phosphorylation of tyrosine residues on downstream substrates, thereby inhibiting intracellular signaling and proliferation of leukemic cells. 
  • This is exactly what's illustrated in the image: the left side shows ATP enabling phosphorylation, and the right side shows a drug (Z) preventing ATP binding and thereby blocking signal transduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate: A folate antagonist that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, used in cancer and autoimmune diseases; does not affect tyrosine kinases.

 

Option C. Pertuzumab: A monoclonal antibody against HER2, preventing dimerization of the receptor in breast cancer; it does not target BCR-ABL or block ATP binding.

 

Option D. Cisplatin: A platinum-based chemotherapy that forms DNA crosslinks; its action is unrelated to kinase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nilotinib inhibits the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase by binding to its ATP-binding site, thereby blocking phosphorylation and downstream leukemic signaling in CML.

questions.text: In the figure below, which letter designates a reaction that may be catalyzed by different enzymes in different tissues, playing an important role in regulation of serum glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Letter A

 

  • Letter A represents the reaction: Glucose → Glucose-6-phosphate
  • This phosphorylation step is catalyzed by different enzymes in different tissues:
    • Hexokinase (in most tissues) — low Km, high affinity, inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate.
    • Glucokinase (in liver and pancreatic β-cells) — high Km, high capacity, not inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate; active mainly when blood glucose is high.
  • This difference is important in regulation of serum glucose:
    • Liver glucokinase helps remove excess glucose after a meal.
    • Hexokinase ensures constant glucose trapping in peripheral tissues even at low blood glucose.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Letter B: Glucose-6-phosphate → Fructose-6-phosphate via phosphohexose isomerase

 

  • Same enzyme in all tissues, not a key point of hormonal control of blood glucose.

 

Option C. Letter C: Fructose-6-phosphate → Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate via PFK-1

 

  • This is the rate-limiting step of glycolysis, but catalyzed by the same enzyme everywhere; regulation here is more about metabolic flux, not directly serum glucose control.

 

Option D. Letter E:  Letter E is triose phosphate isomerase , Same enzyme in all tissues, not a key point of hormonal control of blood glucose

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate is catalyzed by hexokinase in most tissues and glucokinase in the liver and pancreatic β-cells. These isoenzymes have different kinetic properties, enabling tissue-specific regulation of glucose utilization and serum glucose levels.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with several months of headaches and new-onset seizures. MRI reveals a well-circumscribed lesion in the frontal lobe with calcifications. Histopathology of the lesion is shown in the image below. Which of the following molecular alterations is most commonly associated with this tumor and predicts better prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IDH mutation with 1p/19q co-deletion

 

  • Oligodendrogliomas are slow-growing primary brain tumors that often present in adults with seizures.
  • They typically occur in the frontal lobe and frequently show calcifications on imaging.
  • Histology: “Fried egg” cells with clear perinuclear halos and “chicken-wire” capillary vasculature.
  • Molecular hallmark: IDH mutation with 1p/19q co-deletion, which not only confirms the diagnosis but also indicates better prognosis and response to therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTEN loss with EGFR amplification: Found in glioblastoma not oligodendroglioma.

 

Option C. NF2 mutation on chromosome 22q: Associated with acoustic neuroma, meningiomas and schwannomas.

 

Option D. BRAF V600E mutation: Seen in juvenile pilocytic astrocytomas and some gangliogliomas, not oligodendrogliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oligodendrogliomas present with calcified frontal lobe tumors and seizures. Histology shows “fried egg” cells and chicken-wire vasculature. 
  • The key molecular alteration is IDH mutation with 1p/19q co-deletion, predicting favorable prognosis.

choices.text: Formation of organized bacterial communities on surfaces

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient with cystic fibrosis has a respiratory culture that grows a slimy, mucoid strain of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which feature is most directly enabled by this mucoid phenotype?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formation of organized bacterial communities on surfaces

 

  • The mucoid appearance of P. aeruginosa colonies is caused by alginate overproduction, an exopolysaccharide that is a key component of biofilms.
  • Biofilms are structured multicellular communities of bacteria embedded in a self-produced matrix. 
  • Within a biofilm, bacteria:
    • Adhere tightly to respiratory epithelium or indwelling devices.
    • Are protected from mechanical clearance and immune cells.
    • Exhibit markedly reduced susceptibility to antibiotics and disinfectants because the matrix and altered metabolic state limit drug penetration and efficacy.
  • Thus, the mucoid strain’s primary clinical significance is its ability to produce biofilms, which underlies chronic, difficult-to-treat infections in cystic fibrosis patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intrinsic resistance to antibiotics: While biofilm formation indirectly confers antibiotic tolerance, mucoid does not change the bacterial cell’s inherent drug-resistance mechanisms (e.g., efflux pumps, β-lactamases).

 

Option C. Enhanced secretion of exotoxin A: Exotoxin A production is regulated independently of alginate synthesis; mucoid strains do not secrete more exotoxin than nonmucoid strains.

 

Option D. Elevated production of bacteriocins: Bacteriocins are antimicrobial peptides targeting other bacteria; their production is not linked to the mucoid, alginate-overproducing phenotype.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mucoid phenotype of P. aeruginosa reflects biofilm formation, not an inherent increase in toxin or bacteriocin production, and is the cornerstone of its persistence in chronic lung infections.

choices.text: It is administered intramuscularly once a month
It acts as a selective estrogen receptor downregulator without agonist effects
It acts rapidly and is considered safer and more potent than SERMs
It is used in the treatment of hormone receptor–positive advanced breast cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fulvestrant is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It acts rapidly and is considered safer and more potent than SERMs

 

  • Fulvestrant is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Downregulator (SERD). Unlike SERMs (e.g., tamoxifen), it has pure antagonist activity with no agonist effects. 
  • It is administered intramuscularly once a month and is used in postmenopausal women with hormone receptor–positive advanced breast cancer, often after progression on SERMs or aromatase inhibitors.
  • However, fulvestrant does not act rapidly; its onset is relatively slow (full effects can take weeks to months), and it is not considered inherently safer or more potent than SERMs—it is simply used in a different clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is administered intramuscularly once a month: Correct. Standard dosing is monthly IM injection.

 

Option B. It acts as a selective estrogen receptor downregulator without agonist effects: Correct. Unlike tamoxifen, fulvestrant has no partial agonist action.

 

Option D. It is used in the treatment of hormone receptor–positive advanced breast cancer: Correct. Approved for ER+ advanced or metastatic breast cancer, especially in postmenopausal women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fulvestrant is a SERD used in hormone receptor–positive advanced breast cancer. 
  • It acts by degrading estrogen receptors without partial agonist effects. 
  • It is slower acting and not considered safer or more potent than SERMs like tamoxifen.

questions.text: A woman presents with a pruritic papulovesicular rash on the elbows and buttocks. She has a recent diagnosis of gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Direct immunofluorescence of a skin biopsy shows granular IgA deposition at the dermoepidermal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dermatitis herpetiformis

 

  • Pruritic papulovesicular rash on extensor surfaces (elbows, buttocks) is classic.
  • Association with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) is a hallmark feature.
  • Immunofluorescence shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae—highly characteristic.
  • These features are diagnostic of Dermatitis Herpetiformis, a chronic autoimmune blistering disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris:

 

  • Involves mucosa and skin.
  • Flaccid blisters, positive Nikolsky sign.
  • IgG antibodies against desmoglein 3 and 1.
  • Immunofluorescence shows intercellular IgG ("chicken wire" pattern), not granular IgA.

 

Option B. Bullous pemphigoid:

 

  • Tense bullae in the elderly, less itchy.
  • Immunofluorescence shows linear IgG and C3 along the basement membrane zone.
  • No association with celiac disease.

 

Option C. Psoriasis:

 

  • Chronic scaly plaques on extensor surfaces.
  • No vesicles or IgA deposition.
  • Not associated with celiac disease or pruritic vesicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is an autoimmune blistering disease associated with celiac disease, showing pruritic vesicular eruptions on extensor surfaces and granular IgA deposits in dermal papillae on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with type 2 diabetes presents with dyspnea and pitting pedal edema. CXR shows B/L pleural effusions. Thoracentesis removes 700 mL straw-colored fluid (LDH 77 units/L, protein 2.1 g/dL, cholesterol 35 mg/dL, glucose 100 mg/dL, pH 7.4, no WBCs/RBCs, unremarkable cytology). Serum LDH 187 units/L, protein 7.2 g/dL, glucose 110 mg/dL. What is the most likely cause of this effusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congestive heart failure

 

  • CHF causes transudative bilateral effusions.
  • Fluid analysis (low LDH/protein) confirms transudative etiology.
  • No WBCs or malignant cells rule out infection or cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumonia: Exudative with WBCs/fever.

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism: Small, unilateral effusions. Mostly exudative (bloody effusion).

 

Option D. Recurrence of lung cancer: Exudative with malignant cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHF causes transudative effusions.
  • Low LDH/protein confirms transudative fluid.
  • Thoracentesis can be done for persistent effusions.

choices.text: Nil per oral and IV fluids

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents with epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite for 3 days. He has been on a 10-day binge drinking. On examination, he has epigastric tenderness. Lab results:

 

 

What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nil per oral and IV fluids

 

  • Epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and elevated lipase (800 U/L) and amylase (1200 U/L) confirm acute pancreatitis, likely alcohol-induced.
  • Initial management includes bowel rest (NPO) to reduce pancreatic stimulation and IV fluids for hydration.
  • IV fluids are given initially to prevent hypovolemic shock.
  • Pain control and monitoring for complications (e.g., necrosis) are key.
  • Alcohol cessation prevents recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer octreotide: Not standard for acute pancreatitis.

 

Option B. Start IV antibiotics: Only for confirmed infective necrosis in pancreas, not routine.

 

Option C. IV fluids and start feeding: While IV fluids are correct, starting feeding is premature. The patient's symptoms (nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and significant epigastric pain) indicate that the pancreas is actively inflamed. Early feeding, especially with solid food, would stimulate the pancreas and worsen the condition. The transition to oral feeding is a gradual process, usually starting with a clear liquid diet once the patient is pain-free and has a return of appetite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute pancreatitis requires bowel rest and IV fluids.
  • Alcohol is a common etiology; cessation is critical.
  • Monitor for complications like necrosis.

questions.text: Which hypersensitivity mechanisms are evaluated by skin testing procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Types I and IV
