  • Allergen skin prick tests assess Type I (immediate) hypersensitivity. In this test, small amounts of allergen are introduced into the skin, where they cross-link preformed IgE bound to mast cells. This triggers rapid degranulation, releasing histamine and other mediators that produce a wheal-and-flare reaction within minutes.
  • Purified protein derivative (PPD) tests assess Type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity. Here, protein antigens (e.g., mycobacterial proteins) are injected intradermally and processed by local antigen-presenting cells. Th1 CD4⁺ T cells recognize these antigens, secrete IFN-γ, and recruit macrophages over 48–72 hours, causing induration and erythema.
  • Thus, skin testing simultaneously probes an immediate (Type I) and a delayed (Type IV) immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I only: Fails to account for the PPD reaction, which is T cell–mediated and delayed (Type IV).

 

Option B. Types I and II: Type II hypersensitivity involves antibody-mediated cytotoxicity (e.g., hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome), not evaluated by skin testing.

 

Option D. Types III and IV: Type III reactions involve immune complexes (e.g., Arthus reaction), which can be assessed by specific skin tests but are not routinely tested clinically with PPD or allergen prick tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skin testing can evaluate two distinct hypersensitivity mechanisms: immediate IgE-mediated (Type I) and delayed T cell–mediated (Type IV) responses. 
  • Neither Type II nor routine Type III reactions are assessed by standard allergy or PPD skin tests.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with painless hematuria and unintended weight loss. CT abdomen reveals a solid mass in the upper pole of the left kidney. Biopsy of the mass is given below. Which genetic mutation is most strongly associated with this malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VHL

 

  • The clinical features — hematuria, renal mass, and histology showing clear cytoplasm — are classic for clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC).
  • The tumor originates from the proximal tubular epithelial cells of the kidney.
  • VHL (Von Hippel–Lindau) tumor suppressor gene mutations on chromosome 3p are strongly associated with clear cell RCC.
  • VHL inactivation leads to increased levels of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF), which upregulates VEGF and PDGF, promoting angiogenesis and tumor growth.
  • These tumors may occur sporadically or as part of Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome, where bilateral renal cell carcinomas are seen along with hemangioblastomas and pheochromocytomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RB1: RB1 gene mutations are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, not with renal cell carcinoma.

 

Option B. APC: APC gene mutations are linked to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and colorectal carcinoma, not to RCC.

 

Option D. TP53: TP53 mutations are implicated in a wide range of malignancies, including Li-Fraumeni syndrome, breast carcinoma, and many solid tumors, but they are not specifically associated with clear cell RCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clear cell renal cell carcinoma arises from the proximal tubular epithelium and is strongly associated with VHL gene inactivation on chromosome 3p, leading to dysregulated angiogenesis.

choices.text: No inquest is required, as the death was caused by a natural illness.
A police inquest is required to investigate the cause of death.
A Magistrate must hold an inquest into the cause of death.
An inquest is not required, but the body should be forwarded for post mortem examination.

questions.text: A woman dies after 5 years of marriage due to tuberculosis, following prolonged hospital admission in Mumbai, India. There are no allegation of dowry or suspicious foul play from anyone. The attending physician is confused regarding who will be doing the inquest. Which of the following is the correct in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) No inquest is required, as the death was caused by a natural illness.

 

  • Under Section 194 BNSS, a police inquest is required only in cases of suicide, homicide, accidents, or deaths under suspicious circumstances. 
  • Section 196 BNSS mandates a Magistrate’s inquest for special cases like custodial deaths or suspicious deaths of women within 7 years of marriage.
  • In this case, the woman died from tuberculosis (a natural illness) after 5 years of marriage, with no suspicion or foul play. 
  • Since the death is natural and not suspicious, no inquest—police or magistrate—is required under either section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. A police inquest is required to investigate the cause of death: No police inquest is needed — the death was natural.

 

Option C. A Magistrate must hold an inquest into the cause of death: A Magistrate's inquest is only mandatory if the death is unnatural or suspicious (especially within 7 years of marriage). Not applicable here.

 

Option D. An inquest is not required, but the body should be forwarded for post mortem examination: A post-mortem isn’t mandatory unless there’s doubt about the cause of death. Since it's clearly natural, neither inquest nor post-mortem is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Natural deaths from known illnesses (e.g., tuberculosis) do not trigger police or magistrate inquests, nor mandatory post-mortems—these are reserved for unnatural or suspicious circumstances.

questions.text: A 30-year-old illiterate patient after sustaining injury to Right Upper Limb went for Native treatment, where she was given inappropriate tight bandaging. Now she has presented with severe pain with numbness of hand. On examination pulse felt to be feeble, stretch pain present. What can be the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Compartment syndrome

 

  • Compartment syndrome occurs when pressure within a closed fascial compartment (in this case, in the forearm) increases, compromising the blood supply and nerve function in the area. 
  • The classic signs and symptoms align perfectly with the patient's presentation:
    • Severe pain: The pain is often disproportionate to the injury.
    • Numbness (Paresthesia): Caused by nerve compression.
    • Feeble pulse: Indicates compromised arterial blood flow.
    • Stretch pain: Severe pain when the muscles in the compartment are stretched, which is a key diagnostic sign.
    • Tight bandaging: The application of a tight bandage is a common precipitating factor for compartment syndrome, as it restricts the expansion of the muscle compartment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both bone forearm fractures: 

 

  • While a forearm fracture may have been the initial injury, the described progression of symptoms—severe pain, numbness, feeble pulse, and stretch pain after tight bandaging—is not a direct diagnosis of the fracture itself but rather a complication of it. 
  • The diagnosis should reflect the current, life-threatening condition.

 

Option B. Crush syndrome: 

 

  • This is a systemic complication of muscle necrosis caused by severe crushing injuries. 
  • It involves the release of muscle breakdown products (e.g., myoglobin) into the bloodstream, which can lead to kidney failure and other systemic issues. 
  • While a severe injury could potentially lead to this, the immediate presentation with localized signs like numbness, feeble pulse, and stretch pain points more directly to a localized pressure issue.

 

Option D. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): 

 

  • DVT is a blood clot in a deep vein, typically in the legs. 
  • While it can cause pain and swelling, it does not typically present with the classic signs of compartment syndrome in the upper limb, such as stretch pain and a feeble pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to enable learners to identify and recognize the critical signs and symptoms of compartment syndrome, a surgical emergency. 
  • One should be able to correlate the classic triad of symptoms—disproportionate pain, paresthesia (numbness), and pain on passive stretching—with the patient's history and precipitating factors (like tight bandaging) to make an accurate and timely diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify the modality shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mammography

 

  • The image is a classic mediolateral oblique (MLO) view from a mammogram showing breast parenchyma and calcifications. 
  • Mammography is a specialized low-dose X-ray imaging technique for breast tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. X-ray Breast: Incorrect. This term is vague and not a standard diagnostic modality. Standard breast X-ray imaging is called mammography.

 

Option C. USG Breast: Incorrect. Ultrasonography shows the breast in grayscale soft tissue imaging, not the radiopaque appearance seen in this image.

 

Option D. CT Chest: Incorrect. CT of the chest includes the lungs and mediastinum, not a detailed view of the breast alone, and appears with axial slices, not this projection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mammography is the gold standard imaging modality for breast cancer screening and shows detailed internal architecture and calcifications in breast tissue.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, currently 16 weeks pregnant, visits the antenatal clinic for her routine second-trimester evaluation. Her obstetrician recommends maternal serum screening to assess the risk of fetal chromosomal anomalies and quadruple test is ordered. Which of the following analytes is not measured in this screening panel?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin B

 

  • The quadruple screen is a maternal blood test performed typically between 15–22 weeks gestation, most often around 16–18 weeks, to screen for fetal chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) and neural tube defects. 
  • It measures four biomarkers:
  1. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  2. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  3. Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  4. Inhibin A
  • Inhibin B is not part of the quadruple screen. 
  • While it is a hormone involved in gonadal feedback mechanisms and can be used in reproductive endocrinology, it has no role in prenatal screening protocols such as the quadruple test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. hCG: Correct component. Elevated in pregnancies affected by Down syndrome. Lowered in Trisomy 18.

 

Option C. AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein): Correct component. Produced by the fetal liver; elevated in open neural tube defects and decreased in some chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Unconjugated Estriol (E3): Correct component. A marker of fetal well-being and placental function; typically decreased in Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The quadruple screening test includes AFP, hCG, unconjugated estriol (E3), and inhibin A. 
  • Inhibin B is not part of this panel. 
  • This test is vital for assessing the risk of fetal aneuploidy during the second trimester.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has been associated with the adverse cardiac outcomes, including increased cardiac mortality?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rofecoxib

 

  • Rofecoxib, a selective COX-2 inhibitor, was withdrawn from the market due to its association with a significantly increased risk of myocardial infarction and stroke. 
  • The inhibition of prostacyclin (a vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation) without affecting thromboxane A2 (a vasoconstrictor and promoter of platelet aggregation) creates a pro-thrombotic state, leading to cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nicorandil: A nitrate-like drug used in angina; not associated with increased cardiac mortality.

 

Option C. Losartan: An angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) with cardiovascular protective effects.

 

Option D. Metoprolol: A β1-selective blocker that reduces mortality in heart failure and post-MI patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rofecoxib, a COX-2 inhibitor, was linked to increased cardiovascular risk and was withdrawn due to elevated rates of myocardial infarction and cardiac mortality.

choices.text: Promotes cell cycle progression from G1 to S phase
Acts as a transcription factor for epidermal growth factor signalling
Facilitates homologous recombination–mediated repair of DNA double-strand breaks
Stimulates vascular endothelial growth factor expression

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary function of the BRCA1 gene product?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facilitates homologous recombination–mediated repair of DNA double-strand breaks

 

  • BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes a protein involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks via homologous recombination.
  • Mutations in BRCA1 (and BRCA2) increase the risk of breast, ovarian, prostate, and pancreatic cancers because defective DNA repair leads to genomic instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promotes cell cycle progression from G1 to S phase: This role is associated with cyclins/CDKs, not BRCA1, which functions as a tumor suppressor, not an oncogene.

 

Option B. Acts as a transcription factor for epidermal growth factor signalling: Growth factor signaling is mediated by receptors like HER2/neu (ERBB2), not BRCA1.

 

Option D. Stimulates vascular endothelial growth factor expression: Angiogenesis is promoted by VEGF and HIF-1α, not BRCA1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene that repairs double-strand DNA breaks via homologous recombination. 
  • Loss of BRCA1 function predisposes to breast and ovarian cancers due to defective DNA repair.

questions.text: A man went for trekking on a high mountain. Which of the following primary acid–base abnormality is most likely to occur based on his physiological response to high altitude?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Respiratory alkalosis

 

  • At high altitude, the reduced atmospheric oxygen pressure lowers alveolar and arterial PO₂, leading to hypoxaemia. 
  • This is detected by peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies, which stimulate the respiratory centre to increase ventilation. 
  • The resulting hyperventilation causes excessive CO₂ washout, lowering PaCO₂ and shifting the bicarbonate buffer equilibrium toward a higher pH, producing acute respiratory alkalosis. 
  • If the exposure is prolonged over two to three days, the kidneys respond by excreting more bicarbonate, which partially normalizes the pH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: Would require primary ↓ HCO₃⁻ (e.g., diarrhoea, lactic acidosis); not the first change at altitude.

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: Seen with H⁺ loss or excess HCO₃⁻; opposite of what occurs initially.

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: Results from hypoventilation & CO₂ retention, not hyperventilation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • At high altitude, hypoxic stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors causes hyperventilation, leading to primary respiratory alkalosis (↓ PaCO₂, ↑ pH). 
  • With time, renal bicarbonate loss provides partial metabolic compensation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen after 4 days of cholecystectomy. On USG, it showed a significant collection of 200 cc in the RUQ. What will you do further?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) USG-guided aspiration of content

 

  • The patient presents with a post-cholecystectomy fluid collection, most likely a biloma or infected collection. 
  • The next best step is ultrasound-guided aspiration for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. 
  • It helps assess the nature of the fluid and may relieve symptoms.
  • After USG guided aspiration of content, insert pig tail catheter. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Re-explore laparoscopically: It is more invasive and reserved for peritonitis or failed conservative management.

 

Option B. Higher antibiotics: May be used adjunctively but not as a sole intervention.

 

Option C. MRCP: It is diagnostic but not immediately therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-cholecystectomy patients with localized fluid collection, USG-guided aspiration is the initial therapeutic and diagnostic step.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man arrives unconscious after being found near a spent-­shell casing. On exam, there is a 1 cm circular wound on his right chest. The margin is surrounded by a broad, sooty, blackened zone but no soot is found in the central defect. Which firing distance best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Close shot

 

  • In a close shot, the muzzle is held just slightly away from the skin (typically within about 1 ft), allowing hot gases and soot-laden powder to spray out in a broad halo around the entry wound.
  • These hot gases blacken and burn the skin over an area surrounding the defect—but without the tight gas seal required to drive soot or gas into the wound tract itself. 
  • Hence, you see a broad, sooty blackened zone encircling the 1 cm entry wound, with no soot deposited in the central defect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact shot: A contact shot yields a muzzle seal against the skin, forcefully driving gases and soot into the tissues. Externally, you’ll see a narrow soot ring confined exactly to the wound margin, often with muzzle imprint or concentric abrasion. You would not get a broad halo of blackening.

 

Option C. Intermediate range: At about 1–3 ft, the propellant gases have cooled too much to blacken the skin. What remains are unburned powder particles that embed as pinpoint abrasions (“stippling” or “tattooing”) around the wound—no soot or burning.

 

Option D. Distant shot: Beyond roughly 3 ft, both soot and powder particles disperse and never reach the target. An entry wound from a distant shot appears as a clean defect with no blackening, burning, or stippling on the surrounding skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  • Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible. 
  • Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent) 
  • Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: Study the viral replication cycle shown in the given image. Which virus is depicted?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Influenza A

 

  • Key features identifying Influenza A:
    • Segmented (–) sense RNA genome: Influenza possesses eight RNA segments that require nuclear import for transcription, unlike most other RNA viruses that replicate entirely in the cytoplasm.
    • Nuclear replication: The image shows viral RNA (vRNA) and mRNA synthesis within the host cell nucleus, a hallmark of Orthomyxoviruses.
    • Surface glycoproteins HA and NA: Influenza’s hemagglutinin (HA) mediates attachment and fusion, while neuraminidase (NA) cleaves sialic acid to facilitate viral release. These are unique to influenza among the listed respiratory viruses.
    • Budding from the plasma membrane: Mature influenza virions bud through the host cell membrane, acquiring their envelope studded with HA, NA, and M2 proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parainfluenza virus: A Paramyxovirus with a nonsegmented (–) sense RNA genome that replicates in the cytoplasm, not the nucleus. Its surface proteins include hemagglutinin–neuraminidase (HN) but lack separate NA and the segmented genome.

 

Option C. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV): Also a Paramyxovirus, RSV has a nonsegmented genome and fusion (F) proteins but no neuraminidase. It replicates in the cytoplasm and forms syncytia rather than budding via HA/NA.

 

Option D. SARS coronavirus: A positive-sense, nonsegmented RNA virus of the Coronaviridae family that replicates entirely in the cytoplasm and uses spike (S) proteins for entry, without HA/NA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orthomyxoviruses like Influenza A replicate their segmented (–) sense RNA within the nucleus and bud from the plasma membrane using distinct hemagglutinin and neuraminidase surface glycoproteins.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is diagnosed with C. difficile colitis after receiving levofloxacin post-surgery. He has had 2 prior episodes in the last 6 months; both treated with oral vancomycin. Which of the following agents can be added now to reduce recurrence risk?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bezlotoxumab

 

  • This patient has recurrent C. difficile infection (≥2 relapses within 6 months) despite standard therapy with oral vancomycin. 
  • In such patients, adding bezlotoxumab, a monoclonal antibody against C. difficile toxin B, reduces recurrence risk. 
  • It is given IV along with standard antibiotics and is particularly recommended in patients at high risk of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fidaxomicin: Effective for treatment of C. difficile (pseudomembranous colitis) and has a slightly lower recurrence rate compared to vancomycin, but this patient has already had multiple recurrences. Fidaxomicin could be considered as an alternative regimen, but the specific agent shown to reduce recurrence risk when added is bezlotoxumab.

 

Option B. IV ceftriaxone: Incorrect. This broad-spectrum antibiotic could actually predispose further to C. difficile by disrupting gut flora. It has no role in treatment or prevention of C. difficile.

 

Option D. Oral metronidazole: Used in mild initial episodes of C. difficile, but not recommended for recurrent cases (especially after vancomycin failures). Recurrent infections require stronger regimens (fidaxomicin, vancomycin taper, or adjunctive bezlotoxumab).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting C. difficile toxin B and is used adjunctively to reduce the risk of recurrence in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male had a tumor in the left lobe of his liver. A left hemi-hepatectomy was planned. Which of the following segments of the liver will be resected in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4

 

  • The liver is divided into 8 functional segments based on Couinaud’s classification. 
  • A left hemihepatectomy involves the removal of segments II, III, and IV (which form the functional left liver). 
  • Segment I (caudate lobe) is usually preserved unless specifically indicated.
  • This surgical procedure is performed for tumors localized to the left lobe and ensures oncologic clearance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1, 2 & 3: Segment 1 is the caudate lobe and is not routinely removed in left hemihepatectomy.

 

Option C. 5, 6, 7 & 8: These belong to the right lobe of the liver.

 

Option D. 2, 3, 4 & 5: Segment 5 is part of the right lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left hemihepatectomy includes resection of segments II, III, and IV, which correspond to the functional left liver, crucial for managing tumors in the left hepatic lobe.

questions.text: A 32-year-old gravida 3 para 2 woman presents at 34 weeks of gestation for routine evaluation. She has had two prior cesarean deliveries. Recent sonographic evaluation reveals findings highly suspicious for abnormal placental adherence with loss of the normal uteroplacental interface and placental lacunae. The invasive pathology is most likely associated with absence of which of the following histological barriers?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nitabuch’s layer

 

  • This patient presents with signs of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), a condition characterized by abnormal placental adherence to or invasion into the myometrium. 
  • It is commonly associated with prior uterine surgeries such as cesarean sections, particularly in the presence of placenta previa.
  • In a normal pregnancy, the Nitabuch’s layer, a fibrinoid layer within the decidua basalis, acts as a protective boundary that prevents chorionic villi from invading the myometrium. 
  • In placenta accreta spectrum disorders, this Nitabuch’s layer is absent, leading to direct attachment of placental villi to the myometrium (accreta), invasion into the myometrium (increta), or penetration through the uterine wall (percreta).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decidua basalis: While the decidua basalis is the maternal component of the placenta, its mere presence or absence is not the specific issue in PAS. The Nitabuch’s layer within the decidua basalis is the structural barrier that becomes deficient.

 

Option B. Trophoblastic shell: This structure helps in initial implantation and anchoring of the placenta but does not function as a barrier to prevent deep invasion into the uterus. It is not implicated in the pathogenesis of placenta accreta spectrum.

 

Option D. Chorionic villi: These are normal fetal structures that participate in nutrient exchange. In PAS, the problem is not the chorionic villi themselves, but the absence of the structural layer (Nitabuch’s layer) that limits their depth of invasion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absence of Nitabuch’s layer is the key pathological feature leading to abnormal placental invasion (placenta accreta spectrum), particularly in women with previous cesarean deliveries.

choices.text: Inferior surface of the right ventricle
Posterior part of the interventricular septum
Anterior wall of the left ventricle

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with chest pain and shortness of breath. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography confirms a right coronary artery (RCA) occlusion. Which of the following myocardial regions is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior part of the interventricular septum

 

  • The right coronary artery (RCA) supplies several important structures in the heart, including:
    • Inferior wall of the left ventricle
    • Posterior part of the interventricular septum (via the posterior descending artery, which typically arises from the RCA in a right-dominant circulation, the most common type)
    • Inferior part of the right ventricle
  • When the RCA is occluded, as in this clinical scenario (ST elevation in II, III, aVF), the posterior part of the interventricular septum is frequently involved. 
  • This area is critically affected due to its vascular supply from the posterior descending artery, which branches from the RCA in ~85% of individuals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior surface of the right ventricle: While the RCA does supply this area, it is less commonly the main contributor to infarction in ST-elevation MI compared to the posterior septum. Also, ECG signs and wall motion abnormalities point more strongly toward septal involvement.

 

Option B. Lateral part of the heart: This region is typically supplied by the left circumflex artery, not the RCA. It is not implicated in RCA-related infarcts.

 

Option D. Anterior wall of the left ventricle: This is supplied by the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. Infarction of this region would show ECG changes in precordial leads (V1–V4), not inferior leads.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In right-dominant coronary circulation (most common), occlusion of the right coronary artery can lead to infarction of the posterior part of the interventricular septum via its branch, the posterior descending artery.

questions.text:
Which statements correctly contrast egg‐laying patterns of hard vs. soft ticks? 

 

  1. Hard ticks lay eggs only once, in very large batches (hundreds–thousands).
  2. Soft ticks lay eggs in small batches (20–100) repeatedly over time.
  3. Hard ticks deposit eggs in multiple small batches throughout their life.
  4. Soft ticks deposit a single, massive egg batch and then die.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2

 

Statement 1. Hard ticks lay eggs only once, in very large batches (hundreds–thousands): True. Hard ticks lay a single, very large batch of eggs (hundreds to thousands) after engorgement.

 

Statement 2. Soft ticks lay eggs in small batches (20–100) repeatedly over time: True. Soft ticks lay smaller clutches of eggs (20–100) repeatedly over their lifespan.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. Hard ticks deposit eggs in multiple small batches throughout their life: False. Hard ticks do not lay multiple small batches; they oviposit once in one large batch.

 

Statement 4. Soft ticks deposit a single, massive egg batch and then die: False. Soft ticks do not lay a single massive batch; they deposit eggs in several small batches over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard Ticks vs. Soft Ticks:

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department with profuse vomiting, severe abdominal cramping, and profuse watery diarrhea. On examination, his breath has a faint garlicky odor. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 110 bpm. He reports working in a pesticide factory and thinks he may have ingested a small amount of a contaminant. A stool sample is noted to be dark greenish in color. Which of the following toxins is the most likely culprit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arsenic

 

  • Garlicky odor is seen in TOPA (Mnemonic)→ Thallium, organophosphate, phosphorus and arsenic  
  • Arsenic poisoning classically presents with acute gastrointestinal distress—severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and profuse diarrhea—often accompanied by a garlic-like odor on the breath.
  • In arsenic poisoning dark coloured diarrhea which later becomes rice watery
  • Arsenic reacts with sulfhydryl groups and, when reduced in the gut, can yield colored compounds that may impart a greenish or blackish hue to the stool. 
  • The hypotension and tachycardia further reflect arsenic’s profound fluid shifts and vasodilatory effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Organophosphate: In case of organophosphate cholinergic symptoms occur. These inhibit acetylcholinesterase, causing muscarinic signs (excessive salivation, bronchospasm, diarrhea) and nicotinic effects (muscle twitching), plus pinpoint pupils. They do not produce a garlic odor or dark-green stools.

 

Option C. Lead: Chronic lead toxicity features abdominal pain (“lead colic”), constipation, headache, and a bluish gingival line, with stools often dark or tarry from gastrointestinal bleeding. Lead does not cause vomiting with garlic odor or acute secretory diarrhea.

 

Option D. Iron overdose: Excess iron causes nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain early and, later, metabolic acidosis and hepatic injury. Black or dark-green stools from iron sulfide can occur, but there is no characteristic garlicky breath odor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of Poisoning Types:

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman complains of lifelong difficulty seeing in dim light but has perfect daytime vision. Examination shows numerous tiny white dots scattered throughout her mid-peripheral retina, as in the image below. Which inherited condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fundus albipunctatus

 

Fundus albipunctatus is a form of stationary congenital night blindness characterized by:

 

  • Numerous small, round, yellow-white dots in the mid-peripheral retina (“salt-and-pepper” appearance).
  • Congenital nyctalopia (night blindness from birth) with normal daytime (cone-mediated) vision.
  • Delayed rod dark adaptation on electroretinogram that improves after prolonged (>2–3 hours) dark adaptation.

 

This condition arises from autosomal recessive mutations in the RDH5 gene, which encodes 11-cis-retinol dehydrogenase in the visual cycle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinitis punctata albescens: Also features white retinal flecks but causes a progressive rod-cone dystrophy. There is no recovery of rod function with prolonged dark adaptation, and patients gradually lose both night and day vision.

 

 

Option C. Best disease (vitelliform macular dystrophy): Presents with a “egg-yolk” lesion in the macula, not widespread flecks. Central vision and color discrimination are affected early. EOG is the IOC and used to measure Arden ratio.

 

 

Option D. Stargardt macular dystrophy: Characterized by flecks at the posterior pole and a “beaten-bronze” macular appearance, leading to central vision loss in childhood or adolescence. It does not cause congenital night blindness.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with lifelong night blindness, normal daytime vision, and mid-peripheral retinal flecks, think fundus albipunctatus—verify with delayed-but-recoverable rod ERG and genetic testing for RDH5 mutations.

choices.text: Checking growth hormone after an oral glucose load

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 2-year history of increasing knee and shoulder stiffness and swelling in his hands and feet. His snoring got worsened as per his wife, and he has the following features on examination. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Measurement of serum IGF-1

 

  • Enlarged hands/feet, joint stiffness, snoring, and facial changes suggest acromegaly from growth hormone (GH) excess.
  • Serum IGF-1, reflecting long-term GH activity, is the best initial screening test due to GH’s pulsatile secretion.
  • Elevated IGF-1 prompts confirmatory glucose suppression testing.
  • Acromegaly may cause sleep apnea (snoring due to macroglossia), diabetes, or hypertension.
  • Facial features include frontal bossing, coarse facial features, prognathism, squaring of mandible, prominent zygoma, etc. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Checking growth hormone after an oral glucose load: Confirmatory, not initial test. Giving a glucose load decreases serum growth hormone levels to an undetectable range.

 

Option B. Fasting morning growth hormone level: Unreliable due to pulsatile GH secretion.

 

Option C. Glucagon stimulation test: Used for testing GH deficiency, not acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acromegaly is screened with serum IGF-1.
  • Features include enlarged extremities and snoring.
  • Confirm with glucose suppression if IGF-1 elevated.

choices.text: They survive longer than many waterborne pathogens
They are abundant in the human intestine
They require specialized, hard‑to‑obtain culture media
They are easily detected by simple culture methods

questions.text: A municipal laboratory assesses fecal contamination in drinking water. Which property least justifies using coliforms (especially E. coli) as the primary bacterial indicator?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They require specialized, hard‑to‑obtain culture media

 

  • Coliforms like E. coli are selected because they are common in fecal matter, persist longer than many pathogens in the environment, and can be reliably identified on standard, widely available media using straightforward acid‑and‑gas tests. 
  • The notion that they need rare or expensive culture systems is incorrect and does not support their role as practical indicators of fecal pollution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They survive longer than many waterborne pathogens: Survival advantage: Coliforms’ ability to endure environmental stresses longer than many pathogens makes them a conservative marker of past contamination.

 

Option B. They are abundant in the human intestine: Abundance. Their high concentration in human intestines ensures that even small fecal inputs yield detectable coliform counts.

 

Option D. They are easily detected by simple culture methods: Ease of detection. Routine laboratory media (e.g., Acid gas formation test) allow simple, low‑cost confirmation of coliform presence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coliforms are chosen as fecal indicators because they are widespread, resilient, and detectable with basic microbiological methods—not because they demand complex or rare media.

questions.text: A regional health administrator is reviewing the scope of work for Female Multipurpose Health Workers (F‑MPHWs) under India’s National Rural Health Mission. Which of the following activities is not typically assigned to F‑MPHWs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malaria surveillance

 

  • Female Multipurpose Health Workers (F‑MPHWs, also known as Auxiliary Nurse Midwives) focus primarily on maternal and child health, family planning, NIS, communicable diseases and non-communicable diseases, basic disease control at the village level, nutrition, MTP and Dai training
  • Their responsibilities include:
    • Providing antenatal/postnatal care and health education
    • Conducting routine immunization sessions
    • Distributing contraceptives (e.g., condoms) as part of family planning services
    • Supporting DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course) for tuberculosis under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme
  • They do not conduct malaria surveillance, which is handled by the Male Multipurpose Health Workers (M‑MPHWs) and specialized vector‑control teams under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Female Multipurpose Health Workers are responsible for immunization, family planning (including condom distribution), and DOTS support, but malaria surveillance is conducted by male health workers or dedicated vector‑control staff.

choices.text: Carotid artery; compressible structure best avoided for central access
Internal jugular vein; preferred site for central venous catheter placement
Subclavian vein; difficult to visualize above the clavicle
External jugular vein; not suitable for ultrasound-guided central line

questions.text: What is the most appropriate identification of the structure marked in the image and its clinical relevance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal jugular vein; preferred site for central venous catheter placement


The internal jugular vein (IJV) lies lateral and superficial to the carotid artery, is non-pulsatile and compressible, and is the preferred site for central venous catheterization due to its straight course and accessibility under ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carotid artery; compressible structure best avoided for central access: Carotid artery is deeper, pulsatile and non-compressible — it must be avoided to prevent arterial puncture.

 

Option C. Subclavian vein; difficult to visualize above the clavicle: Subclavian vein is not typically visualized in this transverse neck view, as it lies beneath the clavicle.

 

Option D. External jugular vein; not suitable for ultrasound-guided central line: External jugular is more superficial and variable; it is not the standard target for central venous access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under ultrasound, the internal jugular vein appears as a superficial, compressible, non-pulsatile structure lateral to the carotid artery, making it the ideal site for central venous catheter insertion.

questions.text: A district health officer reviews annual birth records and finds that, over the past year, there were 12,000 total births, of which 360 were stillbirths. What is the stillbirth rate in this district?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30

 

  • The stillbirth rate is calculated as the number of stillbirths divided by the total number of births (live births + stillbirths), multiplied by 1,000:
    • Total births = 12,000
    • Stillbirths = 360
    • Stillbirth rate = (360 / 12,000) × 1,000 = 30 per 1,000 total births

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine the stillbirth rate,

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios does not require head imaging prior to lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient with known epilepsy

 

  • Known epilepsy with typical seizures doesn’t require pre-LP imaging unless atypical features present.
  • Focal neurologic findings (e.g., weakness) suggest structural lesions, needing imaging.
  • New-onset seizures may indicate pathology (e.g., tumor), requiring imaging.
  • Papilledema indicates increased intracranial pressure, risking herniation without imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal neurologic findings: Imaging needed for possible lesions.

 

Option C. New-onset seizure: Requires imaging for underlying causes.

 

Option D. Papilledema: Mandates imaging to prevent herniation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Focal signs or new seizures require imaging.
  • Avoid LP in increased pressure without imaging.

questions.text: A laboratory technologist inoculates a specimen with an unknown Burkholderia species into guinea pigs and observes testicular swelling (Strauss reaction) within 3 days. The isolate is nonmotile and oxidase negative. Which Burkholderia species is most likely the culprit?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B. mallei

 

  • Burkholderia mallei is the causative agent of glanders, primarily infecting horses but also transmissible to humans. 
  • Key distinguishing features include:
    • Nonmotile: Unlike B. pseudomallei and B. cepacia, B. mallei lacks flagella.
    • Oxidase negative: Differentiates it from most other Burkholderia spp., which are oxidase positive.
    • Strauss reaction: Inoculation into guinea pigs produces testicular swelling within 2–4 days, a classic diagnostic sign for B. mallei.
  • These characteristics together confirm B. mallei as the organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B. pseudomallei: Motile and oxidase positive. Causes melioidosis, not glanders, and does not produce a Strauss reaction.

 

Option C. B. cepacia: Motile, oxidase positive, and primarily a pathogen in cystic fibrosis or ICU settings. No Strauss reaction.

 

Option D. B. thailandensis: Closely related to B. pseudomallei and oxidase positive, but generally nonpathogenic in humans and does not cause glanders or Strauss reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia mallei:

 

  • Nonmotile, oxidase negative gram-negative bacillus
  • Causes glanders; guinea-pig Strauss reaction (testicular swelling) is pathognomonic

questions.text: A 36-year-old man sustains a stab wound. Imaging confirms that the stab wound tracks just anterior to the T10 vertebral body. Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured as it traverses the diaphragm at this level?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Esophagus

 

  • The esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm at the level of T10. 
  • A stab wound just anterior to the T10 vertebral body would most likely injure this structure as it lies immediately anterior to the vertebra at this level. 
  • The esophageal hiatus also allows passage of the vagal trunks, but the esophagus remains the central and largest structure through this opening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: Incorrect. The aorta enters the abdomen through the aortic hiatus at the T12 level, posterior to the diaphragm.

 

Option B. Thoracic duct: Incorrect. It also traverses the aortic hiatus at T12, not T10.

 

Option D. Vagus nerve: Incorrect. Although the anterior and posterior vagal trunks pass through the esophageal hiatus with the esophagus, they are smaller structures and less likely to be directly injured in isolation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The esophagus traverses the diaphragm at the T10 level, making it the structure most likely to be injured in a stab wound just anterior to the T10 vertebral body.

questions.text: A 68‑year‑old man presents 1 hour after sudden onset right‑sided weakness and aphasia. Diffusion‑weighted MRI of the brain shows a focal area of markedly increased signal intensity in the left middle cerebral artery territory referred to as the “light‑bulb” sign. Which condition is this finding most characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperacute ischemic stroke

 

  • In hyperacute ischemic stroke (within minutes to a few hours of arterial occlusion), cytotoxic edema causes restricted diffusion of water, producing a very bright (“light‑bulb”) signal on diffusion‑weighted imaging (DWI). 
  • This change precedes alterations on other MRI sequences or CT and is highly specific for acute infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemorrhagic stroke: Would show blood products with variable signal intensity on diffusion-weighted imaging, often associated with susceptibility artifact on gradient-echo sequences, not a uniform bright “light bulb” restricted diffusion. NCCT hyper density will be seen

 

Option C. Vanishing bone disease: A skeletal disorder (Gorham’s disease) unrelated to intracranial DWI findings.

 

Option D. Marchiafava‑Bignami disease: Involves demyelination of the corpus callosum and may show diffusion abnormalities, but lesions are less focal and not described as “light‑bulb” brightness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected acute stroke presenting within the first few hours, obtain DWI MRI: a “light‑bulb” bright focus of restricted diffusion confirms hyperacute ischemia and guides urgent reperfusion therapy.

questions.text: A laboratory is comparing four new point‑of‑care devices (A–D) for measuring serum creatinine. The true serum creatinine concentration is 1.0 mg/dL. Each device is tested repeatedly under identical conditions, and the results are plotted on target diagrams A to D, as given below. If a perfect recalibration procedure could eliminate all systematic bias in each device (so their mean equals 1.0 mg/dL), which device would still fail to provide reliable, reproducible results?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Device D

 

  • Device D shows poor precision (large random scatter) as well as bias. 
  • Neither precise nor accurate; and even after recalibration (shifting its mean onto 1.0 mg/dL), its wide spread of readings means it cannot reliably reproduce the same measurement.
  • Precision—reflected by tight clustering—is essential for reproducibility, and Device D lacks it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Device A: High precision/reliable (tight cluster) and high accuracy/validity; recalibration isn’t needed—already reliable.

 

Option B. Device B: High precision but low accuracy (clustered away from the target); after recalibration (shifting its cluster onto 1.0 mg/dL), it becomes both accurate and precise.

 

Option C. Device C:  Accurate but not precise. After recalibration, its mean remains at 1.0 mg/dL and its moderate spread makes it acceptably reproducible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recalibration can correct systematic error (bias) but cannot reduce random error—devices with high scatter remain unreliable, even if their average reading is correct.

questions.text: Basiliximab is an immunosuppressive monoclonal antibody used in renal transplantation. Its action is mediated by antagonism against which of the following targets?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD25

 

  • Basiliximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to CD25, the alpha subunit of the IL-2 receptor on activated T cells. 
  • By blocking IL-2 from binding to its receptor, basiliximab prevents T-cell activation and proliferation, thus reducing the risk of transplant rejection.
  • It is used as part of induction therapy in organ transplantation, especially renal transplants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LFA1: Targeted by efalizumab (withdrawn), involved in adhesion; not the target of basiliximab.

 

Option C. TNF: Targeted by drugs like infliximab, etanercept, and adalimumab for autoimmune diseases; basiliximab does not affect TNF.

 

Option D. IL-2: Basiliximab does not bind directly to IL-2, but rather to its receptor (CD25), thereby preventing IL-2 signaling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basiliximab is an IL-2 receptor (CD25) antagonist that prevents T-cell proliferation, making it useful in preventing acute transplant rejection.

choices.text: Cover the content with a silo bag and shift to the NICU
Cover with saline soaked gauze and wait for it to self-resolve

questions.text: A neonate has intestines protruding from the abdomen without any external covering. What will be your immediate next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cover the content with silo bag and shift to the NICU

 

  • This describes gastroschisis—a congenital defect where intestines protrude without a covering sac. 
  • Initial management involves placing the exposed bowel in a silo bag to allow gradual reduction before definitive surgical repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. An Immediate surgical correction: Incorrect. Immediate surgical correction may not be feasible if the bowel is edematous or distended. Attempting this without stabilization increases risk of complications like abdominal compartment syndrome.

 

Option B. Conservative management with higher antibiotics: Incorrect. Antibiotics are supportive but not sufficient alone. The priority is protecting the bowel and managing fluid loss.

 

Option D. Cover with saline soaked gauze and wait for it to self-resolve: Incorrect. NS gauze can help temporarily, but it’s not as effective or protective as a silo bag. It also risks bowel injury or infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In gastroschisis, the first step is to protect bowel loops by covering them with a silo bag for staged reduction.

choices.text: Ligation of sphenopalatine artery via endoscopic approach

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes presents with severe epistaxis. Initial measures, including anterior and posterior nasal packing, have failed to control the bleeding. Endoscopic examination suggests the bleeding source is in the posterior nasal cavity. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery via endoscopic approach

 

  • In refractory posterior epistaxis, after failure of conservative measures (packing, cautery), the standard next step is endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (SPAL).
  • The sphenopalatine artery is the terminal branch of the maxillary artery and the main supply to the posterior nasal cavity.
  • Endoscopic ligation directly targets the bleeding source while minimizing morbidity compared to more proximal vessel ligations.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligation of anterior ethmoidal artery: Incorrect. The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery supplying the anterior-superior nasal septum and lateral wall. It is not the main source in posterior epistaxis.

 

Option B. Ligation of external carotid artery: Incorrect. Ligation of the external carotid is rarely performed now because it is more invasive and less targeted, with higher morbidity.

 

Option D. Ligation of facial artery: Incorrect. The facial artery supplies mainly the anterior part of the nasal cavity and external nose, not the posterior nasal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For refractory posterior epistaxis unresponsive to nasal packing, endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation is the treatment of choice, as it directly addresses the main posterior nasal blood supply.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding adult cardiac arrest and CPR? 

 

  1. Pulse check should be for no more than 10 seconds.
  2. High-quality chest compressions must achieve a depth of 5–6 cm.
  3. Bag-mask ventilation with room air is acceptable in early CPR.
  4. Chest compression to ventilation ratio is 15:2 in adults.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

Statement 1. Pulse check should be for no more than 10 seconds: True. Limit pulse check to 10 seconds.

 

Statement 2. High-quality chest compressions must achieve a depth of 5–6 cm: True. Depth should be 5–6 cm.

 

Statement 3. Bag-mask ventilation with room air is acceptable in early CPR: True. If oxygen unavailable, room air can be used.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Chest compression to ventilation ratio is 15:2 in adults: False. In adults, compression: ventilation = 30:2.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Adult CPR begins with checking pulse <10s, with 30:2 compression: ventilation ratio and compressions 5–6 cm deep.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to a pharmacy within 24 hours after an episode of unprotected sexual intercourse. She is not currently on any form of contraception and seeks an immediate intervention to prevent pregnancy. Which of the following is not recommended as a method of emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Danazol

 

  • Danazol is a synthetic androgen and is not used as a method of emergency contraception. 
  • It is primarily used in the treatment of endometriosis, fibrocystic breast disease, and hereditary angioedema due to its suppressive effect on gonadotropin secretion. 
  • Danazol lacks both the mechanism and approval to be used for post-coital pregnancy prevention. 
  • Therefore, among the listed options, Danazol is the only one not recommended for emergency contraception, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: This method, known as the Yuzpe regimen, involves using high-dose ethinyl estradiol + levonorgestrel and is an accepted emergency contraceptive method when used within 72 hours of intercourse.

 

Option C. CuT200 (Copper-T 200 IUD): Copper-containing intrauterine devices such as CuT 380A or 375 but can be CuT200 can be used for emergency contraception within 5 days post-coitus. Copper ions are spermicidal and prevent fertilization or implantation, making this method both highly effective and reversible.

 

Option D. RU486 (Mifepristone): Mifepristone is a progesterone receptor antagonist, and in low doses, it can prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation or implantation. It is used as an emergency contraceptive and is effective if taken within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Danazol is not used for emergency contraception. Emergency contraceptive methods include CuT IUD, combined estrogen-progestin pills, levonorgestrel-only pills, and mifepristone (RU486).

 

Note – LNG and Ulipristal, Yuzpe regime, IUDs – primarily used as emergency contraceptives.

questions.text: A 45-year-old gardener presents with nausea, vomiting, visual disturbances (yellow halos), and bradycardia two hours after chewing on an ornamental shrub leaf. His ECG shows peaked T waves and a bidirectional ventricular tachycardia. Which toxin is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oleandrin

 

  • Cardiac glycosides:
    • White oleander (oleandrin, Nerin)
    • Yellow oleander (Thevetin, Thevatoxin, Cerberin)
    • Cerebra odollum (Cerberin)
  • Oleandrin is the principal cardiac glycoside in Nerium odorum (white oleander). 
  • Like digoxin, it inhibits Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase in myocytes, causing hyperkalemia (peaked T waves), increased intracellular calcium (afterdepolarizations), and characteristic arrhythmias such as bidirectional VT. 
  • Visual disturbances (xanthopsia) are classic for cardiac glycoside toxicity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thevetoxin: Found in Cascabela thevetia, but the more abundant glycoside there is cerberin, and thevetoxin is less clinically described; presentation is identical, but naming convention favors cerberin.

 

 

Option C. Cerberin: The chief toxin of yellow oleander and Cerebra odollum; also causes digoxin‐like toxicity, but oleandrin is the more common culprit in white oleander exposures.

 

Option D. Neriumin: Not a recognized cardiac glycoside name (the true second glycoside in Nerium is nerin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oleandrin is the main cardiac glycoside of white oleander—presenting like digoxin overdose with hyperkalemia and bidirectional VT.

 

Additional Information:

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • There are two oleander plants: Nerium odorum and Cascabela Thevetia
  • Both are cardiac poisons
  • Both have digoxin like toxicity:
    • Heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse). 
    • Similar to digitalis.
    • Muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. 
  • Treatment of Both Oleander poisoning:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine 
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies for severe arrhythmias

choices.text: Estrogen and progesterone increase, FSH & LH decrease
Estrogen increases, progesterone decreases, FSH increases LH decrease
Estrogen decreases progesterone increases, FSH decreases & LH increases
Estrogen increases and progesterone decreases, LH & FSH decrease

questions.text: In a regular 28‑day menstrual cycle, which hormonal levels are typically observed between days 21 and 25?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estrogen and progesterone increase, FSH & LH decrease

 

  • Days 21–25 correspond to the mid‑ to late‑luteal phase. 
  • The corpus luteum actively secretes progesterone (peak around day ~21) and a moderate second rise of estrogen. 
  • These ovarian steroids exert negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary, so FSH and LH remain suppressed during this interval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrogen increases, progesterone decreases, FSH increases LH decrease: Progesterone does not decrease yet in the mid‑luteal phase; it is still high. Its fall occurs closer to the end of the luteal phase (around days 26–28) if no implantation occurs.

 

Option C. Estrogen decreases progesterone increases, FSH decreases & LH increases: LH does not increase in the luteal phase; it remains low after the ovulatory surge due to negative feedback from high progesterone/estrogen.

 

Option D. Estrogen increases and progesterone decreases, LH & FSH decrease: Again, progesterone is not decreasing between days 21–25; it is elevated. (FSH is low, but this partial truth doesn’t make the overall statement correct.)

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the mid‑luteal phase (days 21–25) of a 28‑day cycle, progesterone is high (with a moderate estrogen rise) from corpus luteum secretion, producing negative feedback that keeps FSH and LH low.

questions.text: A public health researcher is reviewing several epidemiological studies that investigate the link between a new industrial pollutant and increased rates of a rare cancer. To determine whether a causal relationship exists, the researcher evaluates various criteria used in epidemiology for causal inference. Which of the following is not considered a standard criterion for establishing causality?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensitivity of association

 

  • Causal inference in epidemiology is guided by a set of principles known as the Bradford Hill criteria, which are used to assess whether an observed association is likely to be causal rather than due to chance, bias, or confounding. 
  • These criteria include temporality, specificity, coherence, consistency, strength of association, bio plausibility, dose response and cessation
  • Sensitivity of association, however, is not one of these criteria. 
  • Sensitivity is a statistical measure used to assess the performance of diagnostic tests—it refers to a test’s ability to correctly identify those with a disease (true positives).
  •  It has no relevance in evaluating whether an exposure causes an outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strength of association: This refers to the magnitude of the relationship between exposure and outcome. A strong association (e.g., high relative risk or odds ratio) provides greater support for causality, as it is less likely to be explained by confounding or bias.

 

Option B. Consistency of association: If the same association is observed in different studies, populations, or settings, it reinforces the likelihood of a causal relationship, making it a key component of causal inference.

 

Option D. Coherence of association: Coherence means the observed association does not conflict with the known biology or natural history of the disease. A coherent finding fits within the broader framework of scientific understanding, which strengthens causal reasoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bradford Hill criteria, used to assess causality in epidemiological research, include strength, consistency, specificity, temporality, biological gradient, plausibility, coherence, experiment, and analogy — but do not include "sensitivity of association."

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman arrives at the emergency department with complaints of vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal pain. Her urine pregnancy test is positive, but transvaginal ultrasonography reveals an empty uterine cavity. A subsequent endometrial biopsy is performed, and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely histologic diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arias-Stella reaction

 

  • The Arias-Stella reaction is a benign, hormone-induced change in endometrial glandular epithelium, most commonly seen in the setting of ectopic pregnancy, molar pregnancy, or elevated β-hCG states.
  • Histologically, it is marked by:
    • Nuclear enlargement
    • Hyperchromasia
    • Cellular crowding and pseudostratification
    • Eosinophilic cytoplasm
    • Often occurs in a background of secretory endometrium
  • In this clinical scenario, a positive pregnancy test with no intrauterine pregnancy on ultrasound and the described biopsy findings strongly support the diagnosis of an Arias-Stella reaction, most likely in the setting of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decidual transformation: Incorrect. This refers to changes in the endometrial stroma, not glandular epithelium. Decidualized stromal cells appear large, polygonal, with eosinophilic cytoplasm, and are not associated with nuclear atypia or hyperchromasia like Arias-Stella reaction.

 

Option C. Chronic endometrial inflammation: Incorrect. Chronic endometrial inflammation (chronic endometritis) is characterized histologically by plasma cells in the endometrial stroma and sometimes lymphoid aggregates, not glandular nuclear atypia or eosinophilic cytoplasm.

 

Option D. Endometritis: Incorrect. Refers to acute inflammation of the endometrium and typically shows neutrophilic infiltration in the stroma and glands, often associated with infection, fever, and uterine tenderness — none of which are indicated here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Arias-Stella reaction is a non-neoplastic, hormone-induced endometrial change seen in the setting of high β-hCG levels, most notably in ectopic pregnancy. 
  • It is characterized by glandular nuclear atypia with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.

choices.text: Ischemic injury due to thrombosis of the splenic artery
Autodigestion of pancreatic tissue by activated enzymes
Direct bacterial invasion of pancreatic parenchyma

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, and repeated vomiting for the past 12 hours. He has a history of heavy alcohol use. On examination, he is hypotensive and febrile. Laboratory studies show:

  • Serum amylase: 1,250 U/L (normal: 30–110 U/L)
  • Serum lipase: 2,600 U/L (normal: 0–160 U/L)
  • Calcium: 7.2 mg/dL (normal: 8.5–10.5 mg/dL)

Despite resuscitation, he developed multi-organ failure and died within 48 hours. At autopsy, the gross specimen of pancreas is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of the tissue injury seen in this specimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autodigestion of pancreatic tissue by activated enzymes 

 

  • The gross image shows acute necrotizing pancreatitis, with diffuse stippled pale areas corresponding to fat necrosis and parenchymal destruction.
  • In acute necrotizing pancreatitis, premature activation of pancreatic proenzymes (especially trypsinogen to trypsin) within the pancreas triggers activation of other zymogens, including phospholipase A₂ and elastase.
  • Lipase → breaks down triglycerides in adipose tissue, releasing fatty acids. These bind calcium, forming chalky white calcium soaps (fat saponification) seen grossly.
  • Proteases → cause autodigestion and necrosis of pancreatic acinar cells.
  • The process results in parenchymal necrosis and extensive peripancreatic fat necrosis, as seen in the specimen.
  • Hypocalcemia occurs because calcium is sequestered in these fatty acid soaps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune-mediated destruction of acinar cells: Seen in autoimmune pancreatitis, not in acute necrotizing pancreatitis.

 

Option B. Ischemic injury due to thrombosis of the splenic artery: Can cause segmental pancreatic necrosis but would not produce diffuse fat saponification as seen here.

 

Option D. Direct bacterial invasion of pancreatic parenchyma: Usually a late complication of pancreatitis (infected necrosis), not the initial cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute necrotizing pancreatitis results from inappropriate intrapancreatic activation of digestive enzymes, leading to autodigestion of pancreatic parenchyma and peripancreatic fat. 
  • Grossly, this appears as pale, chalky foci of fat necrosis interspersed with hemorrhagic areas, and histologically, necrotic adipocytes with basophilic calcium deposits.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes for routine ophthalmologic screening. She is asymptomatic. Automated perimetry of the right eye is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early primary open-angle glaucoma

 

  • In primary open-angle glaucoma, initial visual-field loss often appears as a small arcuate scotoma adjacent to the nasal field that respects the horizontal midline. 
  • This defect arises from focal damage to the temporal retinal nerve-fiber layer. 
  • Elevated intraocular pressure in one eye with a corresponding nasal step on perimetry, in an otherwise asymptomatic patient, would be diagnostic for early glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Homonymous hemianopia: Homonymous defects respect the vertical meridian and affect both eyes in corresponding fields, not an isolated nasal step in one eye.

 

Option C. Optic neuritis: Optic neuritis typically produces central or diffuse scotomas and is accompanied by pain on eye movement and reduced visual acuity; it does not produce a horizontal-meridian–respecting nasal step.

 

 

Option D. Pituitary macroadenoma: Compression of the optic chiasm causes bitemporal hemianopic field loss, not a unilateral nasal step.

 

Heteronymous field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A sharply demarcated nasal step on perimetry in an eye with elevated IOP—but no other symptoms—strongly suggests early glaucomatous optic neuropathy, warranting prompt treatment to prevent progression.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug does not act at the presynaptic terminal, but exerts its effect directly on postsynaptic ion channels?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retigabine

 

  • Retigabine (Ezogabine) is unique among antiepileptic drugs because it acts postsynaptically by opening KCNQ (Kv7) potassium channels on the postsynaptic neuron.
  • This leads to membrane hyperpolarization, making it less excitable and reducing neuronal firing. 
  • It does not act presynaptically to alter neurotransmitter release.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tiagabine: Acts presynaptically by inhibiting GABA reuptake via the GAT-1 transporter, increasing synaptic GABA levels.

 

Option C. Gabapentin: Binds to the α2δ subunit of presynaptic voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels, inhibiting calcium influx and thus reducing excitatory neurotransmitter release.

 

Option D. Levetiracetam: Binds to SV2A, a presynaptic vesicular protein involved in neurotransmitter release, particularly glutamate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retigabine is a unique antiepileptic drug that acts on postsynaptic KCNQ potassium channels to hyperpolarize neurons, rather than modulating presynaptic neurotransmitter release.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about how health education and health propaganda shape individuals are correct? 

 

  1. Health education develops individuality and personality.
  2. Health education sets attitudes and directs behavior.
  3. Health propaganda sets attitudes and directs behavior.
  4. Health propaganda develops individuality and personal growth.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 3

 

Statement 1. Health education develops individuality and personality: Through self‑reliant learning and reflective behavior, health education empowers individuals to form their own values, critical thinking, and unique personal growth—fostering true individuality.

 

Statement 3. Health propaganda sets attitudes and directs behaviour: By appealing to emotion and employing passive information delivery, propaganda is designed to shape public attitudes and trigger reflexive actions, guiding people’s behavior in a predetermined direction.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement 2. Health education sets attitudes and directs behavior. False. Health education promotes reflective decision‑making rather than prescribing specific attitudes or actions.

 

Statement 4. Health propaganda develops individuality and personal growth. False. Propaganda discourages independent thought and personal development, focusing instead on uniform attitudes and behaviors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Health education builds individuality and encourages critical thinking, whereas health propaganda manipulates attitudes and enforces uniform behavior.

 

Health Education vs. Health Propaganda:

questions.text: Which of the following storage disorder is most consistent with the finding shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Niemann pick disease

 

  • The image shows foamy macrophages (arrows) with cytoplasm packed with lipid droplets.
  • This is characteristic of Niemann–Pick disease types A and B, which are caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency → accumulation of sphingomyelin in macrophages.
  • These lipid-laden macrophages are called foam cells and are found in liver, spleen, bone marrow, lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher’s disease: Incorrect. Gaucher cells have crumpled tissue paper cytoplasm due to glucocerebroside accumulation, not foamy cytoplasm.

 

Option C. Tay–Sachs disease: Incorrect. Shows ballooned neurons with GM2 ganglioside accumulation; no foam cells in reticuloendothelial system; also no hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Option D. Metachromatic leukodystrophy: Incorrect. Due to arylsulfatase A deficiency → sulfatide accumulation in myelin → demyelination. No foamy macrophages in systemic organs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Niemann–Pick disease —

 

  • Enzyme deficiency: Sphingomyelinase
  • Accumulated substrate: Sphingomyelin
  • Histology: Foamy macrophages (foam cells)
  • Clinical: Hepatosplenomegaly, neurodegeneration, cherry-red macula.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with long-standing permanent atrial fibrillation is evaluated for stroke prevention. She has a history of cerebral amyloid angiopathy and a large intracerebral hemorrhage in the past. What option should be considered?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Percutaneous left atrial appendage occlusion

 

  • AF increases stroke risk; ICH and amyloid angiopathy contraindicate anticoagulation.
  • LAA occlusion (e.g., Watchman) reduces stroke risk without anticoagulation.
  • Ideal for high bleeding risk patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Antiarrhythmic, not for stroke prevention.

 

Option B. Aspirin alone: Ineffective for high-risk AF.

 

Option C. Half-dose apixaban: High ICH risk remains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • LAA occlusion for AF with anticoagulation contraindications.
  • Aspirin insufficient for AF stroke prevention.
  • ICH history guides safer options.

questions.text: Which of the following fungi is notably challenging to grow in laboratory culture due to its specialized lipid requirements and slow, fastidious growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Malassezia furfur

 

  • Malassezia furfur is a lipophilic yeast that requires long-chain fatty acids (e.g., in olive oil–enriched media) for growth. 
  • Standard laboratory media lacking these lipids will fail to support its multiplication, making isolation and culture particularly difficult.
  • Colonies, when they do appear on specialized media, grow slowly and may take up to 2 weeks to become visible.
  • The colonies gives a fried egg appearance.
  • Malassezia furfur causes pityriasis versicolor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Grows readily on routine fungal media (e.g., Sabouraud dextrose agar) within 24–48 hours, forming characteristic creamy, budding yeast colonies.

 

Option B. Dermatophytes (e.g., Trichophyton spp.): While somewhat slower-growing than Candida, dermatophytes reliably grow on standard Sabouraud agar within 1–2 weeks without special lipid supplementation.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus neoformans: Grows well on routine SDA media, often within 48–72 hours, producing mucoid colonies. Its polysaccharide capsule can be visualized with India ink but does not impede culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malassezia furfur requires lipid‐enriched media and extended incubation for successful isolation, unlike more easily cultured yeasts such as Candida and Cryptococcus or dermatophytes.

choices.text: That 3.2 % of all collected fleas were Xenopsylla cheopis
An average of 3.2 X. cheopis fleas per rat
An average of 3.2 fleas per rodent burrow
That X. cheopis comprised 32 % of the total flea population

questions.text: In a plague outbreak investigation, field teams report a Cheopsis index of 3.2. What does this index value represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) An average of 3.2 X. cheopis fleas per rat

 

  • The Cheopsis index specifically quantifies the mean number of Xenopsylla cheopis fleas found on each captured rat. 
  • Threshold of Cheopsis = 1. If rate is >1 means high transmission risk  
  • A value of 3.2 means that, on average, each rat carried 3.2 individual X. cheopis—the primary vector for plague in India—indicating a high potential for transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. That 3.2 % of all collected fleas were Xenopsylla cheopis: This describes the specific percentage index (species’ proportion), not the Cheopsis index.

 

Option C. An average of 3.2 fleas per rodent burrow: This would be the burrow index, which measures average fleas per rodent burrow, not per rat.

 

Option D. That X. cheopis comprised 32 % of the total flea population: Misinterprets the absolute mean as a percentage of total fleas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Cheopsis index value reflects the average count of Xenopsylla cheopis on each rat; values > 1 warn of increased plague transmission risk due to abundant primary vectors.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation is admitted for evaluation of suspected preeclampsia. She reports excessive thirst, frequent urination, and has a past history of bipolar disorder treated with lithium (now discontinued). Her BP is 155/80 mmHg, and her physical exam, blood counts, and liver function tests are normal. Polyuria persists despite fluid restriction. A DDAVP challenge test is done. Lab findings:

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gestational diabetes insipidus

 

  • This woman is in her third trimester and presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and a markedly dilute urine despite fluid restriction.
  • Her urine osmolality remains low with water deprivation but shows a dramatic increase after DDAVP, indicating intact renal response to ADH.
  • In gestational diabetes insipidus, placental vasopressinase degrades endogenous vasopressin (ADH), especially in the third trimester, leading to transient central DI.
  • The normalization of urine osmolality and reduction in volume after DDAVP confirms vasopressin deficiency, not resistance.
  • Although she has a past history of lithium use, the current pregnancy context and full DDAVP response are classic for gestational DI, not nephrogenic or primary central DI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central diabetes insipidus: Presents similarly but is typically non-transient and unrelated to pregnancy. Gestational DI is more likely here.

 

Option C. Primary polydipsia: Would show improvement in urine osmolality with water restriction, which is absent here.

 

Option D. Preeclampsia: May coexist, but does not cause polyuria or dilute urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gestational DI is due to vasopressinase from the placenta degrading ADH, leading to transient central DI.
  • DDAVP (resistant to vasopressinase) corrects the urine concentrating defect.
  • Suspect gestational DI in pregnant women in third trimester with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality.

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the clinic for developmental assessment. On examination he has a prominent epicanthal fold, a single transverse palmar crease, hypotonia, and intellectual disability. Facial features appear flat with upslanting palpebral fissures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Down syndrome

 

  • Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is the most common chromosomal disorder and is characterized by a nondisjunction leading to an extra chromosome 21. 
  • Classic clinical features include:
    • Upslanting palpebral fissures
    • Epicanthal folds
    • Flat facial profile
    • Single transverse palmar crease (Simian crease)
    • Generalized hypotonia
    • Intellectual disability
    • Congenital heart defects (especially atrioventricular septal defects)
    • Duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease
    • Increased risk of leukemia (especially ALL and AML) and early-onset Alzheimer’s
  • The constellation of findings in the question strongly supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Patau syndrome: 

 

  • Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) is presents with holoprosencephaly, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, microphthalmia, scalp defects (cutis aplasia), and severe developmental delay.
  • Facial features are not flat and the hallmark signs of Down syndrome are absent.

 

Option C. Edward syndrome:

 

  • Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18) is characterized by micrognathia, low-set ears, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, and severe intellectual disability.
  • Palmar creases and facial features differ from those seen in Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Fragile X syndrome:

 

  • X-linked disorder caused by CGG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene.
  • Presents with macroorchidism, long face with large ears, high-arched palate, and behavioral problems like autism.
  • Palmar crease and facial features described here do not match Fragile X.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is characterized by hypotonia, a single palmar crease, epicanthal folds, and upslanting palpebral fissures along with intellectual disability and other congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent night sweats, vaginal dryness, and a recent history of two low-impact vertebral fractures. She is not on any hormone therapy. Her menstrual periods ceased 2 years ago. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism responsible for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased estrogen production

 

  • This patient presents with classic features of hypo-estrogenism post-menopause, including:
    • Vaginal dryness (due to atrophy of vaginal epithelium)
    • Vasomotor symptoms such as hot flushes and night sweats
    • Osteoporosis, evidenced by low-impact fractures
    • Increased cardiovascular risk (though not directly seen here, it's a known long-term consequence)
  • All of these are consequences of reduced ovarian estrogen production after menopause. Estrogen plays critical roles in thermoregulation, maintaining bone mineral density, and vascular health.

 

Other Options:
