Option A. Elevated serum androgens: Incorrect. Elevated androgens are more often associated with conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), not the hypo-estrogenic state typical of postmenopause.

 

Option C. Hyperprolactinemia: Incorrect. While hyperprolactinemia can cause amenorrhea, it is not associated with vasomotor symptoms, osteoporosis, or increased cardiovascular risk.

 

Option D. Increased progesterone activity: Incorrect. Progesterone levels also decline after menopause and are not the primary driver of these symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estrogen deficiency following menopause leads to vasomotor symptoms, vaginal dryness, osteoporosis, and increased cardiovascular risk- key clinical markers of a hypo-estrogenic state.

choices.text: Increase olanzapine dose gradually and monitor response

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with schizophrenia has had persistent delusions and hallucinations for 2 years. He was previously on haloperidol at maximum tolerated doses without significant improvement. He is currently on olanzapine 5 mg/day for the last 6 weeks, but remains symptomatic. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase olanzapine dose gradually and monitor response

 

  • The patient has been on olanzapine 5 mg/day for 6 weeks, which is considered a subtherapeutic dose for schizophrenia. 
  • Before labeling the patient as having treatment-resistant schizophrenia, it is necessary to ensure an adequate trial of the current antipsychotic. 
  • This includes using a therapeutic dose for an adequate duration (usually ≥6 weeks). 
  • The next appropriate step is to titrate olanzapine to at least 10 mg/day and monitor for clinical improvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Switch to risperidone: Not indicated yet, since the patient has not had an adequate trial of olanzapine at therapeutic doses.
 

Option C. Add valproate as adjunctive therapy: Valproate is not indicated for persistent positive symptoms of schizophrenia unless there is a comorbid mood or aggression issue.
 

Option D. Initiate clozapine therapy: Clozapine is reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, defined as failure of at least two adequate trials of antipsychotics at therapeutic doses. Since olanzapine was used at a subtherapeutic dose, TRS criteria are not yet met.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Before diagnosing treatment-resistant schizophrenia, ensure the patient has had at least two adequate trials of antipsychotics at therapeutic doses and durations. 
  • Olanzapine should be titrated to an appropriate dose (typically 10–20 mg/day) and assessed for response before considering a switch or clozapine initiation.

choices.text: Short half-life with high fibrin specificity
Immunogenic protein structure derived from bacterial sources
Prodrug that must be converted by hepatic enzymes

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction is given Reteplase as two intravenous bolus doses. What pharmacologic feature of this drug allows for bolus-only delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extended half-life 

 

  • Reteplase is a modified recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) engineered by deleting specific fibrin-binding domains. 
  • This modification reduces its fibrin affinity but significantly prolongs its plasma half-life, allowing for bolus administration rather than a continuous infusion, as required with alteplase. 
  • This makes it more practical in emergency or prehospital settings, particularly where rapid administration is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short half-life with high fibrin specificity: Describes alteplase (tPA), which requires intravenous infusion due to rapid clearance.

 

Option B. Immunogenic protein structure derived from bacterial sources: Applies to streptokinase, which can cause allergic reactions due to its streptococcal origin.

 

Option D. Prodrug that must be converted by hepatic enzymes: Incorrect. Reteplase is active upon administration and does not rely on hepatic metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reteplase is a genetically modified tPA analog with an extended half-life that allows for bolus-only dosing in acute myocardial infarction, improving ease of administration in emergency settings.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of amenorrhea, occasional breast tenderness, milky discharge from both breasts. She takes over the counter medications for dyspepsia but otherwise has no significant past history. UPT is negative. What is the most likely source of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medication related

 

  • Amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and breast tenderness suggest hyperprolactinemia, driven by elevated prolactin levels.
  • Dyspepsia medications like metoclopramide or domperidone, dopamine antagonists, increase prolactin by blocking inhibition.
  • This causes galactorrhea, amenorrhea (via gonadotropin suppression), and mild headaches.
  • No visual defects or severe headaches reduce pituitary mass likelihood.
  • Negative pregnancy test rules out pregnancy-related causes.
  • Medication-induced hyperprolactinemia is reversible by stopping the offending drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal hyperplasia: Leads to cortisol or androgen excess, not galactorrhea or amenorrhea.

 

Option B. Ovarian tumor: Disrupts menses but rarely elevates prolactin for galactorrhea.

 

Option C. Pituitary mass: Can cause similar symptoms but one have to rule out secondary causes of hyper-prolactinemia first (and pituitary tumours often have visual field defects).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dopamine antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide) cause hyperprolactinemia.
  • Hyperprolactinemia presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea.
  • Check medication history before pituitary evaluation.

questions.text: A follow-up patient of long-standing GERD on endoscopy was found to have a nodule in the 2nd part of the duodenum. Which hormone are you suspecting to be raised?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastrin

 

  • A duodenal nodule in a patient with GERD raises suspicion of a gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), especially in the 2nd part of the duodenum—a classic location. 
  • Gastrin-producing  tumors increase gastric acid secretion, which worsens GERD and causes ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin: Suggestive of insulinoma, presents with hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. VIP: Seen in VIPoma, presents with watery diarrhea.

 

Option D. Glucagon: Seen in glucagonoma, presents with necrolytic migratory erythema and hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A duodenal mass in a patient with GERD should raise suspicion of gastrinoma, associated with elevated gastrin levels and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with enuresis. The parents mention the child had a fall from the bed once but has no other significant medical history. There are no signs of urinary tract infection or neurological deficits. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Behavioral modification

 

  • Behavioral modification is the first-line approach in managing primary monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis (PMNE), especially when the child has no underlying neurological or urological pathology.
  • Behavioral techniques include:
    • Positive reinforcement (praise for dry nights)
    • Alarm therapy
    • Timed voiding before sleep
    • Limiting fluid intake in the evening
    • These interventions are non-invasive, cost-effective, and address the behavioral root of the issue in many cases.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Start anticholinergic drugs: Anticholinergics are not first-line for uncomplicated PMNE. They are used in children with daytime symptoms or detrusor overactivity, not in a child with no neurological or voiding issues.

 

Option C. Prescribe oxybutynin: Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic agent, primarily indicated for urge incontinence or overactive bladder, not primary bedwetting in an otherwise healthy child.

 

Option D. Start desmopressin therapy: Desmopressin, a synthetic analog of vasopressin, is effective in reducing nighttime urine production and is used when behavioral modifications fail or in cases requiring short-term control (e.g., sleepovers). However, it is not first-line therapy due to the risk of hyponatremia and relapse after discontinuation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Behavioral therapy is the initial and preferred management for monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis in children without signs of neurological or urinary tract pathology.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with multiple episodes of abdominal pain and a history of passing blood in stools. On examination, he has dark pigmented spots on his lips and oral mucosa. Endoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome

 

  • Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by:
  • Hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract, especially the small intestine.
  • Mucocutaneous pigmentation, most prominently around the lips, oral mucosa, and fingers.
  • Symptoms like abdominal pain, GI bleeding, and intussusception.
  • It is associated with mutation in the STK11 (LKB1) tumor suppressor gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Familial Adenomatous Polyposis:

 

  • Involves hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps, especially in the colon.
  • Associated with mutations in the APC gene.
  • Mucocutaneous pigmentation is not a feature.
  • The polyps are adenomatous, not hamartomatous.

 

Option C. Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome:

 

  • Presents in childhood with multiple hamartomatous polyps, mainly in the colon and rectum.
  • Lacks the pigmented mucocutaneous lesions.
  • May present with anemia, bleeding, or intussusception.

 

Option D. Cronkhite-Canada Syndrome:

 

  • A non-inherited disorder occurring in adults.
  • Presents with diarrhea, weight loss, alopecia, and nail changes.
  • Also has hamartomatous polyps, but no mucocutaneous pigmentation and occurs later in life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome is identified by the presence of mucocutaneous pigmentation and hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine, often in adolescents with GI symptoms and STK11 gene mutation.

choices.text: Quantify urine albumin to creatinine ratio

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension is admitted to the ICU for septic shock secondary to streptococcus bacteremia, managed with IV antibiotics and vasopressors. Laboratory results show Hb 9 g/dL, WBC 12,000/µL, platelets 100,000/µL, AKI with creatinine 1.7 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL), Urinalysis finding is shown below and urine protein to creatinine ratio of 1700 mg/g. What is the best course of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue supportive measures

 

  • Septic shock with AKI, oliguria, and muddy brown casts indicate acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from sepsis and hypoperfusion.
  • Proteinuria (1700 mg/g) is non-specific and not of much value in the setting of AKI. In this case, it is likely to be tubular (not glomerular). 
  • Supportive care (fluids, sepsis treatment) is key, as ATN often resolves with underlying cause correction.
  • Avoid nephrotoxic agents and monitor renal function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quantify urine albumin to creatinine ratio: Indicated if there is suspicion of glomerular injury, not indicated with ATN. 

 

Option B. Renal biopsy: Unnecessary with a clear etiology for AKI. 

 

Option C. Empiric treatment with IV steroids: No role without autoimmune evidence or refractory septic shock. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Muddy brown casts and proteinuria indicate ATN in sepsis.
  • Supportive care is primary for AKI management.
  • Avoid invasive tests when etiology is clear.

choices.text: A biphasic reaction may occur 8 to 72 hours after anaphylaxis
Penicillin allergy is more common in patients with history of allergic reactions
Observation for 6 to 12 hours is appropriate for urticaria
Patients should be prescribed epinephrine autoinjectors on discharge

questions.text: 23-year-old man with a known peanut allergy presents to the ED after accidental exposure at a restaurant. He has urticaria over the chest and upper back, but no dyspnea, throat tightness, or facial swelling. Vitals are stable. He reports having had similar reactions in the past. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Penicillin allergy is more common in patients with history of allergic reactions

 

  • Anaphylaxis and allergic reactions can recur in a biphasic manner, typically within 8–72 hours after the initial reaction — so statement A is true.
  • Patients with anaphylaxis or urticaria should be observed for at least 6–12 hours, especially if there's a history of severe reaction — statement C is true.
  • Epinephrine autoinjectors are appropriate for all patients with a history of IgE-mediated food allergy, even if the current reaction is mild — statement D is true.
  • Penicillin allergy is not necessarily more common in patients with other allergic reactions. While atopy (e.g., eczema, allergic rhinitis) is associated with increased general allergic tendencies, penicillin allergy is independent and may be overreported — so statement B is false.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A biphasic reaction may occur 8 to 72 hours after anaphylaxis: These are well-documented and can occur hours after the initial resolution of symptoms, especially in anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. Observation for 6 to 12 hours is appropriate for urticaria: Appropriate for moderate allergic reactions, even if airway or cardiovascular compromise is absent.

 

Option D. Patients should be prescribed epinephrine autoinjectors on discharge: Recommended for all patients with IgE-mediated food allergy, regardless of severity of current episode. Delay in epinephrine injection increases the risk of death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Penicillin allergy is often overreported and not more common solely due to a general allergic history.
  • Biphasic reactions may occur up to 72 hours after initial symptoms, especially in anaphylaxis.
  • Patients with any IgE-mediated food allergy should be prescribed epinephrine autoinjectors even if their current episode is mild.

questions.text: A 37-year old male presents after a traumatic knee dislocation. On neurological examination, there is sensory loss over most of the dorsum of the foot, except the first web space, and dorsiflexion is preserved. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superficial peroneal nerve

 

  • The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot except the first web space, which is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve. 
  • Because dorsiflexion (a motor function of the deep peroneal nerve) is preserved, the motor component is intact, pointing to isolated superficial peroneal nerve involvement, typically affected in trauma near the fibular neck or with stretch injuries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deep peroneal nerve: Incorrect. Damage would result in loss of dorsiflexion and sensory loss in the first web space. This is not consistent with preserved dorsiflexion and spared first web space.

 

Option B. Common peroneal nerve: Incorrect. Injury would cause loss of both superficial and deep peroneal functions, leading to foot drop and widespread sensory loss on the dorsum. Here, dorsiflexion is preserved.

 

Option C. Saphenous nerve: Incorrect. It is a purely sensory branch of the femoral nerve and provides sensation to the medial leg, not the dorsum of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the superficial peroneal nerve causes sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot except the first web space, with preserved dorsiflexion, distinguishing it from deep or common peroneal nerve injury.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to a reproductive endocrinology clinic due to primary infertility. He and his partner have been unable to conceive after 12 months of unprotected intercourse. His partner’s gynecologic evaluation, including hysterosalpingography, is unremarkable. Semen analysis reveals azoospermia. The next step involves distinguishing between a testicular and an obstructive etiology. Which of the following tests would be most useful to determine the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Testicular biopsy

 

  • A testicular biopsy is the most definitive method to distinguish between obstructive and non-obstructive (testicular) causes of azoospermia. 
  • If spermatogenesis is found to be normal on biopsy, an obstructive pathology (e.g., congenital absence of the vas deferens, ejaculatory duct obstruction) is more likely. 
  • If the biopsy reveals absent or defective spermatogenesis, the etiology is testicular failure (non-obstructive azoospermia).
  • While hormone assays such as FSH and testosterone can provide indirect information, they cannot conclusively establish the cause. Biopsy offers direct histological evidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum testosterone levels: Incorrect. While testosterone reflects Leydig cell function, it is not diagnostic of the type of azoospermia. Testosterone may be normal in both obstructive and non-obstructive causes.

 

Option C. Serum FSH levels: Incorrect. Elevated FSH levels suggest testicular damage, but normal levels do not rule out a testicular cause. Thus, FSH is a useful screening tool but not definitive for diagnosis.

 

Option D. Serum LH levels: Incorrect. LH primarily reflects Leydig cell stimulation and has a limited role in distinguishing obstructive from testicular azoospermia. It is more useful in evaluating hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Testicular biopsy is the most definitive test to distinguish obstructive from testicular causes of azoospermia when semen analysis confirms absence of sperm. 
  • Hormonal tests may support the evaluation but cannot replace histological confirmation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old executive had an insidious onset right knee pain. On examination there was severe tenderness over the right knee. No gross swelling. X-ray showed the following finding. Diagnosis please.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteogenic Sarcoma

 

  • This is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. 
  • It typically presents in adolescents and young adults (10-25 years old), with a peak incidence in the second decade of life. 
  • The most common location is the metaphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • The clinical presentation of insidious onset pain, swelling, and tenderness in this age group is classic. 
  • X-rays typically show an aggressive lesion with a mixed lytic (bone-destroying) and sclerotic (bone-forming) pattern, ill-defined margins, and classic signs of periosteal reaction like "Codman's triangle" or a "sunburst" appearance. 
  • This diagnosis perfectly fits the patient's age and symptoms, and the X-ray findings must have been indicative of this aggressive tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myositis Ossificans: 

 

  • This is a benign condition characterized by the formation of bone tissue within muscle or other soft tissue, usually following a trauma. 
  • On X-ray, it typically shows a characteristic "zonal" pattern of calcification with a dense, well-defined periphery and a less dense center. 
  • While it can cause pain and a mass, the insidious onset without a clear traumatic event and the characteristic radiographic findings of an aggressive tumor (as implied by the correct answer) make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option C. Ewing's Sarcoma:

 

  • This is another highly malignant bone tumor of childhood and early adulthood (typically 5-20 years). 
  • While it can also occur in the knee region and cause similar symptoms, its classic presentation is an "onion-skin" periosteal reaction on X-ray and a preference for the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones. 
  • The patient's age range slightly overlaps, but the specific radiographic findings implied by the correct answer point more strongly to osteosarcoma.

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumor): 

 

  • This is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor that typically affects young adults (20-40 years old). 
  • It characteristically presents as an eccentric, lytic lesion in the epiphysis (end of the bone), extending to the articular surface. On X-ray, it often has a "soap-bubble" appearance. 
  • While the age and location (around the knee) are a good fit, the specific radiographic features (lytic, epiphyseal location) differ from the aggressive, mixed-pattern, metaphyseal lesion typical of osteosarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The learner should be able to differentiate common bone tumors in young adults by integrating clinical presentation (age, onset, location of pain) with characteristic radiographic findings to arrive at the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male with a long-standing history of untreated sexually transmitted infection reports progressive difficulty with balance and sharp shooting pain in his legs. Neurologic examination shows a wide-based gait, reduced joint position sensation, absent lower limb reflexes, and preserved muscle strength. Which of the following spinal cord structures is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dorsal columns and dorsal roots

 

  • This patient exhibits classic signs of tabes dorsalis, a form of tertiary neurosyphilis that involves the dorsal columns and dorsal roots. The symptoms:
    • Wide-based gait and proprioception loss reflect dorsal column involvement.
    • Lightning-like leg pain and absent deep tendon reflexes are due to dorsal root degeneration.
    • Preserved motor strength confirms sparing of motor tracts.
  • This degeneration disrupts fine touch, vibration, and proprioceptive sensation, especially in the lower limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventral spinocerebellar tract: Involved in unconscious proprioception but not classically affected in neurosyphilis. Lesions here wouldn't explain the absent reflexes or stabbing pain.

 

Option B. Lateral corticospinal tract: Carries motor fibers. Damage would cause weakness, spasticity, and increased reflexes—opposite to findings here.

 

Option D. Nucleus proprius: Located in the dorsal horn and involved in processing pain and temperature. While it relays sensory info, its damage doesn’t produce the specific proprioceptive deficits and reflex loss seen in tabes dorsalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tabes dorsalis, seen in late untreated syphilis, primarily affects the dorsal columns and dorsal roots, leading to sensory ataxia, stabbing leg pain, and areflexia without motor weakness.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with an intensely pruritic, boggy, erythematous plaque on his scalp. The lesion exudes pus, and several hairs break off at the skin surface. KOH prep of plucked hairs shows arthroconidia around the hair shaft. Which clinical variant of tinea capitis does this most likely represent, and which organism is the usual culprit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kerion; Trichophyton verrucosum

 

  • Kerion is an inflammatory, boggy form of tinea capitis characterized by tender, pustular plaques and hair loss.

 

 

  • It often results from a robust host immune response to zoophilic dermatophytes, especially T. verrucosum (from cattle).
  • Arthroconidia and hyphae invade the deeper dermis, provoking intense inflammation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Favus; Microsporum audouinii: Produces yellow “scutula” crusts with minimal inflammation, not boggy plaques.

 

 

Option C. Ectothrix; Trichophyton tonsurans: Arthroconidia form on hair surface—less inflammatory, more patchy scaling.

 

Option D. Endothrix; Microsporum canis: Arthroconidia fill the hair shaft—typically noninflammatory alopecia (“black dot”) rather than kerion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammatory scalp lesions (kerion) with boggy plaques and pustules in tinea capitis are most often caused by zoophilic species like T. verrucosum.

 

Remember: Kerion = painful, purulent scalp mass in kids; key pathogen = zoophilic T. verrucosum.

choices.text: Increase the dose of omeprazole to 40 mg daily
Encourage the patient not to miss any doses of omeprazole

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of diabetes, hypertension, obesity, tobacco use, and GERD presents with a new onset of dysphagia, describing a sensation of solid food getting stuck in the mid-chest. He has been taking omeprazole 20 mg daily for 3 years, with occasional missed doses. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Do an EGD

 

  • This patient has new-onset solid food dysphagia, a red flag symptom that requires prompt evaluation for esophageal structural or malignant lesions.
  • His risk factors (age >50, tobacco use, obesity, chronic GERD) increase the concern for Barrett’s esophagus or esophageal cancer.
  • The appropriate next step is esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD), which allows direct visualization and biopsy if needed.
  • Empiric acid suppression (omeprazole adjustments) is not sufficient when alarm symptoms like dysphagia are present.
  • Barium swallow may be useful in evaluating structural abnormalities or motility issues but is not first-line when endoscopy is accessible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of omeprazole to 40 mg daily: Not appropriate as first step in a patient with new solid food dysphagia, which may indicate a structural lesion.

 

Option C. Do a barium swallow: Less sensitive than EGD and not preferred as the initial diagnostic test when endoscopy is available.

 

Option D. Encourage the patient not to miss any doses of omeprazole: Good long-term GERD strategy, but not appropriate in the setting of new-onset dysphagia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • New-onset dysphagia, especially to solids, requires prompt endoscopic evaluation.
  • EGD is the first-line test for assessing esophageal structural abnormalities and malignancy.
  • Acid suppression should not delay investigation when alarm symptoms like dysphagia are present.

questions.text: A team of researchers is designing a case-control study to evaluate the association between long-term exposure to air pollution and the risk of developing chronic bronchitis. To minimize the influence of differences in age and smoking status between cases and controls, they decide to use matching. Here, the matching is done for removal of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Known confounding

 

  • Matching is a technique used during the design phase of observational studies — especially case-control studies — to ensure that the distribution of known confounding variables is balanced between the case and control groups. 
  • This helps reduce the confounding effect of those variables on the observed relationship between exposure and outcome.
  • For example, since both age and smoking are known to influence the risk of chronic bronchitis and may also be associated with air pollution exposure, matching on these variables helps isolate the true effect of air pollution.
  • However, matching is only effective for variables that are known and measurable at the time of study design.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bias: Bias refers to systematic errors in the study process, such as selection bias or information bias. Matching does not eliminate bias; methods like blinding, using standardized data collection tools, or random sampling are more appropriate for that purpose.

 

Option C. Unknown confounding: By definition, matching cannot address variables that are not known or identified at the time of study design. Unknown confounders may still distort results despite matching.

 

Option D. Known + Unknown confounding: Matching does not handle unknown confounding. It is limited to variables that are specifically identified and selected during study planning. Randomization removes both known and unknown confounding

 

Educational Objective:

 

Matching is used in observational study design to control for known confounding variables, improving the validity of the association between exposure and outcome.

choices.text: Cleaning the eyes with a wet sterile swab
Giving a bath immediately after birth
Placing the baby on the mother’s chest

questions.text: Which of the following is considered harmful to a newborn in the immediate postnatal period?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giving a bath immediately after birth

 

  • Giving a bath to a newborn immediately after birth is harmful because it can lead to:
    • Hypothermia: Newborns lose heat rapidly due to a large surface area-to-body weight ratio. Bathing removes the vernix caseosa (a white, creamy, protective layer), and the exposure to cold water/air can drop the baby's core temperature significantly.
    • Respiratory distress: Due to cold stress, babies may exhibit increased respiratory effort or apnea.
    • Hypoglycemia: The stress response and cold environment increase glucose consumption, risking hypoglycemia.
  • WHO and national newborn care guidelines recommend delaying the first bath for at least 24 hours, or at minimum 6 hours if 24 is not feasible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cleaning the eyes with a wet sterile swab: This is a standard preventive measure to clean debris and reduce the risk of neonatal conjunctivitis (ophthalmia neonatorum), especially in high-risk deliveries. This practice does not harm the baby.

 

Option C. Initiating breastfeeding within 1 hour: Known as early initiation of breastfeeding, this is highly beneficial. It provides the baby with colostrum—rich in immunoglobulins—and promotes bonding, temperature regulation, and glucose stability.

 

Option D. Placing the baby on the mother’s chest: This is skin-to-skin contact or Kangaroo Mother Care, and is strongly recommended immediately after birth. It helps maintain the newborn’s body temperature, heart rate, and breathing, and also encourages early breastfeeding initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the immediate postnatal period, harmful practices such as early bathing must be avoided due to the risk of hypothermia and related complications.
  • WHO recommends delaying the first bath to preserve warmth and promote neonatal stability.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has experienced intermittent abdominal cramps and diarrhea for over a year. A stool wet mount reveals numerous large, operculated trematode eggs measuring approximately 160–190 µm in length. Which parasite is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola gigantica

 

Egg morphology and size:

 

  • Fasciola gigantica is a trematode whose eggs are oval, bile-stained, operculated, and notably large (160–190 µm × 70–90 µm).
  • The chronic intermittent GI symptoms reflect the parasite’s migration through the biliary tree and subsequent fibrosis rather than an acute intestinal illness.

 

Clinical course:

 

  • Acute phase (1–2 weeks after ingestion): Larval migration through liver parenchyma causes fever, right-upper-quadrant pain, hepatomegaly, and eosinophilia.
  • Chronic phase: Adults in bile ducts produce eggs that pass into the intestine, leading to biliary colic, intermittent diarrhea, and malabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma braziliense : A canine hookworm; humans harbor only the larval stage (cutaneous larva migrans). No eggs are produced in human stool, and egg size (~60–75 µm) is much smaller.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma caninum: A canine hookworm; humans harbor only the larval stage (cutaneous larva migrans). No eggs are produced in human stool, and egg size (~60–75 µm) is much smaller.

 

Option D. Opisthorchis viverrini: A small liver fluke; eggs are ~27 µm × 15 µm, operculated with a small shoulder. Infection leads to cholangitis and increased cholangiocarcinoma risk, but egg size and shape differ greatly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large, operculated trematode eggs (>150 µm) in a patient with biliary-type abdominal pain and chronic diarrhea point to Fasciola gigantica, a liver fluke that matures in bile ducts.

choices.text: Chronic hypersensitivity reaction to inhaled antigens

questions.text: A 42-year-old man reports gradually worsening shortness of breath over the past several years. He has no history of smoking. Physical examination reveals hyperresonant lung fields with diminished breath sounds. A chest radiograph demonstrates flattened diaphragms and diffuse hyperlucency of both lungs. Pulmonary function testing shows a decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio. His younger sibling has been diagnosed with a similar lung condition. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient’s pulmonary disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduced anti-elastase activity

 

  • This patient’s presentation — progressive dyspnea in a young, nonsmoking adult, family history, imaging with hyperinflation and flattened diaphragms, and obstructive spirometry pattern — is consistent with panacinar emphysema from alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency.
  • AAT is a protease inhibitor that primarily blocks neutrophil elastase.
  • In AAT deficiency, reduced anti-elastase activity leads to unopposed elastase-mediated destruction of alveolar walls.
  • This results in loss of elastic recoil, air trapping, and diffuse emphysema, classically involving the lower lobes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation in surfactant protein genes: Seen in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome and some interstitial lung diseases, not emphysema due to protease-antiprotease imbalance.

 

Option C. Chronic hypersensitivity reaction to inhaled antigens: Causes hypersensitivity pneumonitis, an interstitial lung disease with granulomatous inflammation, not panacinar emphysema.

 

Option D. CFTR gene mutation: CFTR defects cause cystic fibrosis, which presents with recurrent lung infections, bronchiectasis, and pancreatic insufficiency — not isolated emphysema with family history of early-onset disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency leads to early-onset panacinar emphysema due to reduced anti-elastase activity, causing unopposed elastase-mediated alveolar wall destruction, especially in the lower lobes.

questions.text: A 56-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with persistent, foul-smelling vaginal discharge and occasional blood-tinged mucus for several weeks. On pelvic examination, an ulcerated necrotic lesion is noted on the cervix with evidence of extension into the surrounding parametrium. There is no evidence of distant metastasis or palpable lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Concurrent chemoradiation

 

  • The clinical presentation—postmenopausal woman with necrotic cervical lesion that has extended into the parametrium—is characteristic of locally advanced cervical cancer, likely Stage IIB.
  • According to FIGO staging, involvement of the parametrium without extension to the pelvic sidewall falls under Stage IIB. 
  • At this stage, the standard of care is concurrent chemoradiation, which includes:
    • External beam radiotherapy (EBRT) targeting the pelvic region.
    • Cisplatin-based chemotherapy given concurrently to sensitize tumor cells to radiation.
  • Surgery (e.g., radical hysterectomy) is not preferred once the disease involves the parametrium, as this significantly increases morbidity without improving outcomes. 
  • Early-stage cervical cancers (Stage IA–IB1) are typically managed surgically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chemotherapy: Systemic chemotherapy alone is not sufficient for treating locally advanced cervical cancer. It is typically reserved for metastatic or recurrent disease or used as part of concurrent chemoradiation, not as a standalone initial treatment in Stage IIB.

 

Option C. Brachytherapy: While brachytherapy (internal radiation) is an important component of treatment, it is not used alone in Stage IIB disease. It is generally added after external beam radiation as part of the full chemoradiation regimen.

 

Option D. Surgery: Radical hysterectomy is not recommended once there is parametrial invasion. At this point, the tumor is considered inoperable, and surgery would carry greater risks and no additional benefit compared to chemoradiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Stage IIB cervical cancer, where there is parametrial involvement without distant metastasis, the standard treatment is concurrent chemoradiation, combining external beam radiation and cisplatin-based chemotherapy for optimal tumor control.

questions.text: A 54-year-old postmenopausal woman undergoes pelvic ultrasound as part of her evaluation for abnormal uterine bleeding. The report shows an endometrial thickness of 15–16 mm, with heterogeneous echotexture, few cysts, and no internal vascularity on Doppler imaging. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schedule endometrial biopsy

 

  • An endometrial thickness 5 mm in a postmenopausal woman is concerning, especially when associated with heterogeneous echotexture, cysts, or other abnormal features. 
  • In this case, the thickness of 15–16 mm is markedly abnormal. 
  • Even though the Doppler study shows no internal vascularity, this does not exclude endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy. 
  • Therefore, endometrial biopsy is warranted to evaluate for endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and Observe: Not appropriate given the endometrial thickness far exceeds the normal postmenopausal cutoff of 4 mm. Observation could delay diagnosis of a potentially serious pathology.

 

Option B. Start hormonal therapy: Empirical treatment is not recommended without histological confirmation, especially when malignancy is on the differential.

 

Option D. Repeat ultrasound in 6 months: Delayed evaluation is inappropriate in this context. Prompt biopsy is necessary to rule out serious conditions like carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women, an endometrial thickness >4 mm with heterogeneous echotexture and/or cysts requires further evaluation with endometrial biopsy to rule out hyperplasia or carcinoma.

questions.text: A 2-week-old newborn presents with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and periventricular calcifications on cranial imaging. The mother had a mild, flu-like illness during her second trimester. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this newborn’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

 

  • CMV is the most common congenital viral infection.
  • Classic features:
    • Periventricular calcifications
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
    • Microcephaly, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia (blueberry muffin rash)
  • Transmitted transplacentally, especially if the mother has a primary infection during pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Toxoplasma gondii:

 

  • Causes diffuse intracranial calcifications (not periventricular) and chorioretinitis.
  • Often associated with severe hydrocephalus.

 

Option B. Rubella virus:

 

  • Causes congenital rubella syndrome: cataracts, sensorineural deafness, PDA.
  • Calcifications are not typical.

 

Option D. Herpes simplex virus (HSV):

 

  • Usually acquired during delivery, not transplacentally.
  • Presents with vesicular skin lesions, seizures, and temporal lobe encephalitis, not periventricular calcifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital CMV is the most common cause of periventricular calcifications in neonates, associated with hearing loss, microcephaly, and jaundice, especially following a maternal flu-like illness during pregnancy.

choices.text: Production of aflatoxin leading to p53 gene mutation
High rate of hepatocyte proliferation with genomic instability
Increased risk of hepatic iron deposition with DNA damage
Chronic alcohol use leading to acetaldehyde-induced DNA breaks

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is being followed for chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. He has no history of alcohol use. Laboratory studies reveal persistently elevated ALT and AST levels. Abdominal ultrasound shows evidence of cirrhosis. Which of the following mechanisms best explains his increased risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High rate of hepatocyte proliferation with genomic instability

 

  • HBV is a DNA virus that causes chronic hepatocyte injury and regeneration.
  • The increased hepatocyte turnover and proliferation raise the chance of accumulating genetic mutations.
  • In addition, HBV DNA integrates into the host genome, leading to genomic instability and potential inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • These combined effects markedly increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), even in the absence of cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Production of aflatoxin leading to p53 gene mutation: This mechanism is seen in aflatoxin B1 exposure (e.g., from Aspergillus-contaminated grains), not HBV.

 

Option C. Increased risk of hepatic iron deposition with DNA damage: Refers to hereditary hemochromatosis, which can cause HCC, but is unrelated to HBV infection.

 

Option D. Chronic alcohol use leading to acetaldehyde-induced DNA breaks: Alcohol is an independent risk factor for HCC, but the patient has no alcohol use history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic HBV infection increases the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma through ongoing hepatocyte proliferation and HBV DNA integration into the host genome, leading to genetic instability and oncogenesis.

questions.text:
During a biochemistry review session, a student makes the following claims about the citric acid cycle:

  1. Pyruvate directly condenses with oxaloacetate to form citrate.
  2. α-Ketoglutarate is a five-carbon intermediate.
  3. Oxidative phosphorylation takes place in the cytoplasm.
  4. The citric acid cycle can operate under anaerobic conditions.

Which statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Statement 2 only

 

Statement 2. α-Ketoglutarate is a five-carbon intermediate: True. α-Ketoglutarate contains five carbons and is produced by oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Pyruvate directly condenses with oxaloacetate to form citrate: False. Pyruvate is first converted to acetyl-CoA by the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex; acetyl-CoA (2 carbons) then combines with oxaloacetate (4 carbons) to form citrate.

 

Statement 3. Oxidative phosphorylation takes place in the cytoplasm: False. Oxidative phosphorylation occurs on the inner mitochondrial membrane, not in the cytoplasm.

 

Statement 4. The citric acid cycle can operate under anaerobic conditions: False. The cycle requires regeneration of NAD⁺ and FAD via the electron transport chain, which depends on oxygen as the final electron acceptor; thus it cannot function anaerobically.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The citric acid cycle’s α-ketoglutarate intermediate has five carbons, acetyl-CoA must form first to condense with oxaloacetate, and the cycle’s continuous operation relies on mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation under aerobic conditions.

choices.text: Inertization with cement and simultaneous encapsulation
Direct disposal in a sanitary landfill

questions.text: A hospital needs to dispose off, expired pharmaceuticals and metal‑rich incinerator ash in a way that both immobilizes hazardous constituents and permits safe landfilling. Which approach is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inertization with cement and simultaneous encapsulation

 

  • Inertization mixes waste (pharmaceuticals, metal‑laden ash) with cement 15% and lime 15%, chemically stabilizing and immobilizing soluble toxins.
  • Encapsulation then seals the mixture within a durable matrix (e.g., cement mortar), preventing leachate generation. 
  • Together, these steps ensure that hazardous chemicals and heavy metals remain locked in and do not contaminate groundwater when landfilled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encapsulation in plastic foam only: Seals waste but does not chemically bind heavy metals or soluble pharmaceuticals, risking future leaching.

 

Option C. Direct disposal in a sanitary landfill: Bypasses any stabilization—hazardous constituents can readily migrate into soil and groundwater.

 

Option D. Shredding followed by compacting: Reduces volume but neither stabilizes toxins nor prevents leaching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hazardous wastes with soluble toxins or heavy metals, combine inertization (chemical binding) with encapsulation (physical sealing) to achieve immobilization and safe landfill disposal.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with stress urinary incontinence, weight loss and tingling in her feet for 3 months. On examination she has hepatosplenomegaly and bruising in her arms. On examination, Phalen’s sign is positive and urinalysis reveals a 3+ proteinuria. Labs: Hb is 12 g/dL, and S. creatinine is 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum protein electrophoresis

 

  • Proteinuria, peripheral neuropathy (pain, tingling), hepatosplenomegaly, bruising, carpal tunnel syndrome, and weight loss suggest amyloidosis. 
  • Given her age and renal failure – multiple myeloma is highly likely. 
  • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) with immunofixation detects monoclonal proteins or light chains, key for diagnosing plasma cell disorders. 
  • Amyloidosis causes organ infiltration (liver, spleen, nerves) and carpal tunnel from tissue deposition.
  • Elevated creatinine indicates renal involvement, common in these conditions.
  • SPEP is non-invasive, guiding further workup (e.g., bone marrow biopsy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electromyography: Assesses neuropathy but not systemic cause.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B serology: Unrelated to proteinuria or systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Liver biopsy: Invasive, not first-line for suspected amyloidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amyloidosis presents with proteinuria, neuropathy, and organomegaly.
  • SPEP is the initial test for plasma cell disorders.
  • Non-invasive tests precede biopsy.

questions.text: A man is flying on 3,400 m. He develops confusion, headache, and cerebral edema. Which of the following mechanisms best describes high altitude cerebral edema?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypoxia causing cerebral vasodilation

 

  • At high altitude, the reduced atmospheric oxygen pressure lowers alveolar PO₂, resulting in hypoxaemia.
  • This hypoxic state causes direct vasodilation of cerebral vessels, increasing cerebral blood flow in an effort to maintain oxygen delivery to brain tissue. 
  • However, excessive vasodilation, coupled with increased capillary permeability, leads to vasogenic cerebral edema. 
  • The accumulation of fluid within the brain raises intracranial pressure, producing symptoms such as headache, confusion, ataxia, and altered mental status — the hallmark features of high‑altitude cerebral edema (HACE).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis leading to edema: Initial response to hypoxia is respiratory alkalosis from hyperventilation, not metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. Hypoxia causing cerebral vasoconstriction: Hypoxia causes pulmonary vasoconstriction, but cerebral vessels respond with vasodilation.

 

Option D. High PCO₂ causing cerebral vasoconstriction: High PCO₂ (hypercapnia) causes vasodilation, not vasoconstriction, in cerebral circulation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • High‑altitude cerebral edema is caused by hypoxia‑induced cerebral vasodilation and increased permeability of the blood–brain barrier, leading to vasogenic edema. 
  • It’s a potentially fatal complication of rapid ascent and requires prompt descent and oxygen therapy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with sudden-onset palpitations and dizziness. ECG shows a narrow-complex regular tachycardia at 180 bpm, consistent with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). She is hemodynamically stable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine

 

  • Adenosine is the drug of choice for acute termination of AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), the most common form of PSVT. 
  • It acts by transiently blocking AV nodal conduction, interrupting the reentry circuit and restoring sinus rhythm. 
  • Its action is extremely short-lived (half-life <10 seconds), making it ideal for acute use.
  • Dose in adults – IV first dose of 6 mg → (if not controlled) 12 mg second dose → (if not controlled) 12 mg third dose. 3 doses can be used.
  • Dose in children – IV 0.1 mg/kg first dose → (if not controlled) 0.2 mg/kg second dose → (if not controlled) 0.2 mg/kg third dose. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Used for ventricular arrhythmias or atrial fibrillation; not first-line for PSVT due to slower onset and more toxic profile.

 

Option C. Propranolol: A beta-blocker that can slow AV nodal conduction, but it is not as rapid-acting as adenosine in acute PSVT.

 

Option D. Quinidine: A class IA antiarrhythmic used historically for atrial or ventricular arrhythmias; not effective for AVNRT and associated with significant side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine is the first-line drug for acute management of stable AV nodal–dependent supraventricular tachycardias, due to its rapid AV nodal blockade and ultra-short half-life.

 

Prophylaxis for PSVT – DOC is Verapamil

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with low-grade fever, sore mouth, and painful vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and inside the mouth. The child attends daycare, and similar cases have been reported. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxsackie virus

 

  • Coxsackie A16 virus is the most common cause of Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD). 
  • It presents with mild fever, oral ulcers, and vesicular rash on hands and feet. 
  • It is highly contagious in daycare settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV): Typically causes infectious mononucleosis with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly—not vesicular rash on extremities.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex Virus (HSV): Causes gingivostomatitis in children but does not involve hands and feet typically.

 

Option D. Varicella–zoster Virus (VZV): Causes chickenpox or shingles, usually with generalized vesicular rash starting on the trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie virus, particularly A16, is the most common cause of HFMD in children, presenting with oral ulcers and vesicles on hands and feet, often in outbreaks in daycare centers.

questions.text: Organ which can utilize glucose, fatty acids and ketone bodies, is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Skeletal Muscle

 

  • Skeletal muscle is metabolically flexible and can use multiple fuel sources depending on the situation:
    1. Glucose – During fed state and high-intensity exercise (via glycolysis)
    2. Fatty acids – During fasting and prolonged low-intensity exercise (via β-oxidation)
    3. Ketone bodies – During prolonged fasting or starvation (via ketolysis)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: Can use glucose and fatty acids, but does not use ketone bodies (it produces them but lacks the enzyme thiophorase for ketone utilization).

 

Option B. Brain:

 

  • Normally uses only glucose; during prolonged fasting, it can adapt to use ketone bodies.
  • Does not use fatty acids directly because they cannot cross the blood–brain barrier.

 

Option D. RBC:

 

  • Can only use glucose (anaerobic glycolysis) because they lack mitochondria;
  • Cannot use fatty acids or ketones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skeletal muscle can oxidize glucose, fatty acids, and ketone bodies, allowing metabolic flexibility across fed, fasting, and exercise states. The liver does not use ketones, the brain cannot use fatty acids, and RBCs rely only on glucose due to absence of mitochondria.

choices.text: Pleomorphic adenoma of the lacrimal gland
Adenoid cystic carcinoma of the lacrimal gland

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the superotemporal orbit. Examination reveals downward and inward displacement of the globe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pleomorphic adenoma of the lacrimal gland

 

Key point in question:

 

  • Painless, slowly enlarging superotemporal orbital mass
  • Downward and inward globe displacement → suggests lesion in lacrimal gland region (superotemporal orbit)
  • Benign, slow growth → pleomorphic adenoma is most likely.
  • Most common benign epithelial tumor of lacrimal gland.
  • Typically affects middle-aged adults.
  • Presents as a slowly progressive, painless swelling in superotemporal orbit.
  • Displaces the globe downward and inward.
  • No bone destruction on imaging (may cause smooth fossa expansion).
  • Complete excision without biopsy is recommended (biopsy may seed tumor cells and cause recurrence).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic carcinoma of the lacrimal gland:

 

  • Most common malignant epithelial tumor of lacrimal gland.
  • Pain is a key feature (due to perineural invasion).
  • Rapid progression.
  • May cause bone destruction and irregular margins on imaging.
  • Displaces globe downward and inward, but more aggressive clinical course.

 

Option C. Oncocytoma of the lacrimal gland:

 

  • Rare, benign epithelial tumor of lacrimal gland.
  • Usually affects older adults, often asymptomatic until large.

 

Option D. Lacrimal gland dacryoadenitis:

 

  • Inflammatory swelling of lacrimal gland.
  • Usually acute onset, painful, often associated with redness and tenderness.
  • May be caused by viral (mumps, EBV) or bacterial infections.
  • Resolves with treatment of underlying infection/inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In orbital mass evaluation, note the globe’s displacement: a down-and-in shift is highly suggestive of a superotemporal lesion such as a pleomorphic adenoma of the lacrimal gland.

choices.text: D2 receptor antagonism in the mesolimbic pathway
5-HT2A receptor antagonism in the prefrontal cortex
H1 and 5-HT2C receptor antagonism in the hypothalamus
NMDA receptor antagonism in the limbic system

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with schizophrenia started on olanzapine reports rapid weight gain within 3 months. Which of the following receptor mechanisms is most implicated in the pathophysiology of antipsychotic-induced weight gain?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) H1 and 5-HT2C receptor antagonism in the hypothalamus

 

  • Olanzapine, like clozapine, is well-known for causing significant weight gain and metabolic syndrome. 
  • The key mechanism behind this is antagonism at the histamine H1 receptors and serotonin 5-HT2C receptors in the hypothalamus, which leads to increased appetite and decreased satiety, contributing to hyperphagia and weight gain. 
  • These receptors play a central role in regulating feeding behavior and energy homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. D2 receptor antagonism in the mesolimbic pathway: This mechanism is central to antipsychotic efficacy (especially for positive symptoms), but not primarily responsible for weight gain.

 

Option B. 5-HT2A receptor antagonism in the prefrontal cortex: While 5-HT2A antagonism contributes to antipsychotic effects and improved cognition, it does not explain weight gain.

 

Option D. NMDA receptor antagonism in the limbic system: NMDA antagonism is not a primary action of most antipsychotics (except perhaps ketamine-like agents) and is not involved in weight gain related to antipsychotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pathophysiology of antipsychotic induced weight gain:

 

 

  • Aripiprazole and ziprasidone are two antipsychotics with a relatively lower risk of weight gain compared to others. 
  • Olanzapine and clozapine are most associated with weight gain.

questions.text:
A single-base change in a gene converts the codon GAC (encoding aspartic acid) to GAG (encoding glutamic acid). Which of the following descriptors best classify this mutation? 

 

  1. Point mutation
  2. Silent mutation
  3. Nonsense mutation
  4. Conservative amino acid change
  5. Non-conservative amino acid change
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

 

1. Point mutation: A point mutation is a single‐nucleotide substitution. Here, guanine replaces cytosine in the third base of the codon.

 

4. Conservative amino acid change: Aspartic acid and glutamic acid are both acidic, negatively charged amino acids with similar structures. Replacing one with the other typically preserves protein function conservative change.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

2. Silent mutation: Would require the codon change not alter the encoded amino acid (e.g.,UCA replace by UCU both code for Serine).

 

3. Nonsense mutation: Changes a sense codon to a stop codon, prematurely truncating translation. If a codon is replaced by stop codon 

 

5. Non-conservative change: Occurs when the new amino acid has very different properties (e.g., a polar to a nonpolar residue), which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point mutations can change protein sequence; when they swap amino acids with similar properties (acidic to acidic), they are termed conservative substitutions, usually less disruptive to protein function.

choices.text: Iron 132 μg/dL, TIBC 299 μg/dL, ferritin 204 ng/mL
Iron 210 μg/dL, TIBC 350 μg/dL, ferritin 375 ng/mL

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents with fatigue and dyspnea. His wife is concerned with him eating excessive ice in the recent times. On examination, he has angular cheilitis and atrophic glossitis. Labs: Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL, MCV: 75 fL. What will his iron studies most likely reveal? 

(Normal: iron 60-170 μg/dL, TIBC 240-450 μg/dL, ferritin 12-250 ng/mL)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iron/TIBC <18%, ferritin 5 ng/mL

 

  • This patient has classic signs of iron deficiency anemia, including:
    • Fatigue, dyspnea
    • Pica (ice chewing) — highly specific for iron deficiency
    • Angular cheilitis and atrophic glossitis
    • Guaiac-positive stool — suggesting chronic GI blood loss (most likely cause in older men)
    • Microcytic anemia (MCV 75 fL)
  • Iron studies in iron deficiency anemia typically show:
    • Low serum iron
    • Increased TIBC
    • Low ferritin
    • Transferrin saturation <18%

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron 132 μg/dL, TIBC 299 μg/dL, ferritin 204 ng/mL: These values are within normal limits, not compatible with iron deficiency.

 

Option B. Iron 210 μg/dL, TIBC 350 μg/dL, ferritin 375 ng/mL: Suggestive of iron overload; not consistent with clinical and hematologic features.

 

Option D. Iron/TIBC >18%, ferritin 314 ng/mL:Ferritin is elevated and transferrin saturation normal/high — not consistent with iron deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pica, glossitis, and angular cheilitis are hallmark signs of iron deficiency anemia.
  • Guaiac-positive stool indicates chronic GI bleeding, the most common source of iron loss in elderly males.
  • Iron deficiency labs: low serum iron, low ferritin, high TIBC, and low transferrin saturation (<18%).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy at 17 weeks’ gestation presents requesting a pregnancy termination. The clinician decides to proceed with an intrauterine method involving extra-amniotic instillation. Which of the following pharmacologic agents is most appropriately administered via this route?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethacridine lactate

 

  • Ethacridine lactate is an antiseptic agent commonly used in second-trimester pregnancy termination, especially between 12–20 weeks gestation, via the extra-amniotic route. 
  • The procedure involves insertion of a Foley catheter through the cervix and instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space.
  • It is safe, inexpensive, and widely used in resource-limited settings.
  • This agent induces abortion by stimulating uterine contractions and separation of the placenta. 
  • It is preferred in specific gestational windows when medical induction is indicated but systemic agents are either contraindicated or avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used in the induction of labor, particularly in the third trimester, or for postpartum uterine atony. It is not administered via extra-amniotic route and is less effective for mid-trimester abortion due to lower sensitivity of the uterus to oxytocin at that stage.

 

Option B. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone (PGE2) is typically used for cervical ripening and labor induction, often via vaginal or intracervical routes. It is not the agent of choice for extra-amniotic instillation, making it an incorrect option here.

 

Option D. Carboprost: Carboprost is a 15-methyl prostaglandin F2-alpha analog used intramuscularly for second-trimester abortion and postpartum hemorrhage. However, it is not administered via extra-amniotic route, and its systemic side effects (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) can be limiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ethacridine lactate is the agent of choice for extra-amniotic instillation during second-trimester pregnancy termination, typically between 12–20 weeks gestation. 
  • It provides a localized method of induction with minimal systemic side effects.

choices.text: Creeps well on hands and knees

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought for a routine check-up. Which of the following developmental milestones is most likely to be present at this age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Creeps well on hands and knees

 

  • At 9 months of age, an infant typically achieves important gross motor and fine motor milestones. 
  • Among the gross motor milestones, creeping on hands and knees is expected and reflects developing strength and coordination of the upper and lower limbs.
  • This behavior involves a cross-pattern movement where the opposite hand and knee move together, a significant neuromotor advancement from earlier belly crawling.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mature pincer grasp: This fine motor milestone (using the tips of the thumb and index finger to pick up small objects) usually develops around 10 to 12 months. At 9 months, the infant may exhibit an inferior pincer grasp but not yet the mature form.

 

Option C. Can hop on one foot: This is a much later developmental milestone, typically achieved by 3.5 to 4 years of age. It requires substantial balance and lower limb strength not seen in infancy.

 

Option D. Runs steadily: This occurs around 18 months of age, once the child is confidently walking. At 9 months, most infants are either crawling or cruising (holding onto furniture to walk).

 

Educational Objective:

 

At 9 months, normal gross motor milestones include creeping on hands and knees, sitting without support, and pulling to stand; mature pincer grasp and more advanced locomotor skills occur at later developmental stages.

questions.text: The figure shows the ventricular action potential in control (red) and after administration of Drug A (dashed line). Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the observed changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lignocaine

 

  • The graph demonstrates a shortening of the action potential duration after administration of Drug A. 
  • This effect is characteristic of class IB antiarrhythmic drugs like lignocaine (lidocaine). 
  • These drugs preferentially bind to inactivated sodium channels, especially in ischemic or depolarized tissue, and accelerate repolarization by shortening phase 3 of the action potential.
  • This is particularly useful in ventricular arrhythmias, especially post-myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quinidine: A class IA agent that prolongs the action potential duration and QT interval.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: A class III drug that markedly prolongs repolarization and action potential duration.

 

Option D. Flecainide: A class IC agent with minimal effect on repolarization; it significantly slows conduction without shortening the AP duration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class IB antiarrhythmic drugs like lignocaine shorten the ventricular action potential duration, especially in depolarized or ischemic tissue.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man on high-dose risperidone develops tremor, rigidity, and mask-like facies. Drug-induced Parkinsonism is diagnosed. Which of the following medications would be least effective in treating his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selegiline

 

  • Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B inhibitor used in idiopathic Parkinson’s disease to reduce central dopamine metabolism. 
  • However, in drug-induced Parkinsonism, dopamine receptors are blocked by antipsychotics, so increasing dopamine levels is not helpful. 
  • Thus, selegiline is ineffective in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benztropine: An anticholinergic agent similar to trihexyphenidyl, effective in treating DIP.

 

Option B. Promethazine: An antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, often used acutely for EPS.

 

Option D. Trihexyphenidyl: The first-line agent for DIP due to its central anticholinergic action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selegiline is not effective for drug-induced Parkinsonism because it requires intact dopaminergic pathways and does not overcome D2 receptor blockade. Anticholinergics remain the mainstay treatment.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with abdominal distension and heavy menstrual bleeding. On physical examination, a smooth, firm, non-tender, and mobile abdominal mass is palpated, extending from the symphysis pubis to midway between the umbilicus and xiphisternum. Speculum examination reveals a normal cervix. Laboratory evaluation reveals microcytic anemia. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leiomyoma

 

  • The patient’s presentation of progressive abdominal distension, heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia), and microcytic anemia in association with a firm, smooth, non-tender, and mobile abdominal mass extending well above the symphysis pubis is most consistent with uterine leiomyomas (fibroids).
  • Fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the myometrium that can grow to large sizes, causing a palpable abdominal mass.
  • Heavy menstrual bleeding from fibroids can lead to iron deficiency anemia, which explains her microcytic indices.
  • The normal cervix on speculum examination further supports a uterine (rather than cervical) pathology.
  • The mass's mobility and smooth contour are also classic features of fibroids, differentiating them from fixed or irregular adnexal masses.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian cyst: While large ovarian cysts may cause abdominal fullness or mass effect, they are typically not associated with menorrhagia or microcytic anemia, and are often cystic and fluctuant, unlike the firm consistency noted here.

 

Option C. Endometriosis: Presents with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and infertility, but not with a palpable abdominal mass or such profound uterine enlargement. The absence of chronic pelvic pain and tenderness argues against this.

 

Option D. Adenomyosis: Usually affects multiparous women and causes dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and a diffusely enlarged, boggy uterus, not a well-defined, large, mobile mass as seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine leiomyomas (fibroids) are the most common benign tumors of the female reproductive tract.
  • Large fibroids can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, iron deficiency anemia, and a firm, smooth, enlarged uterus palpable on abdominal examination.

questions.text: A 28-week preterm newborn has a continuous murmur, bounding pulses, and wide pulse pressure. CXR shows pulmonary plethora. Which drug can close the defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indomethacin

 

  • The vignette describes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in a preterm neonate (continuous murmur, bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, pulmonary plethora).
  • In premature infants, the ductus arteriosus remains open due to immaturity and increased prostaglandin E2 levels.
  • Indomethacin (or ibuprofen) is a prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (NSAID) that promotes closure of the ductus arteriosus by reducing prostaglandin E2 levels.
  • Hence, Indomethacin is the drug of choice to close PDA in preterm neonates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prostaglandin E1:

 

  • Prostaglandin E1 is given to maintain ductal patency in cases where systemic or pulmonary blood flow depends on PDA (e.g., transposition of great arteries, hypoplastic left heart syndrome, pulmonary atresia).
  • It is used to keep the duct open until surgical or catheter intervention can be performed.
  • Here, the goal is closure, not patency, so this is incorrect.

 

Option C. Furosemide:

 

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can be used to treat symptomatic heart failure from left-to-right shunts, as it reduces pulmonary congestion.
  • However, it does not close PDA. In fact, it may increase prostaglandin E2 production and worsen ductal patency.
  • Thus, it is supportive but not curative.

 

Option D. Dopamine:

 

  • Dopamine is an inotrope and vasopressor used for shock and hypotension in neonates.
  • It has no role in closure of PDA.
  • Hence, incorrect in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In preterm infants, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) commonly presents with a continuous murmur, bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, and pulmonary overcirculation on chest X-ray. 
  • Closure of PDA is achieved pharmacologically using Indomethacin or Ibuprofen (both prostaglandin synthesis inhibitors)

questions.text: Which genetic syndrome is caused by a deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cri-du-chat syndrome

 

  • Cri-du-chat syndrome (French for “cry of the cat”) is a chromosomal deletion syndrome caused by a partial deletion of the short arm (p) of chromosome 5 — specifically 5p15.2.
  • Characteristic high-pitched cat-like cry in infants is due to abnormal laryngeal development.
  • Other features include microcephaly, intellectual disability, hypertelorism, low birth weight, and hypotonia.
  • It is a classic example of a structural chromosomal abnormality and is diagnosed via karyotyping or FISH.
  • Incidence is approximately 1 in 20,000 to 50,000 live births.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Edward Syndrome:

 

  • Also known as Trisomy 18 (presence of an extra chromosome 18).
  • Not caused by a deletion, but by a nondisjunction event.
  • Features include clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, micrognathia, and cardiac defects.
  • Incompatible with long-term survival.

 

Option B. Patau Syndrome:

 

  • Also known as Trisomy 13.
  • Caused by a full extra copy of chromosome 13.
  • Clinical signs include cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, holoprosencephaly, and congenital heart defects.
  • Again, not a deletion syndrome.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Genotype is 45, XO, due to complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, not chromosome 5.
  • Presents with short stature, webbed neck, streak ovaries, primary amenorrhea, and cardiac anomalies (e.g., coarctation of aorta).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cri-du-chat syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by a deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p−), classically presenting with a high-pitched cat-like cry, microcephaly, and developmental delay.

questions.text:
From the steps below, what is the correct sequence of Damage Control Surgery? 

 

1. Patient selection

2. Resuscitation in ICU

3. Abdomen closure

4. Control of hemorrhage
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 4, 2, 3

 

  • Damage Control Surgery (DCS) is a strategy in trauma management where the priority is stabilization rather than definitive repair, especially in critically ill patients. 
  • The sequence is crucial and follows this step-wise progression:
    1. Patient Selection: Identifying patients who would benefit from DCS—typically those with acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy.
    2. Primary Exploration: A quick initial surgery to control bleeding and contamination.
    3. ICU Care: The patient is shifted to the ICU for resuscitation, correction of hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy.
    4. Secondary Exploration: After physiological stabilization, a second surgery is performed to reassess and plan for definitive care.
    5. Abdominal Closure: Only done once the patient is stable and definitive repair is complete.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the stepwise approach to damage control surgery: Initial patient selection, control of bleeding/contamination, ICU resuscitation, re-exploration, and eventual closure.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) on daily ibrutinib presents with fever, unintentional weight loss, and progressive lymphadenopathy. Labs reveal the following:

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

 

  • This patient with known CLL now presents with:
    • Constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss)
    • Rapidly enlarging lymphadenopathy
    • Markedly elevated LDH
    • Laboratory features of tumor lysis syndrome (hyperuricemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, and acute kidney injury)
  • These findings strongly suggest Richter transformation — the transformation of CLL into an aggressive high-grade lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).
  • Richter transformation occurs in ~2–10% of CLL patients and is associated with:
    • Worsening lymphadenopathy
    • Elevated LDH
    • “B” symptoms
    • Poor prognosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute CMV: CMV can cause fever in immunocompromised hosts but does not explain tumor lysis features or lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Stage 4 chronic lymphocytic leukemia: This is not a formal term used in CLL staging. The clinical deterioration and biochemical markers suggest transformation, not stable or progressive CLL alone.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia: No evidence of myeloid blast crisis; CLL rarely transforms into AML. The cytopenias and tumor lysis picture fit better with Richter transformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Richter transformation of CLL into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma presents with:
    • Rapid clinical decline, B symptoms, elevated LDH
    • Tumor lysis labs (↑ K⁺, ↑ uric acid, ↑ phosphate, ↓ calcium, ↑ creatinine)
  • It should be suspected in CLL patients with new systemic symptoms and aggressive disease features.
  • Tumor lysis syndrome can occur spontaneously in high-grade lymphomas.

choices.text: Placental attachment over the internal cervical os

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 22 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset, painless, heavy vaginal bleeding. She is hemodynamically stable, and fetal heart tones are present. Which of the following implantation sites is most likely responsible for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Placental attachment over the internal cervical os

 

  • The clinical scenario describes placenta previa, a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the internal cervical os.
  • It typically presents in the second or third trimester with painless vaginal bleeding and no abdominal pain or uterine tenderness. 
  • This diagnosis is supported by the presence of fetal heart tones, ruling out fetal demise, and the absence of trauma or infection.
  • Placenta previa is most common in women with prior uterine surgery or multiple pregnancies but can occur de novo. 
  • It requires close obstetric monitoring and usually necessitates cesarean delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian implantation: This is a rare type of ectopic pregnancy typically presenting earlier in gestation with abdominal pain and signs of rupture, not painless bleeding at 22 weeks.

 

Option B. Tubal implantation: Tubal pregnancies usually rupture in the first trimester, leading to acute abdominal pain and hemodynamic instability, which is not consistent with this patient's stable presentation and gestational age.

 

Option D. Abdominal implantation: An abdominal pregnancy is extremely rare, often results in poor fetal outcomes, and does not classically present with painless vaginal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta previa should be suspected in any pregnant patient beyond 20 weeks presenting with painless vaginal bleeding. 
  • The bleeding results from placental separation as the lower uterine segment thins and stretches. 
  • The condition is due to placental attachment over the internal os.

questions.text: The image shows a β-lactam ring structure found in penicillins. At which labeled site does penicillinase (β-lactamase) exert its action, leading to antibiotic resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Site A

 

  • Penicillinase (a type of β-lactamase) hydrolyzes the β-lactam ring, which is essential for the antibacterial activity of penicillins.
  • Site A in the image represents the β-lactam carbonyl group, a critical part of the four-membered β-lactam ring.
  • Cleavage at this site opens the ring and renders the molecule inactive, preventing its ability to inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Site B: Refers to a side-chain substitution; not the active site for β-lactamase.

 

Options C. Site C: Part of the carboxylic acid group in the side chain, not involved in β-lactamase interaction.

 

Options D. Site D: Represents a sulfur-linked moiety; not the cleavage site for penicillinase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penicillinase (β-lactamase) inactivates penicillins by cleaving the β-lactam ring at its carbonyl group, disabling its antibacterial activity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with persistent, profuse watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Imaging reveals a mass in the pancreas. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for symptomatic control?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Octreotide

 

  • The clinical picture is suggestive of a VIPoma, a rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that secretes vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to secretory diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria—also known as WDHA syndrome (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Octreotide, a long-acting somatostatin analog, inhibits the release of VIP and is the drug of choice for controlling symptoms related to hormone-secreting tumors such as VIPoma and carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmopressin: A synthetic ADH analog used for central diabetes insipidus and mild hemophilia A; it has no role in VIPoma.

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: An antiepileptic that stimulates ADH release; used in central diabetes insipidus, not in secretory diarrhea or tumors.
